review:
Ааа, вон оно что!

На самом деле, я сначала хотел написать, что считаю несправедливым что метроидваний так много, а зельд мало.

И вот вроде как зельда в стиле link’s awakening (с прыжком в top-down), немного скучноватая, немного прямолинейная, практически непонятная.
Бодро движется вперед, бодро сменяет локации, и как будто концовка недалеко и можно пройти за выходные.
Но все время кажется "что-то как-то простовато", зачем эта пустая локация, зачем здесь проход с тупиком?

А потом бац - и все таки тут больше, и вот уже понятно кем вдохновлялись https://store.steampowered.com/app/1628610/Paquerette_Down_the_Bunburrows/ и https://store.steampowered.com/app/2121980/Void_Stranger/

Такое мне очень нравится. [spoiler]Post-game mechanics рулят[/spoiler]. 

Остальным - на любителя, ремастер хорошо играется и управляется, но это все равно очень сильно indie, arrows+zxc и все такое. Идеально на steam deck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001635307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 306, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1710806078}
review:
You have to go into this game with the right mindset: it was made in less than a year, by two people who were still in college, using Flixel. To compare this with indie games nowadays doesn't do this game justice. But as a student project, it's great. The music is extremely eerie and unsettling. Definitely a lot of Eathbound influence. I do wish the story was more fleshed out. I don't understand the relations between some characters, and between characters and locations. But for 9 or 10 months, it's definitely understandable that those aspects didn't get more attention. 

I think this game really highlights the progression of expectations over the years. Games like this released now just disappear. That's really a shame and is to the detriment of the medium at large.

author: {'steamid': '76561198803548275', 'num_games_owned': 1303, 'num_reviews': 179, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1708016415}
review:
或许是很难安利的作品，但我还是想尝试写些什么。
我相当喜欢这个游戏，所以我想挣扎一下…只是多少有些不甘心如此用心且气质独特的作品被埋没。

2013年的游戏，在十周年之际推出了重制版（我在几年前打开玩过一段但好像是碰上了成就bug，重制版把mac的成就问题修了这真的很好！），目前从steam开启游戏的话，选项会默认选择游玩重制版。

显而易见，这不会是一个适合大多数人的游戏——相当有年代感的画面，较弱的引导，意识流的叙事风格，足以排除太多受众了。
但如果愿意用心窥探一下这个光怪陆离的世界，或许就能有一瞬仿若与制作者的心灵碰撞，或许…会深深为之着迷。


[h2]在我看来，《Anodyne》给玩家带来的体验一共能划分为明显的三段： [/h2]

[h3]第一段，游戏的最初部分。[/h3]
正如游戏描述所写，这是一个zelda-lite游戏，虽然模仿的好像是我没玩过的早期zelda作品（）总之，整个游戏的前半部分就是那种很正常的解谜+战斗+探索地牢的奇幻世界观冒险游戏。
[spoiler]lite也是真的lite，一周目慢慢摸索至全探索我只花了5h左右。为了尝试摸一下三小时内100％通关的成就，我开新档再跑了一遍，很多很多失误的情况下也仅用了2h左右，可能不利用bug正常通关的极限时间能压缩到一个半小时甚至一小时之内（）确实是很轻量了。jpg[strike]（用穿墙bug的话我见过最离谱的是十分钟…不过当然是any％ [/strike][/spoiler]

[h3]第二段，开启风车之后。[/h3]
此时也恰好是一周目的一半进度。在此之后解锁的地图，其主题与整体印象，可以说是急转直下。
杀戮，恶意，孤独，堆叠成山的尸体，质疑，悲剧，还有极其精污的8-bit迷宫…但与此同时，也有一些仿若游离在外的部分，有诗，有爱，有共情，有鼓舞，有对生命的讴歌。都是相当支离破碎的思维碎片，就像是在一个人的意识里四处游荡的感觉。相当独特的体验。
硬要用什么来比喻的话，大概就是在玩添加了一些解谜元素和碎片化台词的《梦日记》的感觉。

[h3]第三段，一周目结束之后。[/h3]
此时会解锁交换地图块的能力，可以随心所欲地走到正常的地图之外，探索隐藏区域，收集一些彩蛋道具与剩余的卡片。
——也就是，我最爱的，meta部分！（好耶！）
一般来说披露存在meta内容就已经算是剧透了，但我觉得我必须写出来！因为本作的meta内容作为通关后才解锁的玩法，[b]实在是太容易被错过了。[/b]
我对meta的好像不太确切的理解大致是：显然是在游戏之外的内容，但却也切切实实属于游戏的一部分。也就是说，如果要完整体验游戏的话，这也必定也是不容错过的部分！
嗯…这部分就不做过多剧透了，只能说推荐每个来玩《Anodyne》的朋友们都请一定要亲自尝试一下！这应当才是使其如此经典的原因。[b]如果说第二段的精神旅行似的体验是从心理上模糊了玩家与制作者的界限；那么这一段体验则是将玩家直接拉到了制作者的身边，一边共同胡闹似地“破坏”着游戏，一边像老友一样地饮茶谈心。[/b]


至于游戏的难度或者说门槛我感觉是偏低的。
由于是小体量的游戏，地图不大也不算太复杂，所以将能跑的地方都跑一遍就能轻松全收集（一周目）
解谜的引导其实做得不错，虽然都是较常见的机制但整体的设计与难度曲线的把控都相当的不错。不算有多突出但绝对不是短板。
战斗应该算是偏简单，保存点很密集，主角的血量也给的很富足，基本上除了最终boss由于带点解谜所以初见会比较茫然以外，别的boss都是追着瞎捅就能轻松初见过。但由于部分小怪和boss的奇妙走位，要追求无伤会比较难，但游戏也没做这部分的要求，甚至重制版还提供了使角色无敌的辅助模式可供选择 [spoiler]（我做速通成就时开启了无敌模式，能节省一些时间，也不会影响成就获取。不过事实证明不开启此模式的话，时间也能相当宽裕xd） [/spoiler]
总之，如果对能否获得良好体验有所顾虑的话，至少我的感受是游戏设计相当优秀，游玩体验自然流畅，虽然部分地图有些复杂但苯路痴也没怎么迷路（）只是较弱的引导可能会导致卡关，但四处多跑跑总能找到方向。

最终乱七八糟地写了这些。
只是希望如果有人愿意耐心看到这里，并且稍微有些感兴趣的话……能否给《Anodyne》一个机会呢 <3

author: {'steamid': '76561197999192194', 'num_games_owned': 877, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1707882973}
review:
"Anodyne" is a little Zelda-like that has equally some charm and 8-bit creepiness mixed in. The plot is hard to follow, and if it's a parody or send-up of something, I'm not sure what. You're a little dude and you wander around and do some small dungeons in a semi-open world,collecting cards of monsters and characters, 

It wants to be a Zelda clone, but lacks what makes Zelda interesting: polish, fun combat, and design. A slog. Not recommended.

Pros:
- Some interesting puzzles that require real thought to solve.
- Black and White Town is an unnerving reference of the famous Pokemon Lavender Town. I really liked this section.
- Every dungeon has its own unique mechanic, keeps it fresh.

Cons:
- I have no idea what the plot of this game is. What am I missing here?
- Awful combat. You can easily get stun-locked and hurt by wonky hitboxes. Enemy design is bare bones and bosses are either a joke or a headache.
- Very minimal map. You do a lot of backtracking, can get lost easily. Needs to indicate more clearly what that screen contains (such as a blocked path) and where exits are. At least fast travel is here.
- Way too easy to get completely stuck and have no clue where to go. Not fun.
- Navigation in dungeons can be a chore. Lots of one way paths, dead ends, and with a lackluster map you tend to wander far more than you should.
- Levels are thematically chaotic with no clear sense of progression. There's a circus next to a zombie maze. Okay?
- Music is very repetitive and since you'll be wandering a lot, you get to hear it constantly repeat.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980238525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1707232453}
review:
Do you like mazes?
Do you like constantly hitting dead ends?
Do you like large worlds that are mostly empty?
Do you like not having a useful map?
Do you like not having i-frames after being hit?
Do you like "quirky" indie games that pretend to be mature and deep by making allusions to trauma?
Do you like playing games with no sense of progression beyond collecting macguffins?

If you said no to *any* of these, avoid this game. This game is boring, frustrating, and pointless. With how many stereotypes and cliches that make up its design, it's basically a parody of *that kind* of indie game... the kind that hipster game journos name drop for cred.

I'll end on an amusing anecdote: according to my Steam play history, I had put in a bunch of hours into this game years ago. No matter how many times I saw that number scrolling through my library, I could not recall a single thing about this game. I should've taken that as an indicator of what I was in for: a game that leaves no lasting impression. With any luck, I'll forget about it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019327608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1706983221}
review:
Minimalist take on Zelda which turns out quite well. In essence, you explore the world as a character known as Young. You will collect cards and meet characters along the way. The game is divided in two sections, the first part which is more exploration, and then the second part which you can access once you have enough cards which adds a platforrming dimension to the exploration. As a gamer with the reflexes of fossilised arthropod when it comes to platforming, I did struggles in some of these sections. However, I think most players would actually enjoy these parts.

Despite its minimalism, the game has a lot of character, with different worlds offering novel environment challenges.

I would recommend this game without hesitation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130438044', 'num_games_owned': 1217, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1706825247}
review:
This is such a weird and interesting game.

Graphically, the game looks very nice and wears its inspirations on its sleeves. The game shares two very similar tilesets to ALTTP and one very reminiscent of yume nikki's buildings. The pixel art is nice and neither too simplistic or overly complex.

Gameplay wise this is essentially a Zelda game with an exploration-centric postgame. You will like the game if you liked Zelda games, though maybe the postgame isn't as appealing to you fi you're not big into exploration.

As for the sound design, I'd say this is where the game is lacking the most. The music is... Just okay, for the most part. Some of it is bad. Some of it is great, but it's a mixed bag.

Overall? I recommend :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198005262183', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1706056018}
review:
I wouldn't normally compare this to any of the 2D Zelda games, but I think the design choices (musical elements, art direction, enemy/boss design) force the comparison. It really, really wants to be a Zelda clone, but it's too minimalist for its own good. 

Most of the time, I was searching the dungeons and thinking, "Why am I here again?" "Why do I care about the plot?" "Wait, what was the plot again?" "What even is this?"
Those probably aren't questions you want to ask when you're playing a Zelda clone, but they come up pretty often. 

Enemy design was...quirky. Things would jump into my sprite/hitbox, lock me in place and just kill me out of nowhere. i-frames are non-existent. Luckily, there is no real drawback from dying, so it becomes a massive inconvenience and not a rage-inducing design flaw.

Some of the interstices before the second round of dungeons seemed 100% pointless. Why am I running around slaughtering kids? Why am I running from giant zombies? Why do I care? All good questions without a good answer. 
If there is a deeper meaning to the game, it was never clearly defined. As it stands, it feels more like a joke on the player: we've been tricked into playing a lackluster Zelda clone. A better shaped narrative/story really could have made up for the flaws and lack of depth in the game. 
D+

author: {'steamid': '76561198048789701', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1989, 'last_played': 1705728979}
review: I bounced off of this game the first time I played it but after giving it another chance when the remastered version released this has become one of my favorite games. It's hard to explain why but there's something I really enjoy about the zelda style combat/exploration/puzzle-solving combined with how this game uses its environments to tell you about its protagonist and suggest his backstory through them. It's a game that gives you a lot to think about but also leaves a lot of itself up to interpretation in a way I like a lot. Highly recommend using a gamepad to play as some of the late game stuff is a lot harder when playing on keyboard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136438582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1704954948}
review:
So, the studio behind this does storytelling in a way that speaks to me in particular in a very specific manner, but I'll try to break down why someone else would enjoy this game. 'Cause the game rules.

The game comes off as a solid top-down Zelda clone at first glance, and it kind of is, but what sets it apart is the atmosphere and the mood. The world your character explores is weird and has no desire to explain itself, the game can flip between unsettling, whimsical and peaceful with the greatest of ease using a combination of visual storytelling, great music, and distinct environments.

The game isn't for everyone, so maybe you'll bounce off, but that's kind of why I like indie games to begin with. They don't have to be for everyone. But I'd say give at least one of Analgesic Studio's games a try, maybe this, maybe Anodyne 2, (this game is not required to play the sequel, but I'd still recommend both), maybe Sephonie. Because there's a chance their games will hit you the same way they hit me, and if they do, they are SUPER worth playing.

review: Anodyne is a psychological action-adventure game that draws inspiration from classic Zelda titles, but with a darker and more surreal tone. The game takes place in the subconscious of the protagonist, Young, who explores various themes and landscapes with his broom as a weapon and tool. The game features a retro-style pixel art and a catchy chiptune soundtrack that create a unique and immersive atmosphere. I enjoyed playing Anodyne on mobile, but I have not yet tried the Steam version or the sequel, Anodyne 2: Return to Dust. I would recommend Anodyne to anyone who likes challenging and unconventional games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060373295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1701654853}
review:
I have no idea how this got in my Steam Library. I don't know how much I paid for it. And I had absolutely no idea what was going on almost the entire time. But the music, the sound design, the old school Legend of Zelda meets Ib gameplay absolutely hooked me the entire five hours. Beat it in one sitting. The mechanics were tight enough and the puzzles intuitive enough to not be frustrating. I don't expect to play an NG+, but this was a little gem that I enjoyed uncovering.
EDIT: fwiw, I did play the remastered version, so that's what this review pertains to!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043873302', 'num_games_owned': 8209, 'num_reviews': 190, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1701373593}
review:
Lo que parecía ser un simple tributo a los Zeldas de la Snes, resulta ser un paquete completo de exploración, puzzles y un poco de combate, todo con un encanto propio que logra destacarlo por si mismo.

Recomiendo muchísimo jugarlo sabiendo poco o nada, no porque tenga giros argumentales abismales o se trate de un juego totalmente diferente al de las capturas y trailers, sino porque es una experiencia corta, completa y hecha con cariño. Desde el estilo visual muy bien hecho, la música variada e increíble, y unos controles simples pero funcionales (aunque con algún que otro problema de colisión con los saltos).
Una muy linda experiencia.

review:
Weird one.

You can't know well if the game's taking you anywhere. When I finished it I still wasn't sure what the hell I just played or if it had any meaning, leaving me a bit empty. But it's the whole atmosphere which drew me in.

Pleasing sights and art style, beautiful color palette, atmospheric soundtrack, clever mechanics that do their job and weird dialogues.

Worth a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984445840', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1700449989}
review:
Bought this game hoping for a old school Zelda experience and after multiple attempts at getting into this game I give up.  It's Zelda with bad controls, bad map design, and none of that Zelda charm whatsoever.

Piss easy dungeons which aren't fun to navigate and have nothing exciting waiting for you just dumb cards so no real motivation to progress.

Would not buy again 3/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095479631', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1700436910}
review: I really enjoyed my time with this game. I'm not sure it's the kind of game I can recommend to absolutely everybody, but I think it's worth checking out. Gameplay wise, it is an old top-down zelda like, but with a bunch of quality of life features. But it's also one of those games that clearly has an underlying story that is very much up to interpretation, and is hard to decipher. Later portions of the game get kinda disturbing. If you like those kinds of things, do consider giving this game a try--it's a real hidden gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000620753', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1697827319}
review:
If you liked the old school top-down Zelda's along the lines of Link's Awakening, then this is a treat. I love the music and the story, and the game play is just challenging enough to be satisfying. I wanted to cry at the end, in a good way. Then I wanted to cry again finding the last of the cards, but more out of frustration (some of those challenges are brutal).

On thing I would say is that I don't have a great sense of direction so had to use guides just to help me navigate some of the levels (even with the benefit of the in-game map). Some parts a deliberately maze-like and I would just never have got through them without help. Still, well worth playing.

review: I bought and finished this a long time ago. Now that it's remastered, I would be remiss to not leave a recommendation. Analgesic's output is always stellar, and this is still one of my favorite retro Zelda-likes. The atmosphere is impeccable, and the playful outlook on design eventually leads to a special reward for anyone who is curious enough to push the boundaries of the game. If you enjoy the structure of Zeldas, and can enjoy surreal or horror-leaning aesthetics, you will be swept away.

review:
Legitimately incredible game. It's very interesting because it scratches that undertale itch despite having been made two years before. 

What makes this game so great is that a lot is left unexplained. A lot of atmospheric elements will strike you as very out of place, and even the story is very vague and doesn't explain this much of the world.

It's definetely worth your time, tough you should know that this studio's other games are all very different from this one and you may not like them as much at first,

author: {'steamid': '76561198075868257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1440171365}
review:
Frankly it's a mess. It's a game that [i]really[/i] doesn't know what it wants to be.

The graphics and sound and a few small bits of dialogue are trying to be dark and artsy and mysterious, but then there's a ton of lame jokes (or attempts at jokes, e.g. 'I bet you're reading a rock because you have no friends') strewn throughout the dialogue, and the plot (if you can call it that) is minimalist to the point of being ridiculous.

The player character is supposed to save 'The Land' (Yes, that's the name of the game world) from 'The Darkness' (What is 'The Darkness'? No clue!), and must protect something called 'The Briar' (No, I have no clue what it's supposed to be either). Later on the player encounters more genius placenames like 'Beach', 'Forest', 'Chasm', and 'Rainy Area'.

It's like the developers took a bunch of stuff from multiple different games and other media and mashed them together in the hopes that it would produce a good game. Specifically: 2D Zeldas like Link's Awakening, the Mother/Earthbound series, Yume Nikki, a little bit of Chrono Trigger (in the form of the hub world, which resembles The End of Time), and what I presume is supposed to be a nod to Ramona Flowers from Scott Pilgrim in the form of a girl randomly showing up on a Bicycle from time to time. Some of you are probably thinking those sound like good things, and they may well be in their original context, but when mixed together without logic or cohesion they're just messy - like putting salt on your cereal.

On the surface it's mechanically similar to a 2D Zelda game - it's tile-based; it has monsters, NPCs, and bosses; it has a sword in the form of a broom - but it completely lacks the charm and structure of a Zelda game. For most of the game the player only has one or two tools, as opposed to usual half-a-dozen different dungeon items one would expect from a Zelda game, which drastically affects how the game plays. (Basically, imagine a 2D Zelda where you spend half the game with only a sword. It isn't very fun.)

Then there's the bigger issue of the player being given just the [i]bare minimum[/i] of direction.

After the first NPC gives the barest of outlines of a plot 'The Darkness is threatening The Briar, go and stop it', the player just wanders out into the world, eventually picks up their weapon (a broom of all things), and goes through the motions of some very basic 2D Zelda obstacles (killing slime monsters to get a key from a chest and opening a road block). After the player eventually stumbles their way to the first temple with only one NPC interraction inbetween (the random girl on a bicycle), they are told to enter the temple but not [i]why[/i] they need to enter the temple, let alone what they're supposed to be looking for.

Along the way the player will pick up some cards, but they won't be told what the cards are for until [i]after[/i] completing the temple, and even then it's just "the cards are vital to your quest" without any kind of explanation as to why. (Eventually the player will (the developers hope) figure out of their own accord that the cards can be used to open numbered gates.)

The boss of the temple makes some remark about having been watching the player and telling the player to be careful who they trust, which I presume is supposed to be deep or mysterious, or an attempt at trying to recreate the atmosphere of Link's Awakening (which the game seems to take as its main inspiration - even using one of its lame jokes to paraphrase the "Windfish in name only, for it is neither" with "Village Elder in name only, for he is neither"), but if that's the goal it fails miserably. Sure, it seems mysterious, but at this point the player has little reason to care, let alone worry about who they should be trusting.

The game continues with its lack of direction and increasingly weird and eerie places, but after a while I just couldn't take it anymore and threw in the towel. Without any kind of direction or reason to explore and with so few NPCs to talk to along the way, the world just felt empty and boring, and I couldn't find the will to continue.

author: {'steamid': '76561199260478196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1706, 'last_played': 1694431946}
review: 9.75 out of 10! First of all, they absolutely nailed it with the Link's Awakening style, which is clearly what they were going for here. Exceeded my expectations for a top down Zelda-like. The dungeons were awesome. The story was bizarre but charming, and pretty dark at times. I liked it. Non-generic, and it had those strong indie vibes. And btw, just 2 devs made this, in about a year, and I must say, they did one hell of a job. The pixel art is lovely, and the dialog was done so well that I ended up talking to every NPC multiple times, just to see what all they had to say lol. Of course, that's totally optional, it's not text-heavy by any means, as far as gameplay and progression goes. This is one Zelda-like game that truly stuck to that formula, unlike so many others I've played. There's no life-sim elements, or procedurally-generated dungeons, or any other BS I often see in games that look very Zelda-like, but that's about it. This game looks AND feels extremely Zelda-like, through-and-through, but without being a shameless clone of it. The only reason I didn't rate it 10/10 is bc controller compatibility ain't exactly seamless. It's a bit of a process. Just make sure you enable Steam input before playing, then you have to remap the inputs in options, which will all be assigned to keyboard by default. But there's very few inputs, so it's not a big deal. My Xbox controller felt like overkill tbh. In fact, you could play this game with a basic NES-style controller if you have one. I wish I could play it on an actual GB Color. And I'm definitely gonna buy Anodyne 2 right now. GG

author: {'steamid': '76561198090891781', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1691042297}
review:
you need to let go. it's alright. you don't need to force interactive elements to be compelling. you don't need piss easy dungeons or cheesey, tone breaching dialogue. you don't need to be like daddy zelda and mommy chrono trigger. they love you even though you spend all your time at yume nikki's house. 

you shine whenever you aren't a game. you give me an experience i normally only look for in music. that's special. no, really. life is a continuous series of events what we assign meaning to only when we look at it. you express the human. you express motifs, moments, and emotions that spring gently forth from our collective struggles. you do so without recourse and demand nothing, you demand no narrative, no through line. you are raw expression. you aren't disconnected from reality, but you don't excuse it. we can talk about how we compartmentalize later, today we feel.

you are one of the few games that i wish was less of a game. unfortunately that means i can't recommend you to anyone looking to...play a game. you are boring, monotonous. you ape the structure of other games and don't understand why, you reference the things you love and it bogs you down from being the thing you desperately want to be. i care about you, really i do. that's why i stuck around, but it's time to move on, and i can't expect anyone else to think like me.

review:
If you enjoy lovely soundtracks and a fascinating world to explore, then I think Anodyne is a game you'll enjoy. There was so much in this game to seek out and find, and I had a good time just wandering while solving puzzles and collecting cards. There are pieces of a story to be had, but you'll be piecing the story together yourself, so keep that in mind if you prefer games with more clear-cut stories.

I had a very nice time exploring The Land, and I hope that you do too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015351058', 'num_games_owned': 915, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1460765811}
review:
Anodyne is a game that definitely stuck with me.

From the strange and interesting visuals to how it drew me in with the Zelda-style presentation and combat. There is a lot that can be said about Anodyne, but most importantly is not to miss out on this game. There is a lot to unravel in the world of Anodyne. Some of this will tell you more about the world, while some of this will tell you more about yourself.

There are collectibles to gather, monsters to fight, and a weird and wild story to unravel.

Coming back to write this review has left me feeling like I'm long overdue for a replay of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072134835', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1565893869}
review:
This game really surprised me. I really expected to give a negative review, with how initially underwhelmed I was with the game... but after everything, I came out with this game giving a really unique experience. I'd really recommend it to anyone who likes strange games.

This is a pretty major spoiler, so don't read this next part if you don't want to be spoiled on why this game has stuck with me so much.

[spoiler] I had a pretty bland experience through the game. At the end, however, you gain an ability to completely deconstruct the game and everything it stands for. In the post-game, you enter test maps, break out of bounds, and some of the content is only accessible with glitches. I always liked playing with glitches, and breaking out of bounds in games, so having a game that allows you to go even further with that felt surreal. I'm confident it's an intentional effect, and I'm sure the developers had the same fun breaking games that I did, and wanted to encourage that here. It's a very bold and reckless thing to encourage in a game, and I think that bizarre embrace of the fun of deconstructing games like this turns this from an unassuming game into one that captivates me. [/spoiler]

Putting it harshly, I think... a lot of this game I found very bland, sometimes annoying, and even unenjoyable... but I'd still recommend it if you're willing to play through some rough bits for something unique and bold. It's what I like to see in games and I really feel good looking back at this game, I'm really glad I finished it. One of the rare games I've played that made me want to play the rest of the company's games just to see what else they have... looking forward to experiencing the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561199026122846', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1687144277}
review:
仿塞尔达的一款俯视角冒险游戏。
游戏内容比较奇怪，场景较为多变，对话内容让人摸不着头脑，我认为这一定程度上是对主角生活的一种隐喻，但随着我玩完游戏通关后的额外部分，我发现其实有大部分内容属于作者的杂谈，与游戏剧情关联不大。
游戏的关卡设计和难度设计其实比较差劲，大地图和迷宫中有太多的死路或是回头路又或是大量的无用地图；小怪重复度高且攻击不易躲避；游戏指引性较差，很容易迷路；boss设计算是有趣，可因主角血量太厚导致毫无难度可言。
游戏后面的meta部分也有点生硬了，甚至我都有点不确定它算是meta要素。
游戏的亮点还是在文本上，不过肯定只有少部分人去挖掘，倒是与大众无关。
游戏不够成熟，但值得体验。
7/10

review: It's best to go in knowing relatively little about Anodyne, so I'll keep it short. It's sort of like The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening, but I feel like that sells the game a bit short and simultaneously sets expectations too high. It's far more surreal and strange, taking Link's Awakening already dream-like nature and magnifying it. Some areas can get very abstract and dark thematically, with glitches being incorporated into the narrative and gameplay. It's good and doesn't overstay its welcome unless you're going for completion.

author: {'steamid': '76561199048793608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 590, 'last_played': 1681002223}
review:
Good game, enjoyable. A little lost at times, with some clever puzzles. Some big dungeons are cool and really play near like a Link’s awakening. In general it’s more based on the atmosphere than on lots of bonuses/objects, and the pace is somewhat contemplative which is exactly what I was looking for.
That said, the game has a few aspects that might or might not feel like shortcomings to you. It is a bit short (no surprise here), The complexity is of course a lot below Zelda: there are only 2 or 3 objects, and the boss fights are easy. The story is a bit sad but more unsettling, even horror-like at times; it might be a bit triggering for some. I liked the spooky atmosphere, but it is not really justified by any context, which make the intent of the authors pretty unclear. For example you can have a boat ride in a merry swamp where you have to hit grumpy frogs, exactly like you could have in any Zelda, and then spooky-horror settings with close to none explanation for why they are here. I preferred the general engagement in Wait - extended, although they are quite different game the kind of atmosphere is comparable, with a lot more content in Wait. Wait felt a LOOOT longer and dense, even though it is probably a bit shorter (well cheking now, I played 5 hr Anodyne and 8 hr Wait, but several of the hours on Wait were probably on pause). Wait is actual horror though, so beware. Wait made me felt uneasy because it’s so engaging, story-rich and you have nothing else to do but think and be scared; and if you play at night your mind starts questioning what reality is. Anodyne is more confusing because the world seems very empty, unfinished and kind of abandoned by its creators. It’s also why it reminds me of Link’s awakening: it can only be a dream in my opinion, though it could be something more sinister.
For me, the story though refreshing compared to most games felt a bit just sketched, unfinished. There are lots of open questions, but I wouldn’t even call them "mysteries" since we know so little of anything that nothing really has enough flesh to captivate and ask real questions.
Anyways. Special thumbs up for the ending, which has some impressive moments I wasn’t expecting.
However, I was annoyed with the post-ending. The exploration of the world with the new power doesn’t keep its promises. There is close to nothing to find. I would close the game right after the ending and not try to explore more, you most of the time only end up in emply and buggy screens of developing zones, it’s not worth it. I feel that this feature is superfluous and they yould have removed it.

review: If Yume Nikki and The Legend of Zelda (the original 2D version) ever had a baby, I think it's fair to say that it might be something like this. There's combat but the primary focus of the game seems to be on exploration and solving puzzles. It doesn't have all the neat power ups that Zelda has but it doesn't really need them. In spite of the fact that there are only a few abilities available for you to use, Anodyne creatively gives you many ways to make use of them. There are many areas to explore, each with their own unique characteristics and there's a diverse array of odd creatures to boot. I'm impressed with the level design in this game and I like the boss fights. The music is good, too. It's nice that there are no tutorials, there's no need for them because the developers made it so people are able to easily learn how to play the game without them even as new things are introduced. I really like this game. I look forward to playing the sequel, Anodyne 2: Return to Dust.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032589399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 269, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1451699807}
review:
Anodyne - це захоплююча пригода зі забарвленнями платформера і RPG елементами. Гра була випущена 22 березня 2013 року і була розроблена Sean Han Tani та Joni Kittaka. У Anodyne гравець приймає на себе роль молодого хлопця, що називається Young, який прокидається в чудовому світі, що нагадує літературу фентезі і має надзвичайні розміри.

У грі головним завданням гравця є дослідження цього світу, який наповнений різними перешкодами, загадками і монстрами. Гра має чудову графіку в стилі піксельного мистецтва, яка створює особливу атмосферу. Головний герой має набір зброї, що дозволяє йому вбивати монстрів і розгадувати загадки.

Одним з головних плюсів гри є її унікальна атмосфера, яку створює музика та графіка. Також, Anodyne має цікаві локації, загадки і багато діалогів, що додають грі глибину і цікавість. Однак, деякі гравці можуть знайти гру трохи надто легкою та короткою.

У загальному, Anodyne - це чудова гра, яка підходить для тих, хто любить фентезі і пригоди з невеликими елементами головоломок. Гра має чудову графіку і звукову супровід, а також незвичну атмосферу, яку можна відчути протягом всієї гри.

review:
ゼルダの伝説風、ゲームボーイ風というレビューとレトロなスクリーンショットに惹かれて購入しました。

しかし、ゲームボーイ風とはよく言ったもので「チープ」な内容もゲームボーイ風と言っておけば良い印象を与えるということかと思います。

基本的に画面切り替わり型の古いゲームです。全体像がわかりづらく、大して面白みの無いマップを、繋がりがわかりづらいという理由で無駄に散策させられることになります。この退屈な散策をゲームボーイ風と感じて楽しめる人なら面白いかも知れません。私は無理でした。

その退屈なマップをひたすら歩いて様々なキャラクター等に出会いますが、哲学的などうでも良い自分語りをするだけで、ストーリーらしいものはありません。不思議な世界観をプレイヤーの想像力で楽しんでくださいというスタイルです。全然面白くも何ともありませんでした。

そして、こういう退屈な散策も至る所に出て来る宝箱から胸が躍るアイテムでも出れば多少は楽しめたかもしれませんが、基本的に出てくるのは鍵かキャラクターの絵が描いたカードです。武器はホウキのみです。

何の魅力もないカードをひたすら退屈なマップを収集するだけのゲームです。

セールで百円で買いましたが、それでも時間の無駄と感じるゲームでした。オススメしません。

author: {'steamid': '76561199384867213', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 902, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 902, 'last_played': 1670649371}
review:
Anodyne is a game I selected for my first full play-through and review almost entirely on a whim, ensnared by its appealing trailer shortly after downloading Steam for the first time. The first thing that immediately grabs you about this game is its pixel art style, which is by turns beautiful, surreal, and unnerving. There are multiple levels in this game where it's a joy just to take in all the imagery, the cute and cuddly sprites, and of course, the soundtrack (which matches the art style perfectly). 

The gameplay here is probably the biggest weak point, and ranges from mindless fun to genuinely tedium. I may just be a whiny bitch who doesn't know how to play video games, but passing multiple levels hinges on guessing how to use a new mechanic you've never encountered before (without any hints or instructions). The payoff is huge when you actually get it without any help, but it also yields a [b]lot [/b] of frustration. That being said, I think there's actually intent behind the game's repetitive tendencies, and it revolves around the narrative themes of depression, purposelessness, and self-doubt. 

The writing in this game is interesting, and likely plays off the gameplay's tendency to bore. It's definitely surrealist, which occasionally seems like an excuse for vague, noncommittal writing. More often than not, though, [i]Anodyne[/i] has an knack for disturbing or even existential atmospheres. These moments of dread, sadness, or reflection often come out of nowhere, but the game's slower or more repetitive levels are what makes this kind of reflection possible, making space in your mind for thoughts that would be blocked out by adrenaline in a faster-paced game. Much of the writing in [i]Anodyne[/i] is almost aphoristic, and some of the one-liners stick are genuinely provocative and now live rent-free in my subconscious. Examples include, "Peripheral vision is the hive of demons" and "We are born into the decay of our mothers body." 

Ultimately, I think [i]Anodyne[/i]'s storytelling succeeds because it allows you to impose your own life experiences onto the symbolism of Young's subconscious. Not every "scene" or level lands perfectly, but the beauty lies in little, unanticipated moments. The nightmarish nihilism of the Red Dungeon, or the themes of self-harm hidden in Youngtown. The self-aware loneliness of "Space," and the reflective despair of "BLUE." It's a strange and beautiful world, one that's simultaneously comforting an unsettling.

review:
我知道城市可以很脏乱差,但我喜欢看看外面的万家灯火.

它以自己独特的方式美丽着.虽然不像星星那样无穷无尽,但是却又在人情味上增添了一些美妙的复杂性.

每盏灯后,都有一个怀揣着希望,恐惧和秘密的人...往外看是一种充满恐惧和孤独的个人行为.

我觉得自己是爱着每一个窗户后面的人的.我爱你、爱着人们,你们都是我的星星.

不管你的人生轨迹是怎样,不管你认为自己有多么堕落,
我都爱着你.

今夜你最可爱…

抱歉，我又在胡说八道了.
不过谢谢你的聆听.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095082555', 'num_games_owned': 542, 'num_reviews': 359, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1659490599}
review:
This game has high highs and low lows. I love the world, the characters, and the unnerving atmosphere. I love the soundtrack too. As far as presentation, its fantastic, and it singehandedly saved the game for me. I played the entire 6 hour experience in a single day. It takes a lot for a game to hold my attention like this.

The game manages to do a TON with it's simple combat system, and implements a lot of cool puzzles that build upon themselves and get progressively more difficult without ever feeling too unfair. I enjoyed the boss fights as well.

This game was made in less than a year by a 2 person team, and the results are about as good as they possibly could be.

However, I definitely have some grievances. Combat is just sloppy and annoying in a lot of situations. There were a lot of moments where the enemies and hazards are nearly impossible to avoid with any consistency leading to you getting knocked around all over the place.

The problem isn't that the game is difficult, in fact, your health bar is so huge that it takes effort or complete incompetency to die in most situations. Even the most annoying enemies in the game can just be brute forced because of how frequently enemies drop health refills.

The puzzles are fun, but often not thought out well enough. You can cheese your way past a lot of puzzles by abusing the jump button. I was never quite sure if you were SUPPOSED to be able to jump across 2 block gaps, but you can if you time it just right and in a few situations it led to me sequence-breaking and occasionally getting softlocked.

I'm glad I bought it, and enjoyed my time in the majority of situations. I'm excited to play the sequel! For only $10 I would recommend it to anyone. Especially if you like quirky games like Earthbound, Off, OneShot, etc.

review: In the year 2022, Anodyne might be, at first glance, kinda redundant. Since it's release in 2013, there have been swarms of indie pixel art games that have subversive elements to them. However, I found through further play that Anodyne brings some ideas to the table that still feel fresh. It's experimental and snappy. If it introduces a mechanic that you find grating, you can be sure that it'll move onto something new quickly. And, for those more dedicated to picking apart it's world, there are plenty of really interesting secrets to find (although some seem so obscure you might be referencing a guide here and there). Overall, for about 3-4 hours of play, Anodyne brings great atmosphere, wonderful music, and a mystery that respects your intelligence. Definitely give it a shot.

review:
Competent Zeldalite with some enjoyable dungeons, maps that are fun to explore, immersive atmosphere (I recommend playing at night), and a good soundtrack.

It's slow paced, the story is intentionally reserved and didn't really interest me, and some late game collectables become tedious to find due to the nature of how you travel from area to area.

Towards the end, the game gets creative and does some things that are unique and unexpected. It gives it a stronger identity and makes it stand out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031106404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1655412113}
review:
Not a huge fan. Didn't finish it. 
(this is more a "I didn't like it" than "don't play it" kind of review)

I love the narrative design, lots of genuinely novel ideas and surprising moments. Love the music. Art's serviceable if not charming at best.

But I really don't like the core loop very much. You pulled me in when you had bosses gaslighting me, a charming bike rider baiting me with jokes about her bike being her "wares" when she turns out not to be a shopkeeper, forcing me to [spoiler]accidentally kill a fisherman and entering the organ flesh dimension his dead body creates a portal to[/spoiler], but as the game went on the surreal quirk didn't carry it for me.

Dungeon hazards are super annoying and the jump doesn't make it much easier to deal with them. Enemies are no reward and hence never worth dealing with. Broom mechanics fun-ish but never developed very far. There's tons of tedious movement on the overworld that even slightly more thought to shortcut building (you gave me a jump ffs, use it) would've greatly reduced. I like the cards but not enough of an overall reward to carry me either. The map is often downright unhelpful.
Maybe I've become too zoomer brained, but more player guidance and a tiny bit more depth to core gameplay would've done wonders here. Little too Zelda-lite for me.

Tho this kind of writing does make the ending pretty underwhelming since there's not many connections you have with any of it's characters cus the game is more focused on making abstract places that feel detached from the rest of the game. 
Anyway it's a linear zelda-like that's fun for a casual playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166266593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1651393400}
review:
《镇痛》使我想起推完《Cross†Channel》那个炎热而遥远的午后。黑须太一想象着一个全员到齐的天台。

「还有人活着吗？」
     没有回答。
「请活下去。」
     没有回答。
「生存便是寂寞。」
...

「那么，下周再见。」

关掉游戏，慵懒的哈欠开始跟回忆对冲，我的脑内回响电波和蝉鸣。黑须太一近在眼前。

有些游戏企图给予我们精神上的自由。制作人们树立规则和边界，把生活的严肃性消解，于是“万物皆允”；却谨慎地盖上薄纱，防止玩家们掀起图像和文本叩问界限。玩家与制作者的双向奔赴是迷人的诅咒，如果制作者最终选择了保留，我们就会得到《梦日记》；如果制作者展现过多，我们会得到《新手指南》，又或者三岛由纪夫的《假面告白》，玩家变成急躁的解读者，把主人公和作者视作同一人。
所以《镇痛》使我想到《C†C》，世界与主人公无限遥远却无比亲切。无比宁静、孤独。

我也许能告诉你，主人公叫杨（Young），名字谐音荣格（Jung）。杨不是一个精神病患者。
我也许能告诉你，《镇痛》的世界就是杨的世界。那是来之不易的东西：游戏里一切从最自然简约的方式出发，包括那套“塞尔达”的玩法。你是富有意识的玩家。
也许孤独不是阶梯，而是延绵不断的平行路，你在《镇痛》的世界里茫无头绪地一直走，直到杨的道路变成你的道路，杨的思考变成你的思考。陌生的事物会近在咫尺，你把它们做成卡片，插入回忆的卡槽；你与它们有一搭没一搭地聊天，因为最深刻的对话是与自己的对话。语言是最好的镇痛剂。

除此之外，我就没有什么可说的了。《镇痛》是薄薄的一层，只剩下轻轻响起的OST，比如Anodyne、Fields、Cliffs、Understanding（BV1jg41137SD），就像《C†C》的结尾只有久久的蝉鸣。这里没有某种“意义”，因为意义必然在世界之外。这里只有音无彩名了。

[h2]房思琪的初恋乐园[/h2]

英文评测区有点把我惹急了。他们宣称是进来找“游戏”的。我越往下翻看越感到奇怪，他们除了“塞尔达”以外还找到了更多“塞尔达”，就像鲁迅家门前除了枣树还有一颗枣树。现在我们把《镇痛》开除游戏籍吧。
林奕含走了5年了，她的话仍然响亮。我有时就会突然想起。

[b]“这只是本书，你们都不敢看，而它却是我的人生，你们却劝我活下去。”[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198132276974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1651163589}
review:
Anodyne is the first game by Analgesic and it shows. This game is 10 years old now from the beginning of its development, and will officially be 10 years old from release next year, and it was one of the first major wave of indies, alongside Shovel Knight and Super Meatboy, from back when Steam did its own curation. By tje standards of today's indies, it comes of as rather quaint when we have games like Hyper Light Drifter, Unsighted, and Blossom Tales just to name a few, however it is still worth playing , especially if you're interested in the library of these particular developers.

Anodyne is a top down action adventure game much like one of the 2D Zelda games, however this game is significantly simpler in terms of mechanics. Your only weapon and tool for the entire game is a broom with which you can use to attack enemies and relocate piles of dust to solve environmental puzzles and use as makeshift rafts to traverse bodies of water. Apart from that the only other upgrade you get are jumping shoes that allow you to platform, which is pretty wonky given the perspective and the obstacles thrown at you at times. The only way in which you are gated is by collecting trading cards of the sprites in the game, each of which contains a small blurb about... something. Collecting enough of these will allow you to pass through gates requiring certain numbers of them and access deeper parts of the world, and collecting all of them will allow you to see the game's true ending.

It doesn't sound like much, but because this game has so few mechanics, the pacing is really quick and the runtime of the game is really brief being 5-10 hours depending on if you're going for 100% or not. Plus, the lack of complex mechanics allowed for more focus on environments and mining the simple mechanics for what they're worth. Not all of it works, and there are definitely areas which feel awkward and antiquated. Most of the game however is perfectly playable and still engaging even after all this time.

The story is nothing much to speak of. Instead of going for a straightforward storyline, like all of Analgesic's future titles, this game goes for abstraction and meta allusions and humor. It's probably for the best with one's first game as it fuels further thought and analysis, keeping people thinking about it, however it doesn't give the most satisfying conclusion. It feels more like a cloudy look into the thoughts of the developer rather than a legit game world with a story to it, which I'm just not a fan of. Having a solid throughline to carry the spacy ideas and tie everything together with central themes is something I much prefer and something the sequel, Anodyne 2 excels at in addition to various gameplay improvements.

As I said in the beginning, Anodyne is the first game of the developers, and that's something I don't necessarily hold against it, but it's hard not to be biased when each game they've made has been an improvement over the last one. I appreciate this game as an early venture from them and I appreciate that they used it as a jumping off and a learning experience from which to make even better games. It is still perfectly fine in its own right and for those that enjoy this particular genre of game, it's an interesting and simplified diversion from other games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121112670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 277, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1646110420}
review:
Anodyne is a top-down arpg.  Beat it and got 4/6 achievements (100%'d outside of getting all the cards and speedrunning) in 5 hours and 45 minutes using a keyboard.  Difficulty is Medium.  

Controls - It tells me in the beginning that I can use my controller, but fooling around with getting the controller set up didn't seem to work for me.  I decided hitting space and using the keyboard was the easiest route with controls.  The buttons are easy enough to figure out.  There's additionally a window pre-game saying 'click arrows to resize screen', but I skipped that with space and it auto-resized to fill the screen anyway. 

Movement - Had no problem getting around the map, attacking baddies, dodging things, and talking to people.  

Story - Buhhh.............  I guess?  What happened?  

Music - retro rpg. I really liked most of the ost.  Some was creepy.  Some was earwormy.  Some made it surreal.

Gameplay - You'll spend most of the game wandering around exploring in an acid-tripping retro world that reminded me of one part original Zelda and one part Earthbound.  Between the map and portals, it's easy to stay on track with where you have and haven't been with a few exceptions (a certain circus maze comes to mind).  

Variety - Tons of different enemies and bosses, though many of the bosses were too easy to beat. 

Achievements - There are 6 achievements total.  Two are harder to get. 



I played Anodyne in three 2Hr sessions.  The first time I couldn't get into it and didn't know wtf was going on or why I should keep playing.  The second time I got a general sense of the map and played for the sake of exploring, finding bosses, and seeing where the game was going to take me.  The third time I gave up trying to understand things and played for the fun of the dungeons, 100%ing things, and finding at least 36 of the cards - and by then I was really enjoying myself.    This game isn't going to knock your socks off.  There's no great over-arching story with warring nations or any grand powerups that turn the game on its head (outside of maybe jumping).  There is a surreal experience to be had, amusing levels, and wayward blurbs of contemplative ideas smudged into a blob of what might be a story that I can't for the life of me sort out.  Is it a bad game?  I didn't like it in the beginning because I couldn't get immersed in what was going on or comprehend Young's motives, but it's not a bad game.  After chewing on it for an evening or two, I ended up growing to enjoy the experience.  So it's an OK game.  A game you'll put down going, "Okay, I played that."  and either forget it or be so weirdly intrigued that you'll find yourself picking up Anodyne 2 in the hopes it'll explain something a little more coherently or flesh out stuff a bit more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982455625', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1643435623}
review:
There's a couple things that make this experience more frustrating than rewarding.

The bad: The controls are counterintuitive but can be remapped, I recommend enter->attack shift->jump WASD move. Collision boxes are vague and not pixel-perfect, and this is the source of most of my damage. You're often backtracking without a clear goal, and the labyrinthine levels make this tedious. New mechanics just suddenly appear without introduction, and feel like dead ends to unlock later. Many obstacles require insanely fast reflexes, and unclear visual cues had me walking into many enemies thinking they were friendly. Several hits are not "fair," including a checkpoint in a room full of enemies and more than one cutscene moment.

The good: The boss fights are quite fun, and are very well done. Once you realize you're dealing with a puzzle and not a dead end, they're fun challenges. I really appreciated not being led by the hand, and treated like I have never used a computer before. NPCs have witty dialogue, and the world building was amazing. Nothing really felt 'forced,' and the area theming looked great. The nether gate area is laid out in the same orientation as the maps they represent, so finding those were easy.

What I would change: Enemies need more clear visual cues, and more crisp hitboxes and clearer dangerous/not states. Better use of coloration would make enemies more clear to make it more clear who's friendly. New game mechanics need more prominent introductions, and a more sequential or clearer set of directions to follow would make the mazes more entertaining.

author: {'steamid': '76561198857168495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1675770670}
review:
To be honest, the only reason I played this game was out of obligation: I have long been interested in playing the sequel, and this game was cheap. 

Let's face it, RPGs with Zelda-type gameplay are a dime a dozen;  however, as with any RPG, tedious gameplay can be forgiven if the story is worth the playthrough. Anodyne, despite not looking like much, is one of the better indie RPGs...ever.

In many ways, the game is similar in spirit to undertale, however where undertale is direct, Anodyne is subtle and understated. There are countless indie RPGs with nothing really to say, where a threadbare plot is often hidden behind cryptic delivery, but here there is actual meaning. Anodyne is in some ways a meta-game, but wheras Doki Doki Literature Club was just a gussied-up creepypasta, Anodyne is legitimately thoughtful, and in some ways, rather heartbreaking. Aside from one clumsy late-game puzzle and less than stellar platforming, I really can't recommend this game highly enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007540184', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 1821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 775, 'last_played': 1675571389}
review:
How ironic that a game calling back to Nintendo titles of the early 90s should now evoke a nostalgia of its own: this latter age not being the hallowed days of the SNES and Game Boy, but rather that period 8 to 12 years ago one might tentatively call the "First Indie Wave." Old-school graphics and chiptunes were as omnipresent as the mature themes and alienating experiences that accompanied them; a young Toby Fox taught us to love again; and Steam was, as ever, raking in the moolah. But while the likes of [i]Undertale[/i], [i]Hotline Miami[/i], and [i]Papers, Please[/i] went on to critical acclaim, [i]Anodyne[/i] did not. And perhaps that's what I found so nostalgic about this game, the sense that it remains a time capsule of a brief era, stubbornly perambulating in circles while its peers have long since moved on.

It's very clearly an early effort by a small development team, but that lends it a certain charm. The story and writing is strange and obtuse, but not really intriguing enough that I felt I had to learn more, and at worst coming off as pretentious. Theming dungeons around hotels, apartments and circuses is interesting, though possibly the constant change in scenery is too eclectic for the game's own good. Many of the jokes fell flat, though there were a couple that made me chuckle. The gameplay is simple but quite fun, though for many it might seem too repetitive. The post-game content is based around a very interesting concept, but comes with a frustrating flaw. It's a game of near misses, and there's something oddly compelling about that.

If I was to recommend this game, I'd say get it during a sale, and play at least until you reach the windmill. The music and visuals of that scene alone sold me on the experience and the time I invested in it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053481680', 'num_games_owned': 2918, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1635907962}
review:
アイテムが剣（このゲームだと箒なのだが）とジャンプだけになった2Dゼルダライクゲーム。
謎解きというほどでもない簡単なギミックを次から次に解いて探索を進めていくのが楽しいゲームだ。

日本語訳は完璧だが何の事を言っているのかよくわからないあいまいかつ脈絡のないテキストはプレイヤーに物語をあまり理解させる気がないと思わせる。

またクリア後のおまけが他に類を見ないくらい斬新で珍奇な代物だが頻繁にバグる上に探索のヒントが全然見あたらなかったためすぐに投げた。
具体的に言うと[spoiler] マップのタイルをある程度自由に入れ替える事ができるようになりマップが用意されていない場所にも侵入できるようになる。
ただし変な所に入り込むとはまって動けなくなったり画面表示がモザイク状に乱れたりする。
お年を召した方にしかわからないと思うがファミコンのカセットを半刺しにしたときに出てくるアレだ。
幸い標準機能の規定位置へのファストトラベルがバグっても使えるのでどうにもならなくなったらこれで戻れという事らしい。 
こんな自由度が高すぎるというかただ放りっぱなしにしただけの状態で隠しカードを探せという事らしいがどこをどう探索しろというのだ？[/spoiler]
これは一見の価値はあると思う。一見した後は途方に暮れる事うけあいだが。

結論としてはサクサク進むゼルダ的な短編ゲームがやりたい人やヘンテコなものがどうしても見てみたいという人にお勧め。
後者の人は上のネタバレは読まない方がいいぞ。予備知識なしに見た方が楽しめるだろうから。

author: {'steamid': '76561198065787551', 'num_games_owned': 63, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1577485568}
review:
Bought this game while on discount for 2 euro.  If you see this game on discount buy it! Especially if you like zelda like game especially the first ones.
The combat system is pretty easy. There are some collectibles (heart cointeiner and cards. Plus some secret ones that are a pain to find example: for you you have to afk something like 8 real hours in a spot).
The exploration is nice! there are a lot of daungeons and they are all themed in a very different way.
The story may be consufing but it's not super hard to understand (it's pretty much a trip inside the protagonist mind)
The cons is that it does not offer a lot of playtime. I finished it in around 5h and i collected everything i could before end game.
Endgame contect has an intresting idea but at the end it just collecting the last few cards remaining and some other little thing nothing to intresting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106571734', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1698082921}
review:
This game really surprised me by how much it respects player agency - letting them do whatever they want to do. There's a lot of moments where the game trusts the player to do what they seem fit and it's done in surprisingly cleaver ways with the simple mechanics that it has.

The music is super fitting as well. The soundtrack is so restrained. I really like that about it. It's tracks hit the right vibes at the right times. There's never a song played at a time that may clog the atmosphere with needless noise and thereby robbing it of its really good emotional moments. The music is super consistent if we're talking about playing it for a proper mood and proper timing of when the song actually plays - I understand that it's pretty subjective, but it at least succeeded for me in terms of timing and mood). 

I would highly recommend this if you're looking for a slightly odd and atmospheric adventure with a wonderful and fitting ost.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044362464', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1700194428}
review:
(I got the game in a bundle last year and completed it. I bought it again to leave a review.)

Have you ever lost a friendship? Worried about the distance between you and another person? Wondered what someone really meant to you, and what you were supposed to do about it? And along the way, started to wonder what your place was in the world, and how the things you see around you got that way? 

I do not relate to the reviews stating they felt there was no point to the game or that it was confusing. The game is about a 20something delving into his subconscious to process an event or relationship he has experienced. Along the way we are treated to snippets of his worldview, memories, neuroses and fixations. 

There is no overarching moral to the story (thank god) - there are speeches here and there, and some obvious metaphors, but at the end of the day it is about Young's long think. In Zelda fashion there is no postgame, but the significance of that is inverted: instead of our Link's existence starting and ending with his mission, it's more about the world of Anodyne itself, with Young's subconscious only relevant so far as he needs something from it.  Very meta, since Young is controlled by the player who spends 7 or 8 hours in the world of the game then emerges to the rest of their life. 

Indeed there is something fitting (and deeply sad) about the entire world being inside Young's head. Unlike Yume Nikki, which feels tinged by the alien and paranormal, it's pretty clear who is an introjection of what (e.g. a scolding boss who condescends to Young is probably a schoolteacher mixed with a parent, some adult authority figure) and that none of this is *supernatural* per se, it's just vividly psychological. The dungeons, mazes, puzzles, and enemies Young faces are all manifestations of his ruminations or anxieties, and likewise, Sage, the Briar, and Mitra, are manifestations of inner voices or people important to him. 

With this in mind, the tonal whiplashes reflect a stream of consciousness, flitting back and forth between memories, musings, and paranoias. The broad range of environments, topics covered, and moods, similarly reflects a person's full range of interiority - after all, our lives are everything we experience, plus how we think and feel about that. As someone who spends a lot of time inside their head, to the point of preferring imaginary conversations over real relating, Anodyne being one long game of "Young talks to himself" is resonantly and painfully lonely. 

The "fakeness" of Anodyne is what makes it feel refreshingly real. That everything is set in a layer of existence removed from the base layer of Young's waking life mirrors the way the player experiences the game as a step removed from the base layer of their own personal reality, allowing Young's worries to bleed past the scope of the game itself. Exposed to, say, characters jumping to their deaths, it feels less like "Well these people are dying in front of me to set the tone of this videogame", and more, "Wow, our world is a pretty messed up place where this kind of thing happens." 

Young's ruminations are our ruminations. In terms of graphics and gameplay, the refusal of immersion engages the strongest reality-maker: our metaphorical understanding. Young's world really exists - in the mind of some troubled zillenial out there.

The graphics are tight, the paletting carries the art direction and ensures that no level, prop, or character feels out of place. The music is extraordinarily effective. The writing, mostly in the form of flavor text on items, signposts, etc, is charming and wistful and sometimes so mundane and kitchen-sink that it smacked me in the face. Overall despite some wonkiness with controls, the game has the image of a polished, professional production, and it's really impressive to me that Anodyne's creators were still university students at the time. 

While lacking specified commentary or concrete suggestion for the real world, Anodyne offers companionship - "I worry about this stuff too." Something I've always struggled with when it comes to playing or making games is *escapism*. Every game, no matter how high-minded, practical, or moralizing, is ultimately a diversion from everyday life. Anodyne makes that its strength. Here is an escape from reality about escape from reality. The painful, melancholy world of the inner mind is made beautiful, nostalgic, somewhere you can even take refuge. It's okay to stay here, solving puzzles in your subconscious. You can stay until you're done figuring them out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074303150', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1627509573}
review:
Игра, в которую я собирался поиграть столь долго, что уже успело выйти продолжение... Два года назад. В общем, пора уже закрыть этот бэклог, пока плесень на нём не потребовала независимости!

Anodyne — очень странный предмет. Одной ногой игра плотно увязла в сюрреализме, построенном на чередовании никак не связанных между собой локаций и общей абсурдности творящегося действа, а другой — прочно держится за своё видеоигровое нутро и не превращается в очередной интерактивный перфоманс, вышедший из барбершопа. Но насколько этот геймплей стоит того, чтобы тратить на него время?

Сами разработчики идентифицируют свою игру как «The Legend of Zelda на минималках», это же им вторят и рецензенты, — однако, как мне кажется, такое описание ей не очень подходит. В целом, Anodyne создаёт впечатление эдакого сборника головоломок в открытом мире, где вы в первую очередь расколупываете логику построения местных комнат, а сражения с монстрами получаете как бы на сдачу.

У вас по сути кроме верной метёлки, выступающей в роли оружия, нет никаких дополнительных методов взаимодействия с миром; даже прыжки и те открываются где-то в середине пути, напоминая таким образом, что пора бы пройтись по старым локациям и поискать новые пути для продвижения. Ну, и куда без боссов, которые хоть и бывают довольно интересными, но всё же страдают от общей топорности здешней боёвки. Финальный злодей, впрочем, заставил меня откатиться к чекпоинту раз двадцать...

А вот смысловую подноготную творящегося сюра я не понял. Совсем. Не, вроде ясно, что в сюжете рассказывается история паренька Янга, который проходит через слои собственного подсознания, но чем именно мы занимаемся и чего добиваемся в итоге — я без понятия. В эту же степь идёт и странная последовательность локаций. Какой-то абсурд ради абсурда.

В любом случае, Anodyne — это интересный инди-проект, который несмотря на некоторую... непонятность творящихся на экране событий остаётся всё-таки полноценной игрой. По атмосфере напоминает старую игрушку Weird Dreams, но с той лишь разницей, что в неё можно играть и получать от этого удовольствие. Надо теперь глянуть, что разработчики намутили в продолжении...

author: {'steamid': '76561198977373363', 'num_games_owned': 90, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1640724929}
review:
One of a kind. This is the type of game that leaves a lasting impression onto you, and for me, it sure did, I still remember playing it on a cloudy day that was slowly turning into a rainy one.
The soundtrack makes the experience so much more unique as you visit the mysterious worlds you come across. It's a puzzle type of game, in which there are many roads, doors and ways that are blocked until you learn something new or get the right things to unlock them. It's a wonderful game that transports you into this weird dream like pixel land full of dangers and wonders, it has some scary parts that freaked me out and some puzzles that I really had to use my brain. It also has a card collecting mechanic!!! Highly recommend it to the adventurer/mystery enjoyers out there

author: {'steamid': '76561198399079728', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1629561555}
review:
5時間程度でクリア。見下ろし型ゼル伝的なアクション。
アクション部分には文句なし。

謎解き要素を控えめに、アクションの難易度をぐっと上げたゼルダの伝説。アクションゲームとしての完成度を見た場合、インディーゲームとしてはかなり出来が良い。出来ることは箒による攻撃動作と（少し進めてからできるようになる）ジャンプのみ、謎解き用のアイテムも金の概念さえもないシンプルな構成ではあるが、先に進むにつれて激しくなるボス戦はシンプル操作が故にプレイヤースキルを問う形になっており、確かな成長を実感できるものだ。ラスボスは他より難易度が高めで、多少の慣れが必要になるか。
物足りなく感じたのはストーリー部分。
無意識が生み出した夢を思わせる抽象的世界を冒険するゲームだと銘打たれている以上、曖昧で断片的な情報から詳細を想像するしかないことは最初から想像できていた。それは確かな事実であり、また作中を彩るBGMは安心と不安の狭間を行き来するような曲調で「そういう世界観作り」は非常に上手くできていたと思う。
ただし、台詞とカード、石から読み取れる情報ではあまりに不足が過ぎており、ストーリーの全容がまったく把握できなかった。結局主人公であるヤングとボスたちが敵対する理由はなんなのか、目的はなんなのか、無意識の世界で何をどうしているのかが理解できないまま、なんとなく良い終わりを迎えられたのだろうという予感だけでゲームが終わってしまった。

全体としては良いのだが、手放しで褒めるほど最高かというとそうではない感じ。
とはいえ2013年リリースの作品を2021年になってプレイしてこの感想が出てくるわけなので、以降の作品ではより良い体験が得られることは確信できる完成度でした。短くまとまっているところも個人的には良し。

author: {'steamid': '76561198076755073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1629229320}
review:
Great little game, I really enjoyed this one! The last dungeon could use some refinements imo. I haven't played the other game this one is heavily inspired by along with Zelda A Link to the Past and Link's Awakening, so my closest frame of reference (along with the Zeldas) was EarthBound, actually, because of some themes, the general creepiness and the gorgeous soundtrack. The soundtrack, btw, while awesome, could hook us a little bit more. It's not bad by any stretch, but it could be catchier - being catchy is not bad and I'm sure the composer would be able to deliver. As for what the soundtrack actually delivers, I can't truly complain. The whole mood of the game is very well accompanied by its music. The pixel art is also very beautiful. Great game overall.

On a separate note, I wish indie developers would hire professionals to translate their games. In games such as this one, it's either a perfect translation or none at all. The Brazilian Portuguese translation is far from the worst I've seen (for many games it would qualify as good enough), but there are many errors - some big, some small - that end up detracting the experience. I know it's not a cheap nor an easy job, but non-professional translations hurt these games more than they help them.

Score: 8.1/10

review:
This is an odd one. Top-down Zelda-like. You go around levels. Fight monsters. Bit of platforming. Collect plot coupons. Beat Bosses. But it's all weird. Traipsing through an ancient looking dungeon. Activating a wind turbine to progress. Navigating through a dilapidated hotel and fighting a giant eye and then a fire ghost. 

And it kinda feels like you're walking through someone's stream of consciousness? Maybe?

If that sounds intriguing, give it a play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972325018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1666662643}
review:
Anodyne is not simply a game, but an experience. Throughout the game, as your character progresses and you find more of what the land has to offer, one thing always persists. That one thing is the existential feeling that the land, along with everything is imperfect. Whether it be an NPC that suffered a horrible fate, or a puzzle which requires 2 hours only to yield a useless item. You come to question why the world is like this, why such odd inconveniences plague the world. However, when you look at these imperfections compared to other games and stories, those of which have been polished down to be only perfection, you can realize what Anodyne is, a diamond in the rough.

Good work and carry on

author: {'steamid': '76561199183716445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1625118649}
review:
[h2] Anodyne: Legend of Zelda surrealista com toques de humor [/h2]

Sabe aquela sensação de que parece que o jogo está escondendo algo de ti? Como se existisse uma barreira tênue entre a realidade do jogo em que o personagem vivencia, porém com uma cortina de fumaça que esconde uma verdade maior por trás?

Então, Anodyne é isso! Assim como outras análises apontaram, ele lembra muito aqueles games do Legend of Zelda antigos, principalmente Link's Awakening (tem até um personagem que usa roupas parecidas com o Link, e ele corta arbustos para ganhar dinheiro, o diferencial é que ele tem uma barba, provavelmente pra fugir de um possível c&d da grande Nintendo), mas misturado com alguns elementos de estranheza apresentado em JRPGs como Yume Nikki, OFF e afins.

O jogo conta a história de Young, um ser humaninho que tem que ir desvendando os mistérios por trás do mundo dos sonhos do seu próprio subconsciente, sendo guiado pelo Sábio da Vila (que curiosamente não é tão sábio e nem faz parte de nenhuma vila), e de Mitra, uma garota aventureira acompanhada de sua fiel bicicleta, Wares.

Como já comentei, é um jogo incomum que provoca estranheza, porém conta com alguns momentos bem legais de humor, como a da arma do protagonista ser apenas uma vassoura.

Outro ponto interessante é que o jogo apresenta cartas que você pode adquirir (36 são necessárias para chegar na área final do jogo), e cada uma consta uma mensagem que pode revelar um ponto da personalidade de Young (tal como uma que pergunta se ele gosta dos seus [b] nentendos[/b]) ou, em outros casos, tem uma mensagem críptica (tal como um chefão falando que [b] sempre que Young estiver sozinho, ele estará lá com ele[/b]. 

[i] Fazendo um breve side-track, eu curto muito esse estilo de narrativa, pois pense bem, se alguém te faz uma ameaça como "Toma cuidado, hein", "Olha por cima dos ombros" e afins, tudo bem, você pode ficar preocupado, talvez achar zoado e tudo mais... porém, se alguém chega para ti e fala [b]"Os mortos choram sobre o brilho da Lua pálida"[/b], você com certeza vai ficar MUITO mais tenso! Um belo exemplo disso se encontra [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=60YqA8LWBQs] neste vídeo[/url], onde o cara chama um número e começa falando de boa com uma garota até assustar ela com a palavra "REQUIEM" e desligando na cara! [/i]

O final do jogo não explica muito, porém dá a entender de que O Briar possui uma grande importância para Young, e o jogo conta nada de forma explícita. As vezes isso pode ser caracterizado como design preguiçoso porém, para este jogo, somado com a forma com que o todo é apresentado, deixa a experiencia muito melhor, aberta à interpretação. Em suma, é uma experiência única que deve ser aproveitada por pessoas que curtem aqueles belos joguinhos surrealistas de RPG Maker.

Aah, vale lembrar que a arte é MUITO bonitinha, e a OST é definitivamente MARAVILHOSA!!

review:
The game is a poorly designed Zelda clone: run around, fight clunky enemies with random hitboxes, endure horrible platforming, collect items to progress. 
The levels are pretty bland so is the music, save for a few compositions (like the cliffs one). 
The bosses are either too easy or tedious (the very first one and the very last one). 
The plot makes zero sense (all this meta-no-substance-mYsTeRiOus yoke) and the characters are not memorable. 
The framerate drops after around 25 minutes when playing on Mac. Additionally, the achievements are not recorded when playing the Mac version.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978225486', 'num_games_owned': 2308, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1658819670}
review: Anodyne is happy to leave you with the impression that it's a quirky little trip (and deserving of appreciation/analysis on that front) but also very willing to reward observation; its mechanics are simple for a top-down action game, and it tells its story in bits and pieces with wide gaps for the audience to fill in on their own. Combined, these aspects result in a campaign that's practically free of filler material, assuming you like what's on the surface to begin with and are willing to trust that the game knows what it's doing. I personally did on both fronts, and I now consider it one of my favorite games of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198303320692', 'num_games_owned': 994, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1653043468}
review:
Okay so here's my experience:
I start the game and am greeted with a message saying I need to resize the window using the arrow keys so that no excess black pixels were present. I thought this was a bit unusual to say the least.. alas, i had not yet realized that this would set the tone for every other aspect of the game.

After resizing, it told me it detected a controller and would I wish to use it, I would have to configure it first. So i try to configure but to no avail. It would detect none of my button presses (this is an official xbox one controller btw). Puzzled, i try a second controller, which also does not register anything whatsoever.

Getting frustrated, I decide to skip the configuration and just play on keyboard instead. There, we immediately discover the highly impractical layout of arrow keys for moving, c for attack, x for "?????" which is also used as a cancel button for the map/menu, and ENTER to access your menu which displays the map and some other info. Since the enter key is so far away from x & c, i decided to map it to a key that my left hand could comfortably use.

Going into the controls menu, I accidentally press the left arrow key, which is actually the button used to start remapping all of the keys. Unaware that i'm already mapping keys, i try to press the down and up arrow keys to try and highlight the correct key. Obviously this totally fucked up my controls and i decided to alt F4 before it could save my control scheme. Restarting the game and going back to the controls menu, I read "Press left to change controls. space to cancel" Both very odd keys to press for the actions they do, but fine, i remap them and am FINALLY ready to play this shitty game.

Getting to the creme de la creme, i quickly find out that the gameplay is boring, the graphics are ugly, the soundtrack is... well, it's a freaking joke. The dialogue tries to be funny but it really isn't. And truthfully, the dialogue is probably the best thing this game's got going for it. Which REALLY isn't a good thing.

I reached the first dungeon and decided to off myself. It gave me the choice of continuing or not. I promptly said no thanks and it booted me to.. not to the main menu, but to a room with some awkwardly placed furniture and a chest. Confused as to why i'm still controlling my character, I move to the next room. However my curiosity got the better of me and I wanted to know what was in that chest, so I go back to the previous room I was in. However upon going through the door. The game fades to black and NOW i'm in the main menu.

Seriously, wtf?? What did I just play?

TLDR:
- Gameplay is boring.
- Graphics are ugly.
- Sound design is a joke.
- Control scheme is confusing, impractical, and inconsistent.
- Controller support does not seem to work whatsoever.
- Dialogue scrolls very slow and very annoyingly.

And after all these cons, I dont have a single pro to list on here. I see all these positive reviews and am baffled at how people could possibly say anything positive about this, comparing it to zelda is an insult. Unfortunately, i cant refund it anymore as I bought this game a while ago and only now played it.

I wouldnt play this even if it was free, selling it for €8,99 should be a crime. STAY AWAY FROM THIS ONE.
