review:
This is one of those game where I  really struggle to recommend or not.

on one hand it's generally solid, despite some clunkiness, infuriating hitboxes and controller support dependent on luck. level design is good and it captures the athmsphere and mechanics of old zelda games. on the other hand, gameplay or design-wise it offers nothing really original, and it feels like the n-th indie pixel-art game and the barely hinted story isn't enought. I appreciate the love and care single devs put in these project and I think you should buy it if you feel the same way, but as far as recommending it I really can't do it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198887008717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 615, 'last_played': 1616549345}
review:
昔の「ゼルダ」や「ゆめにっき」を彷彿とさせる、可愛らしくも何処か不穏な雰囲気に彩られた世界を旅するゲーム。
この独特の雰囲気は恐らく意図したものであり、無二の魅力であるのだが、それにしても説明不足に過ぎる感は否めず、ラスボス含め、なぜ戦うのかも分からず唐突に始まるバトルにはやや興醒めな所もあった。
全体としての完成度は非常に高く、難易度も簡単すぎず難し過ぎず丁度よいと思えるものだった。

「雰囲気で語りたい」という意図は分からなくもないが、もう少し状況や目的に関する説明があれば、より深く感動し、のめり込めたであろう、というのがクリア直後の感想。

author: {'steamid': '76561198080098643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1308, 'last_played': 1549234357}
review:
Anodyne is a great game, and I'm still not entirely sure what the message was. I don't think I'm supposed to ever find out.

You play the role of Young, a Janitor who collects cards and tidies rooms. Kinda.
Gameplay is two-dimensional, with an oblique projection (cabinet?), and a multi-functional broom that serves as a weapon and a traversal tool (in more ways than one!).

It's a strange game, and words really fail to describe it.

[b]Linux Note:[/b]
This game has a native Linux build! Sorta...
To run it, you'll need Adobe AIR, a long-since discontinued Adobe application runtime. The Windows build is bundled with AIR, and honestly, it might be easier to run it in WINE/Proton these days.

But... the "native" AIR version worked flawlessly once AIR was installed.

review: Anodyne and Anodyne 2 are two of my all time favorite games. I recommend them to anyone who will listen. Melos Han-Tani and Marina Kittaka have established such a strong, unique voice for their games. These games are beautiful, melancholy, lonely, funny, and warm all at once. I love exploring the world of anodyne. It is alien, it is heavy with atmosphere, it is full of strange wonderful inhabitants. At the end of the journey you feel satisfied by what you've seen, but you also feel that there is so much more to this world and to the lives of the people you met. The soundtrack is perfect and adds to the beauty and mystique of the world. The humor and writing is so much better than 90% of games. Play it!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198040997121', 'num_games_owned': 730, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1614301926}
review:
The combat is trivial and unsatisfying, you go through many rooms and areas very quickly which look quite similar, yet the map gives you very little information to go on making it quite easy to get lost.

My time with this game mostly consisted of navigating labyrinths with very little to drive me forward, I received two upgrades to my main weapon, a jump ability, and something like six health expansions. The obstacles I was faced with did not seem to grow particularly more interesting, neither did the kit I was tasked with conquering these obstacles using.
In a Zelda-styled game you would generally receive items that would allow you to interact with the world in a new way so that a commonly retreaded overworld can be slowly opened up to the player. Even in the first Zelda game the main objective was fairly clear, and the entire game world outside of dungeons was actually a manageable size so you could learn it after a few hours. This game instead features a ton of areas where each room is mostly without any features of interest, instead of upgrading the player's abilities the game locks areas behind gates that either require specific keys or for the player to have gathered a set number of collectibles. Beating a boss and receiving a card with a picture of the boss on it is not satisfying to me.
It is however a pretty cheap game and I suppose for a sale price it is worth it for the curious

author: {'steamid': '76561198150928904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1614625682}
review:
This was a very refreshing game for me. I went in with blank expectations and was genuinely surprised. The gameplay is notably simple, but it deceptively takes on complexity as the game progresses. Each area is relatively similar from a mechanical standpoint, but the music, visuals, enemies, and level designs all come together to give each one a unique atmosphere. Collecting cards based on NPCs and enemies throughout isn't terribly rewarding, but knowing that retrieving more cards will inevitably net you access to max health upgrades, new abilities, and new areas gives them meaning. You also get charming little card descriptions with each one, and although they don't add anything to the gameplay, they do teach you a bit about the story and the world you're in.

The only arguable downside to this game is the story, as it depends what you're looking for going into this game. If you want a very direct game where your mission, your intentions, and the intentions of all of the characters are understandable and laid out for you, this is NOT the game for you. That being said, if you're looking for an abstract, ambiguous, and thought-provoking experience that you'll have to piece together and figure out yourself, you'll LOVE the story.

I highly recommend this game, and it has me thirsting to play the sequel. I hope this helped. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198018829255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 645, 'last_played': 1610827879}
review:
[h1] We need to go deeper into this stranger thing. Directed by David Lynch. [/h1]

At only 3-5 hours with a cheap price tag and overall enjoyable. Yea I can give that a positive review. The graphics drew me in as it reminded me of the old LoZ GBC games, until I realized, oh no wait this is a bit more like Earthbound than LoZ. It's more a mix of both.

Exploring the various places is fun, but sometimes you can get lost, confused, and the map isn't the most helpful. That's a negative.
Meanwhile the fighting is solid, yet challenging.
There's not much else to say about Anodyne other than it was a passion project, and the off-kilter/rude humor gives way to showing off something the devs really cared about and liked. Which again, with a cheap price tag and something you can beat in an afternoon, isn't the worst thing out there, but also above some other games in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996919908', 'num_games_owned': 1529, 'num_reviews': 869, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1610751363}
review:
[h1]Jetzt wird gekehrt [/h1]

Ein Mann, ein Besen und jede Menge Staub!

[b]Gameplay[/b]
„Anodyne“ gibt sich sehr viel Mühe, den Charme der alten „Legend of Zelda“-Spiele einzufangen. Klappt das? Ja, sehr gut! In 16Bit Manier erkunden wir die abwechslungsreiche Spielwelt, bekämpfen mit einem simplen Kampfsystem Monster und lösen Rätsel in den Dungeons. „Anodyne“ lebt mitunter wohl auch davon, dass man ständig die Augen aufhalten muss und neue Spielmechaniken ohne große Erklärungen, aber doch sinnvoll ins Spiel eingefügt werden. Ziel des Spiels ist das Sammeln von genügend Spielkarten, die sich überall in der Welt befinden und sich in beliebiger Reihenfolge einsammeln lassen. Die Spielzeit für einen Durchlauf ist mit 8 Stunden dabei vielleicht übermäßig lang, dafür bleibt das Spiel durch ständige Veränderung allerdings sehr frisch und zieht sich nicht.

[b]Story[/b]
Die Geschichte ist schwer zu fassen. Als Auserwählter kriegen wir den Auftrag eines Magiers, die Karten zu sammeln und so zum „Briar“ vorgelassen werden zu können. Unterwegs treffen wir allerdings noch verschiedene Charaktere, die ganz nett auftreten. Besonders gut hat mir allerdings das Leveldesign nicht nur aufgrund des Gameplays gefallen, sondern auch wegen den einzigartigen Thematiken. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2362998432

[b]Grafik/Sound[/b]
Lasst euch von der „simplen“ 16Bit Grafik nicht täuschen: „Anodyne“ ist nicht einfach hingeklatscht, sondern liebevoll strukturiert. Aber natürlich muss man den Retro-Stil mögen. Wirklich wundervoll ist zu der 16Bit Grafik die 16Bit Musik, die einfach wundervoll ist. Ich habe mir den Soundtrack sogar extra nochmal besorgt.

[b]Fazit[/b]
„Anodyne“ ist ein wundervolles Zelda-like Spiel, dass jedoch nicht nur kopiert. Stattdessen wirken die beiden Entwickler hier sehr inspiriert und machen ihr eigenes Ding, dass auch mit dem Original mithalten kann. „Anodyne“ ist wohl der Inbegriff eines Indietitels und ich kann es wirklich jedem ans Herz legen, der einfach mal einen schlauen Titel spielen möchte. Mittlerweile gibt es übrigens auch [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/877810/Anodyne_2_Return_to_Dust/]Anodyne 2[/url], dass allerdings eine andere Richtung einschlägt. 


Ich schreibe viele Reviews zu Indiespielen. Für mehr davon kannst du mal in [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Drakeschool] meiner Steamgruppe[/url] vorbeischauen. Ich würde mich freuen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179962105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1609961025}
review:
Part of me appreciates what this game wants to be. It straddles the line between Zelda-style action and exploration and a surreal existentialist haze. The problem I have with it, though, is that it's boring.

I see plenty of people praising this because it's like the classic Zelda. Except the original Zelda had a ton of different items. It had money that you could use to buy new equipment and supplies. It had a robust roster of enemies. It had catchy music. It had fast-paced, challenging game play that was augmented by its items and equipment. Anodyne has none of that. Was the original Zelda directionless? Yes. Was it horribly vague at times, especially when it came to finding walls to bomb? Yes. But there were so many resources back in the day to help you out: Nintendo Power, unofficial strategy guides, tip lines: it was vague but you could still beat it. And people tend to forget the reason so many of those games from that era were so vague was due to the hardware limitations. 

Anodyne, after two hours of playing, left me feeling like I was still waiting for a game to begin. Screen after screen with nothing in it. Maze-like paths that led to the same place. Bland environments. Enemies and puzzles that offered no challenge. And man are the tonal shifts bad. Sometimes I could tell it wanted to be like Earthbound with its bizarre humor. Then I travel through a whirlpool formed by a man I killed into a bloodsoaked nightmare realm and perform...an abortion? It was all over the place and it didnt create an engaging experience.

If you want a Zelda-style action game, go play Hyper Light Drifter. Go play 3D Dot Game Heroes. If you want an Earthbound or Undertale clone, find something other than Anodyne. Its dreary and boring in an attempt to come off as deep. But its just boring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039267618', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1609109886}
review:
I must say, I played the game in (more or less) one sitting. I usually do not play games like that so I was fairly new to the 'Zelda-like' experience. 
Overall, I really  enjoyed the game.
The graphics are quite charming, the characters are entertaining, it is a good mixture of humour and darker aspects.
The gameplay on the other hand is quite minimalistic. I played it on a laptop which is not the most ideal way to play this game. Some of the jumping bits were quite a bit frustrating, same with the fact, that you can't attack and walk at the same time. That made no-damage run impossible for me, I'm probalby just not good enough for these kind of games. The many deaths where quite frustrating, since it felt like I couldn't do mouch about it. 
Either way, it was a fun experience. I recommend getting this game once it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021270585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1608939263}
review:
Got this game seeing the 2nd on twitter & wanting to check it out. After giving it a shot, I'm definitely looking forward to playing the sequel next.

As for pros & cons, I really liked how the game managed to replicate the Zelda feel of unique dungeons while letting the player use only two items- where the uniqueness in the dungeon is how the player's broom can interact with the environment, creating rafts of dust, clogging airways so you can walk past them, angering maids and so on.
That being said, the game's weakpoint lies in its level layouts. Levels are far too open, leaving the player with tons of downtime walking between rooms or backtracking- and despite this, there's plenty of areas where I got myself stuck by going past a one way door only to find a locked door on the other side before I had found a key. Creating an environment that allowed the player to circle through it naturally without having to use the "return to entrance" button in the pause menu would've created a much more fluid experience.

All in all, totally recommend it for anyone looking for a very atmospheric and clever indie adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132766666', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1685623195}
review:
If you're looking for a short game where you tackle bite-size dungeons, talk to NPCs with ominous dialogue, and just generally vibe in an eerie world with great music for a while, Anodyne is for you! The story isn't particularly cohesive, but it gets by through sheer atmosphere and personality. And, unlike similar surreal experiences like Off or Space Funeral, that atmosphere is backed up by its competent exploration gameplay. It doesn't do anything particular unique, but I find this blend of dungeon crawling and creepy vibes to be weirdly cozy, relaxing, even.

Anodyne somehow manages to feel mysterious and distant and deeply personal at the same time. It presents itself like some sort of obscure, unknowable game buried within your memories, yet it is also clearly a labor of love between two hard-working game developers. I think it's this feeling of “human sentimentality” that really makes it what it is, that gives depth to its vague sense of dread. Anodyne is messy, flawed, and hard to follow, but it feels like it comes from a special place. I really enjoyed it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965044333', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1603566932}
review:
I can't in good conscience recommend this game, and no, I didn't finish it, but due to the items recovered, I'd say I was somewhere in the middle of it when I gave up. I think this game should be an example of how to NOT make an attempt at a Zelda/Metroidvania game. So, beginner devs, you might want to get this game to see what pitfalls you should avoid.

First off: If you have a weird story, sure, that's fine, some of us love that stuff. But when it's just RANDOM stuff you type out that has no meaning to anyone but yourselves, nobody is going to get it. And after a while, the player isn't going to care either. Allergies or not. 

Secondly: If your game relies on backtracking, make it more obvious where the player is set to go next. A small text indicating "I better make it to the big mountains" is enough. Seriously, without that, your player will do a bit of your exploration and then tire because there's no semblance of connection to anything in the game. It's hard to enjoy a game when it starts feeling like a job you know?

Third and final: IF your game contains jumping, for the love of all things holy, get your jumping mechanics on point. The reason I quit this game was that there's an area in this game that's just one pit fall room after another. And at that point, I asked myself "Am I really having fun here?" .. and then I started thinking back on the other points I mentioned and realized that no, I'm not having fun.

That being said, the mountains were nice though.

review: [i] Anodyne [/i] is a weird one. On its surface it plays like an old-school Zelda game -- explore it's unique world panel-by-panel, fighting monsters, completing "dungeons", and solving puzzles. Delve a little deeper though, and you'll find a strange, disturbing, dark world with many mysteries. Don't expect to finish this game and have everything wrapped up with a nice, pretty bow and all your questions answered. It's surreal, beautiful, and somehow nostalgic. The art design and music pair together wonderfully, and it's definitely worth your time if you enjoy similar games (i.e. [i] OneShot [/i] , [i] OFF [/i] , [i] Lisa [/i] , etc.)

review: I'm going to describe this game as if I don't know what a Zelda game is, because, well, I don't know what a Zelda-like game is. It is a top down action game with a lot of exploration, puzzles, combat and boss fights. Combat is very simplistic you only have attack button and you avoid incoming damage by distancing yourself from enemies or moving away from projectiles and such. Puzzles are kind of easy, not sure if they can be called puzzles as the only thinking you will do is how will you work your way around the map to reach your objectives - you will mostly have to jump over holes that doesn't hurt you if you fail but teleports you back to the room entrance, sometimes you will travel rivers or swamps on a mass of dust while fighting enemies on it, jump over damaging obstacles and stuff. It isn't hard but not too easy to the point of being boring either. You need to collect keys and cards -both not optional- to be able to make progress and reach the final boss fight and ending. It is a nice game and I quite liked it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041278080', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1597760749}
review:
クリア後レビュー

うーん...。
前評判が良くて期待しすぎたせいなのか、自分にはあまり合わなかったです。

クリアはしたし、製品は良いものだとは思うし、
面白くなかったわけではないけれど、人にはおすすめしないかも。
だからサムズダウン。


・良かった点
マップデザインが素晴らしい。探査しがいがあって色んな箇所に行きたくなる。
（私のモチベーションは、ほとんどがこれでした。）

プレイヤースキルを求められているようだけれど、セーブポイントが多くてストレス無く進むこと。


・おすすめする人
ibや青鬼などRPGツクールで遊んでいた人たち。
子どもではないけれどオトナでもない、中高生に合うのかもしれない。

インディー感。学生(大学生)2人が作ったゲーム、というところに反応する人。
白昼夢。ぼーっとした心地。に興味ある人におすすめなのかも。


・良くなかった点
全般を通して雰囲気ゲーム、陰鬱な印象（比較的、明るめのステージも有る）。

支離滅裂な前後の繋がり。ストーリーは、有って無いような印象を受ける。
気になっていたことも、思わせぶりな謎として置いてあるだけで解決するわけではないです。

一部、ほこり設置の移動操作性が悪い（自分の環境だけなのかも）。


・特徴や思ったこと
BGMは先を知りたい不穏な雰囲気に合ってるとも思うけれど、
未完成という印象の方が残ってしまいました。

序盤は退屈な感じ。出来ることが増えて楽しくなってきたけれども、少々苦痛。
ストーリーは曖昧過ぎてモチベーションは色あせていった。
ゆめにっきが比較に出されていて自分も似ていると思ったけれど、
（語弊があるけれど）ゆめにっきの、いつプレイヤーを裏切り刺しに（脅かしに）くるかもしれないというのとは方向性が別物と感じた。ただただ不穏で若干、不気味なだけ。
だから退屈に感じたのかも。

登場人物の特徴的なセリフ回しは好みが分かれるのかな。
優しいセリフ回しは鎮痛剤のようで、その意味でmotherっぽかった。その点は好みでした。
しかし、誰も謎めいていながら何も無い感覚は白昼夢っぽいというか、ストレス虚無というか。

ゲーム概要の"Mash Those Buttons"の説明文に
「本作からは「ゲーム・オブ・ジ・イヤー」の強烈なオーラが見える」とあるけれども、
それに対しては、私は酷く、とても、疑問符が浮かびます。

でもエンディングを見たら、ひとまず満足できました。

p.s.
システム要件の項目は素直で面白いよね。

review:
Серия самых коротких рецензий:

Нормальная

P.S.: Расшифровка:

Трэш — знакомиться с игрой рекомендуется исключительно тем, кто в диком восторге от описания, скриншотов и продолжительности. Остальным, из контакта с этой игрой, только тыкать палкой, как какашку на дороге.
 
Так себе — в основном, эта игра предлагает меньше, чем вы увидите из описания и скриншотов. Рекомендуется только тем, кому вышеперечисленные критерии окажутся «зашибись».

Нормальная — неплохая игра своего жанра. Сами судите по описанию, скриншотам и продолжительность. Игра, примерно, соответствует своему наполнению. 
 
Хорошая — весьма неплохой представитель своего жанра. Многие могут найти тут «свой шедевр». Зачастую, игра приятно соответствует своему описанию и скриншотам.

Отличная — эти игры, зачастую, превосходят свои первые впечатления, основанные на описании и скриншотах (в расчёт не берём репутацию, ибо «тот кто знает, тот поймёт»). Хорошие представители своего жанра.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965213592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 1692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1194, 'last_played': 1596734362}
review:
This game is really something special. Recommended for fans of old school Zelda games, Alundra and other top-down puzzle/adventure games. After nearly 20 hours played, I've finished the main story, but have barely scratched the surface of the secrets/additional post-game content, which is currently consuming my time.

What sets Anodyne apart is the sheer challenge (mostly from puzzles and exploration), dark, creepy and surreal tones/themes/humour, and of course feels. The game's soundtrack is also sublime and sets the mood for this bizarre adventure perfectly.

Anodyne is a very well-made love-letter to the genre, with many of its own innovative twists. You won't be running around with a sword, instead your weapon is a broom, which you will mostly use to solve puzzles and batter enemies to death. This may sound silly, but it is implemented in quite a smart way as you use the broom to manipulate and use dust piles for various purposes. The puzzles are quite fiendish at times (although nowhere near as hardcore as Alundra was, thankfully!), and there is challenge in simply exploring the world and progressing the story.

The story itself is very surreal, and the entire game seems to be very metaphorical. Rather than being set in a literal fantasy world, it seems the game is showing the mental struggle taking place in the mind of an adolescent coming of age and the alienation involved. This leaves a lot of the story up for discussion and debate, which I'd say is much better than being fed exposition. You will still have many questions after you finish the game.

Anodyne is also highly replayable, featuring a New Game Plus which adds quite a significant amount of new content, including many new secrets to discover. After beating the final boss, you will unlock the ability to switch tiles around in the game, allowing you to travel outside of the map, or to pass through previously-impassable barriers to find new secret areas and so on. This is a very neat touch and it's a lot of fun just looking for ways to break the game using the Swap Tool. There are a whole bunch of secret areas and easter eggs to discover using this. I've never seen a dev implement something so strange, but it works exceptionally well.

To conclude, I'd rate this game very highly, and it's up there with other classics of the top-down action RPG genre. I am very much looking forward to playing Anodyne 2 now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112596020', 'num_games_owned': 811, 'num_reviews': 380, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1596589091}
review:
Anodyne is a very average Link to the past like game on the surface, a very INTERESTING/DARK/META/SUPERFRIGGINCRAZYGAMEPLAYMECHANICS under the surface.

Anodyne is a game that I will tell you is best played without this being said so if you are interested in a game like this or love some meta crazy stuff then dont listen to this and just by the game.




NOW THAT THOSE PEOPLE ARE GONE or you arent sure yet:

Anodyne in a lot of its base game is a very average game, like if you do want something like this just play zelda because is crazy better, but the thing that makes this game special is its post game quest and overall late game ideas and settings.

The game tells a deep narrative that I wont spoil but goes into some crazy areas that feel out of place in the game, a lot of the game after beating the majority of it gives you this tool to move parts of the entire map around decunstructing maps to go out of bounds to find secrets. It makes the game very unaccesible for some people who wont go or try to 100% this game. I ultimately did not finish this game or complete it. It usually takes people about 4 hours to complete or 100% it and there is an achievement to do it in 3 hours hardly anyone has. The game in this way is amazing and special in its own way but ultimately for the most part was an average game that brought you back to areas you already were in to hunt down this one place you couldnt access before or to do completely something else and it became a little boring or annoying trying to remember where or back track which lost me about I would say 60% in through the game but I still most definitly reccommned it to others.

7/10 - Its very cool and special in those areas which definitely deserves a 7 AND EVEN HAS YOU GLITCHING INTO THE DEBUG ROOM TO 100% THE GAME but at least 50% of the game is a very average zelda-like game. Those areas truelly make it something else though its alot to get through however and became a little tedious. OH AND DONT EXPECT A HUGE REWARD FOR 100% THE GAME. You actually will get NOTHING which PISSED MANNNY PLAYERS OFF.

review: I had high hopes for this game. The areas are really cool-looking, the soundtrack is fantastic, and I love the creepy, surreal vibe. Exploration is really fun at first, but overstays it's welcome. Dead-ends and empty areas abound - lots of time is spent wandering around repeatedly through the same areas. You need to find these cards to progress. For me, this worked okay (if a bit unoriginal) as a progression mechanic for most of the game. Until the end. That's where I just gave up on it. You need almost every single card available to get to the final boss (36 of 37 available at this point in the game). I said 'screw it' at 30. Aimlessly wandering already explored areas to try and squeeze out 6 more cards didn't sound fun to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977776136', 'num_games_owned': 692, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1593992751}
review:
I like this game a lot. Anodyne gives that nostalgia feel of the old 16-bit adventure games, while throwing in its own twist. The graphics (especially in later levels) are neat and pretty, the audio is very good throughout, the satirical humor is enjoyable, and the difficulty scales fairly reasonably.

About half of this game is an interesting take on the classic style of gameplay and story. However, it won't be long before you notice the game takes a wild turn. It's a sudden shift that I didn't see coming. It made the story so unpredictable that you won't know who's what, or where's why.

Even though I completed the game, I still don't know what the story is about. I can guess, but that's about it. There are many secrets to be found, including good-old-fashioned "hidden paths" or glitches to exploit. I don't know what all the secrets are, but figuring out what's possible when you put your mind to it is part of the fun.

「ゆめにっき＋ゼルダの伝説夢をみる島」という感じ。
温かみのあるグラフィックにどこかホラーを感じさせる雰囲気は最高。またゼルダと形容されるようにアイテムを得るごとに行ける範囲が広がっていくのはゲームとして非常に楽しい。
謎解きやアクションはほどほどの難易度といったところなので気楽にプレイできるところも良い。

author: {'steamid': '76561197985797191', 'num_games_owned': 5587, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1591962002}
review: As they've described in the "about this game" it plays like a 2D Zelda game, the atmosphere and story though feel more akin to Earthbound. I'm loving this story, the atmosphere, the boss fights but I'm really struggling with the controls and the gameplay. I don't know why but for a 2D game I'm struggling to work out exactly where I'm standing in relation to platforms and enemies. It's making basic enemies like bats and sections that require accurate character placement extremely frustrating. I do recall for example Zelda a Link to the Past being a little bit like this and having a similar problem but I just don't recall being as frustrated by it. I'm also finding the controls a little floaty, although it might be because I'm using the analogue stick on an xbox 360 controller so I think I'll try the D pad or just the keyboard instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080018933', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1577627545}
review:
I really enjoyed playing this game. Must say tho that after playing the first time for just few minutes I had a hard time to get back at this game. It was around the time I played through the first dungeon that I got really addicted to this game. I found myself playing a couple of hours completely forgetting about time. Everytime you enter a new area there are multiple directions to explore, and you really want to!

Gameplay wise it feels like your typical zelda-game, wich is great for those that like it. Was first playing it with a keyboard, but I suggest to play it with a controller. Makes it easier with boss-battles.

Also really loved the soundtrack. Gives you the feeling/emotion every environment needs.

It's hard to describe exactly what kind of style/ambience/emotion this game brings you. It's kind of a mix of everything, wich at the same time feels perfect that way.

So if you really like playing zelda-like games and like games that have a unique style with them, I really suggest you give this one a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123373354', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1588958432}
review:
Игра ничего. Мне нравится ходить, бродить, но даже не смотря на это она показалась затянутой. Будь она на треть-четверть короче, хуже бы не стало. 

Геймплей не напрягающий большую часть игры, и это хорошо. Правда под конец становится нужно немного более осознанно нажимать на клавиши, я не очень понял, зачем мне это. Может мне просто поднадоело уже.

Юмор странный, местами и не очень приятный. Хотя сами диалоги иногда приятны или даже интересны.

С сюжетом тут вообще странно. Сначала кажется, что сюжета тут нет, либо он пародийный. Со временем растет чувство, что тут все метафорично, особенно в конце. Но в действительности тут и то, и другое. Двоякие впечатления. Метафора тут где-то и есть, но такого уж прям сюрреализма и психоделики тут не чувствуется. За этим лучше к Юменикки фангеймам. Эта игра слишком похожа на нормальную, как для меня. В смысле, понято, может быть, задумывалось, что это все сон, главный герой в нем спит, разбирается там со своими проблемами, психология, все такое... Но оно так не выглядит большую часть игры. Просто бродишь и бродишь.

Какие-либо сильные эмоции игра вряд ли вызовет. Но если настроение просто на медитатив, можно попробовать.

author: {'steamid': '76561198207083779', 'num_games_owned': 1291, 'num_reviews': 841, 'playtime_forever': 1659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1659, 'last_played': 1587187775}
review:
This is a very complicated game with intricate puzzles.  Some puzzles I solved purely by accident.  It isn't easy to describe, unless you play it.  It is very unique and people who worked on it: really put a lot of thought and passion into it.  The music/OST set the mood/places exactly.  If you like figuring puzzles out and doing crazy jumps: go for it.  If you like to figure out the symbolism of this game: go for it (everyone has their own interpretation).  Looks good, plays good, but it will never ever hold your hand...

I commend this game for its accomplishments and it actually made me be a more "confident" player, because that's the only way I could do majority of pretty much everything.  Kudos and best of luck to the team.  Always.  Thank you for the fun game.  :D :) :>

P.S. I made sure I didn't finish the card collection, so I can come back once again and practice my skills at it.

review:
Pretends to be an homage to old school NES roguelikes, Zelda and so on... But it fails due to a poor level design and a total absence of cohesion.

Anodyne makes no sense at all, you walk the levels wondering what's going on, why would walking plants, a dog and slims join forces to kill an old man with a broom.

And while you try to figure out you get bored listening to annoying elevator music.

There are plenty of better options than this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143351556', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1586730562}
review: the game look interesting and fun from all the pics and videos it advertises, unfortunately i couldnt even play this game. At the very beginning  i was greeted with a controller config process... that doesnt work, the first time you have an option for yes or no to start the controller config, i said yes. it choose a button for "UP" for me and the test white block just kept floating up on its own. the second time i said yes again and the same thing happened. after that i was stuck at this controller config yes or no screen and now the confirm buttons nor the keyboard buttons work. i closed the game and reopened, it happened again right after the second time. i quit and restarted, and again the same. so i gathered the game must be programmed to troll you so i just quickly pressed up on the gamepad before the game will automatically assign something like it does and followed the directions finished and started the game. the character just kept walking up and i couldnt get him to stop. i looked around online and i guess this has been going on for over a year and was never fixed, i guess its supposed to be like this. Anyway i had give a negative review since the game was unplayable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198349670496', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1640283591}
review: Anodyne es un homenaje a los juegos clásicos de Nes como The Legend of Zelda y el resultado es un juego realmente extraño. Lo que más me ha chocado ha sido la grandísima diferencia temática entre cada escenario y también el lore que trae consigo cada uno de ellos, en el caso que sea apropósito consigue una ambientación bastante guay, porque de verdad se siente como una aventura en 2D pero totalmente alejado de los juegos clásicos. También le podemos añadir que la banda sonora juega un papel secundario excelente, no esperaba para nada algo tan bueno. Anodyne es un juego corto y bastante divertido, su gran pega son sus mecánicas que pese a ser simples y sencillas tienen muchos errores a lo largo del juego, incluyendo las de los bosses, desafíos finales que acaban convirtiéndose en puros machaca-botones.

If Anodyne manages to make you f e e l, you'll love it. If not, then it's simply not for you. But for what it's trying to do it's doing great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032408385', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1710869614}
review:
I am writing this here because Epic Games doesn't have reviews yet. I got Anodyne 2 while it's free and wanted to play the first one before venturing to the second.

While Anodyne 1 was a Legend of Zelda clone which tells a very personal story with a few personal gimmicks, Anodyne 2 is beyond being a clone, it's a great game by itself. It still tells a sorta personal story and has some kinda "god bad/human free will good" theme generally. But whatever it does, it does with care. Care with its dialogs, care with its gameplay, care with its nostalgic PSX feels and with its world design too. 

The best thing about Anodyne 2 is the game constantly breaks gameplay expectations with different areas, changing gaming history eras, connections with other games, tropes or cliches. The fun writing helps this too.

I recommend getting the two games together and hopefully you will reach and find the sort of secret connection between them. It would have been no offense even if there were none. But there is, it's a cool bonus and it made me glad I bought the first one too.

Great job. I will be waiting for more of you two.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025909144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1617534065}
review: Questo gioco mi ha ricordato No more heroes (per meglio dire No more heroes 2 visto che è quello a cui ho giocato io), No more heroes ha una storia abbastanza semplice da capire di base, strana magari però semplice, poi parte e ci infila dentro di tutto cose senza senso e assurde che non hai assolutamente idea di cosa vogliono dire e del perché sono lì e non ci capisci niente ma va bene lo stesso. Anodyne è un pò simile, solo che gli manca il punto di partenza semplice che sembra avere senso. Anodyne è solo una valanga di assurdità pazzesche, confusionarie e fuori di testa che incontrate una dopo l'altra senza possibilità di capirci niente. In realtà spesso è abbastanza chiaro di quali argomenti volessero parlare gli sviluppatori (c'è parecchia depressione, disagio, temi controversi e scabrosi, cose così), ma è come avere degli improvvisi flash di lucidità in cui si afferra un concetto generale in mezzo ad un casino allucinante di cui si continua a non capire il senso. E gli sviluppatori spesso mi hanno dato l'impressione di essere nella fase "adolescente edgy", se non fosse chiaro abbastanza lo dico esplicitamente. Se quanto ho detto finora non vi spaventa (tenete anche conto che Anodyne è più calmo e rilasssato di No more heroes, molto meno sopra le righe, e per questo motivo questi contenuti risultano un pò più pesanti) posso consigliare Anodyne perché il gameplay e la struttura dei livelli sono molto intriganti e piacevoli. In pratica è un grosso labirinto suddiviso in varie zone tematiche in cui lo scopo è riuscire a raggiungere tutte le aree esistenti quindi fondamentalmente è un gioco di esplorazione, e il gameplay è semplice e immediato al punto giusto da risultare molto divertente e appassionante. Dal punto di vista tematico e narrativo non l'ho apprezzato molto perché trovo che essendo così criptico da più che altro l'impressione di essere fuori luogo e inopportuno. Non è l'unico gioco che mi ha lasciato qualche dubbio riguardo al significato, ma tra i giochi di questo tipo è l'unico in cui questa cosa mi ha infastidito. Come gioco è bello, e posso apprezzare il tentativo di creare qualcosa di strano e bizzarro fuori dagli schemi, ma Anodyne non fa nulla per venire incontro al giocatore. Quantomeno una trama un pò più digeribile per fare da collante a tutto il gioco avrebbero potuto sforzarsi per crearla.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979830493', 'num_games_owned': 1262, 'num_reviews': 326, 'playtime_forever': 366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1589093729}
review:
I really like the vibes, and I'll likely buy the soundtrack. Best OST I've heard in years. I dig the general aesthetic and I did find a lot of similarities between components of both Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past and Anodyne. Gameplay is pretty slow, and combat seemed quite trivial in terms of difficulty. 

I only found the atmosphere, design, and puzzles to be of appropriate depth. Combat, story, and variety of gameplay were all very shallow. The combat changes very little throughout the game, and introduces very few new enemies. It felt like the game mostly just berates you with puzzle after puzzle. All require the player to  determine what mix of things/actions need to happen in order to make an area or chest accessible. Rinse, repeat. It all became a bit tedious leaving me mostly interested in what the next zone's theme and music will be.

My recommendation is to skip the game, check out the soundtrack, and see if maybe Anodyne 2 is any better (I haven't checked yet). I don't find this game compelling enough to recommend as of April 2020. 

[i]IF you love action-puzzles and find the game at it's historical lowest on-sale price of $0.99 cents - then I'd say go for it.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198332701463', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1582339244}
review:
This game COMPLETELY surpassed my expectations. I'm normally a big fan of Zelda-like games, but I passed this one over multiple times because the screenshots made it look boring and generic. But what the screenshots fail to capture is the incredible atmosphere. The game juxtaposes the ordinary with the strange and unexplained to create a surreal feeling, with an excellent soundtrack to add to the surrealness. It's also much more than just a Zelda clone. It adds many unique ideas of its own to the formula, like a broom that you can use to pick up and move dust to solve puzzles and fight enemies, as well as serving as your "sword". There's also water, which you can only wade through for a certain number of blocks before sinking, but can travel over using a piece of dust as a raft. 

Top-down platforming is a central focus of the game, with a dedicated jump button. The mechanics are surprisingly good, and it doesn't become frustrating because if you fall in a hole, it's just a slap on the wrist as you respawn at the entrance to the current room. I've heard a bunch of reviews complaining about the jumping mechanics, which makes me think the people writing them made it through the entire game without figuring out how to coyote jump. If you don't know what I'm talking about, look up "coyote time". It's a feature in most platformers that allows you to jump for a few frames AFTER you walk off a ledge. It's very powerful and easy to use in Anodyne. Once you get the hang of it, you should be able to jump over two block wide holes fairly easily. And the majority of the game is designed with the assumption that you can only jump over one block so coyote jumping actually allows you to skip over some sections of dungeons. I wouldn't consider it an exploit, because there are some areas in the game that can only be accessed by coyote jumping, so the devs must have put it in on purpose, but it's not explained in-game so a lot of people probably missed it. 

If you have ever had even a passing interest in top down Zelda or Zelda-like games, I would highly recommend Anodyne. It has a lot more to offer than its screenshots and description let on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198273981402', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1191, 'last_played': 1580251626}
review:
❀ Shorter review : 
Anodyne appears as a game that possibly has the best post game quest developed by a classic duo. The world of Anodyne presents itself in melancholy atmosphere and music. Overall, it’s a retro collectathon, platformer and puzzle game. 

☆ Longer review :
In the beginning, Young gets tasked to save Briar from the darkness. The Sage gives him advice on what he’ll have to do in order to be strong enough to defeat him. As Young, you get to explore a wide vast of areas with interesting characters, settings and much more. 

☀ The gameplay :
Each item you get proves important for your journey. Combat is simple and quick. There’s a few bosses that need a bit of puzzle and platform in order to defeat them. Normally when finishing a boss, there’s a heart fairy that gives you an extra heart container and some fairies are just in new maps you visit. Because it’s a collectathon, the more cards you collect, the more areas you unlock.

☁ Maps and OST : 
They compliment each other. Without a good OST, the maps would be lacking and vise versa. Anodyne does a great job at displaying this. There were songs when visited would give such an eerie and uncomfortable vibe, example “Blank” and Woods” gave me mega chills. But songs are vibrant, relaxing and colorful like “Fields” and “Windmill.” The aesthetics of the maps are very pretty. It feels like some areas I’d like to visit for hours others appear as creepy and grim. It’s a nice variety.

☂ Conclusion :
This game’s often compared to old Zelda games. I agree with it, but there’s so much more to Anodyne than meets the eye. This game’s perfect for if you love puzzle solving and pixel graphics. I love what this game provides and I hope you do too.

review:
I don't have a lot to say about Anodyne, it's a nice Zelda-like reminiscent of Link To The Past but in a dream world of beautiful, relaxing, surreal, and sometimes unsettling environments. If you're a fan of games that focus on the atmosphere with relatively chill gameplay and story to go along with it (like Yume Nikki, FEZ, Knytt) you'll love this. Plus, the soundtrack is amazing, it sets a consistent tone without feeling too samey (and contrast is used to great effect).

There's also some really interesting postgame stuff to explore if you get through the base game and want more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198368722500', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1578491508}
review:
[h1]Anodyne had an interesting post-game, but that was all I enjoyed about it.[/h1]
Anodyne's gameplay is most accurately described as a meh Link's Awakening clone. It never evolves past that stab, dodge, and repeat with the combat. Environments are another personal complaint of mine. They ranged from being genuinely interesting to extremely generic. The black-and-white town and flesh dungeon were dark and visually unique, but then some areas are just normal lakes,  generic forests, and straight-line mazes. It's hard to say why I had issues with the soundtrack, but it just wasn't engaging. Story-wise, I liked it a tiny bit, but it's all shoved into the very end of the game. The only thing I enjoyed about it was the post-game, as the title would suggest. Having collectibles hidden out of bounds and having some even require the use of glitches was pretty interesting. But to get to that, you have to go through a slog of the main game. If you have any interest in Anodyne, I suggest skipping straight to the sequel. The gameplay and graphics seem much more varied, which is a major plus. And they even keep the map-breaking element, but in a 3D environment, which makes that mechanic much more interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561199006042865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1578034784}
review:
It feels like the world of Yumme Nikki meets the gameplay of Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening.

The gameplay is pretty solid, however requires a bit of backtracking and while the early dungeons are fun to explore some of the later worlds, such as the hotel, which is too long compared to the other dungeons, and the maze which is 90% dead ends with only one item to collect, don't feel as fun to explore. The music is pretty good and fits the game and places in which they are used, probably the best is the Windmill theme. The puzzles are pretty easy to solve, especially early on, to the point they felt useless to the overall game. While the game is for the most part not hard, the parts where it does offer a challenge don't even feel fair or interesting. The only 2 hard enemies is the dog, who can be beat by the boring method of running away from him and attacking when he stops, and the lion, who you beat by just attacking his fire breath. This is probably due to the fact you only have one weapon in the entire game, making combat severely restricted. Some of the jumps in the game have to be very precise to achieve, until you realize you can jump halfway into the sprite of the hole and still not fall. The graphics go for a pixel aesthetic, but don't do anything special artistically to set it apart.

While the plot is I'm guessing supposed to have some sort of symbolism, it feels somewhat tacked on. The themes don't fully come across and some parts, such as the[spoiler]town where you stab people with a knife, the backstory of said town, and the blood sea world[/spoiler]feel like they're supposed to have some follow-through, but since they don't feel like the game trying to hard to be "deep". I feel the creator made the game to explore themes of loneliness & living in fantasy worlds in your imagination, however there is way too much fluff that has nothing to do with said theme.

While I feel the game is quite fun for the most part, the fact your combat options are severely limited, some of the boring dungeons, and short length, the game feels more like a flash game you'd find on newgrounds or armor games. Not a bad game, but probably not worth $9.99.

Overall an alright game with good music, decent 2D zelda style gameplay, half good half boring worlds, and pretty forgettable "deep" plot.

Rating: 6.5/10

review:
Anodyne is almost what it advertises itself as: a Zelda-lite. But where Zelda is a lighthearted adventure in a fantasy world, Anodyne is more of an uncanny trip in nightmare land with some pretty grim stuff thrown in for good measure. It might be an acquired taste, but it works pretty well for me personally. 

The UI is clearly made for mobile devices, but works decent enough on desktop. Unfortunately, joypad input is locked to one of the sticks. If you use a joypad I recommend using something like joytokey for remapping the arrow keys to your d-pad to get around this, since controlling protagonist Young with a stick is less than ideal. 

All in all, I'd say this is among the better sub-1€ games (I picked it up on sale) I've played this year, and it's clearly worth more than that.

review:
When you played Zelda, did you wish you were wielding a broom? Did you think to yourself, "You know, what if the plot were more like an acid trip?" Then you'll enjoy Anodyne. And even if you didn't want those things from Zelda and even if you're someone who's incapable of enjoying anything, you'll at least admire Anodyne for its surreal, often philosophical meanderings. 

Mechanically, maybe the game isn't super interesting: You go from stage to stage collecting cards to unlock a door that leads to the final boss, but its style elevates it from a retro cash-grab to something artistic that will add value to your Steam library.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973155187', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1603468392}
review:
Pretty neat little game, I enjoyed it. The whole map feels like a dungeon. I liked discovering new places. The whole is not very long, took me about 10 hours to finish it, but that's fine. The game is like a dessert. I feel like it's perfect the way it is.

The story is a bit unusual, but that's good, and I liked the characters and the whole feel of the game. There are good ideas in this game!! I had fun! 

Some say this has a zelda gameboy feel. I would say, yes, the way the game is played, there's definitely a similarity, and I enjoyed it!

I would recommend playing with a NES/SNES style gamepad (i used joytokey), it's very fitting for this game.

A note, the sequel is a somewhat different game (but the sequel features elements with 2D micro universes that definitely call back to this game)

author: {'steamid': '76561198334210502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1581659497}
review: First, let me get this out of the way- the game does have some slight performance issues, due to being made (from what I've heard) in Flash. However, I quickly got over them due to just how awesome this game is. The puzzles and dungeons are extremely fun, meeting that nice blend of action and brain usage that was present in the gameboy Zelda games, and the atmosphere is so great. I've heard people say this story makes no sense, but I have a few ideas of what it could be interpreted as, and you should try to interpret it in your own ways as well! Even if you get no story significance from it, however, it's still a great time to play through, and has hands-down the neatest postgame quest of any game I've seen. Please- play. this. game. I'm endlessly surprised with just how little people have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068812845', 'num_games_owned': 257, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3855, 'last_played': 1571244523}
review: I dont leave reviews often, but this one felt worth saying something. I really enjoyed the art style, the game play was simple and easy to master. I enjoyed the overall feel of the game, but it def wouldn't be for everyone. Its a little odd. if you enjoy a zelda like experience set in a bit of a slimmed down parallel universe then this might be for you. The card collection system was fine, didn't seem like much of a hurdle to enjoying the game as some other reviews have stated. The one thing i would advise is that if you need  direction on where to go, have the wiki handy. Either I was totally oblivious to the clues as to where to go next to progress, or there really wasn't much in the way of "hey, head this way next if you want to keep going", which seemed intentional on the creators part. Overall I was happy to complete it, and would recommend it to friends that want something a little different to play casually as they wind down from the day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126076637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1624219248}
review:
Ever since playing Yume Nikki in my early twenties, I've wished for a game that took the same "dream feel" atmosphere and surrealism, but applied meaningful game mechanics. Anodyne comes the closest I've ever seen to satisfying that desire. 

A lot of you probably don't know what Yume Nikki is, so I'll try to explain what I mean without that context. In Anodyne, you are set free to explore the world, a world clearly representative of the main character's subconscious. The game doesn't hold you hand or apply much in the way of interpretation; all of that is left up to you. Because of the lack of hand holding, the puzzles and exploration feel real, like you are discovering a lost country. 

A lot of people are saying that this is a lot like early Zelda games. I can't make much comment there because I've never played a Legend of Zelda game (yes, I've played Yume Nikki and not Zelda; don't ask). However, the game has some very basic combat based on learning patterns and dodging attacks. It's well-done. I'm a fan of slower, "learn the pattern and chip away at the enemies health when the opportunity arises" kind of combat. It's also very easy--most bosses I only died to once or twice if at all--until you get to the final boss. That spike in difficulty shocked me a bit, but it also drove home the theme. Plus, it was one of those bosses where you know exactly what you're supposed to do, but your fingers turn into french fries after playing for so long, so...it might not have been as hard as it seemed in the middle of the night. 

If you love exploring and atmosphere (and if you have a thing for surrealism) I highly recommend this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979784190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1568887481}
review:
For the sale price, this game was well worth the purchase, and I had a great time finishing it. 

It feels like a forgiving blend between a simplified 2D Zelda and Earthbound. The game features dark, random conversations that interact with real life issues, light puzzling, light platforming, and a small yet diverse world. Each map's theme is uniquely beautiful, with a soundtrack that feels perfect. Every dungeon was fun, and the travel mechanics work extremely well with the game's progress.

I wish there was more of just about everything: save slots or profiles, maps, dungeons, map tiles, enemy types, items, weapons, weapon complexity, and NPCs.

The minute amount of content destroys instant replayability. I may revisit the game in the far off future, assuming the human world, including infrastructure, doesn't devolve into bedlam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136535250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 693, 'last_played': 1613783041}
review:
Mexendo bastante com a jornada do herói, Anodyne é capaz de reproduzir a pegada dos Zeldas 2D, adicionando um twist próprio para surpreender o jogador. Sua arte e trilha sonora evocam um senso de nostalgia no jogador e seus segredos incentivam demais a exploração, te deixando ou tenso ou intrigado com o quê o jogo busca te contar.

Não cheguei a ter nenhum problema com o jogo além da dificuldade em saber pra onde ir, ainda mais quando se perde foco ou deixa-se o jogo encostado por um tempo. O que se torna um problema já que saber pra onde ir te leva a cards que, consequentemente, avançam a trama até conclusão. Para os que tiverem paciência, além do final da história, você desbloqueia uma ferramenta nova, te dando acesso a um pós-game genial.

Para quem curte Zelda-likes recheados de segredos, Anodyne é exatamente isso e ainda mais.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103916275', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 271, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1567797587}
review:
Ganz launig, aber echt nichts Besonderes und schnell wieder vergessen

Nun, wenn ich Anodyne mit einem Wort beschreiben müsste, dann würde ich das Wort „Meh“ wählen. Dieses Indie-Top-Down Action-Adventure mag zwar gut spielbar sein, ein paar nette Rätsel bieten und mit einer interessanten Game+ Idee locken, aber unterm Strich erwartet einem ein eher langweiliges Machwerk, dass sich hinter dem Deckmantel der Indie-Kunst so einige grobe Schnitzer leistet. Die Handlung ist kryptischer Müll – muss man einfach mal so deutlich ausdrücken. Die Grafik ist dermaßen grobpixelig, dass keine nostalgischen Gefühle entstehen möchten. Und ich verstehe beim besten Willen nicht, warum man den Bildausschnitt auf Danmaku-Breite quetschen musste. Macht null Sinn. Und da im Gameplay-Bereich eigentlich auch keine wirklich nennenswerten Highlights ins Gedächtnis springen wollen, kann man nur noch den OST als großes Pro-Argument aufführen. Dieser erzeugt eine schöne surreal-melancholische Stimmung, welche Anodyne einiges an Persönlichkeit mit auf dem Weg gibt.
Versteht mich nicht falsch, Anodyne ist schon ganz launig, aber wenn man so ein improvisiertes Indie-Spielchen kurze Zeit nach einem Vollblüter wie Minish Cap zockt, dann merkt man recht schnell, dass hier nicht allzu viel dahintersteckt.


Pro und Kontra:

Pro:
- schöner Soundtrack, der seinen eigenen Flair erzeugt
- sehr gute Steuerung und Spielbarkeit
- spätere Dungeons sind ganz gut aufgebaut und bieten auch einige nette Rätsel

Neutral:
- 8,99 € für ca. 5+ Stunden Spielzeit
- eine durchaus interessante Game+ Idee, die leider unkomfortabel umgesetzt wurde

Kontra:
- die Handlung ist nicht viel mehr als ein kryptisches Interpretations-Gebräu
- etwas zu grobpixelige Grafik, die obendrein in einem zusammengestauchten Bildformat dargestellt wird
- öde Bossgegner (der finale Bosskampf ist aber gut gelungen)
- die Spielabschnitte zwischen den Dungeons wirken eher zäh und nervig
- die Jump-Passagen im späteren Spielverlauf können sehr nervig werden

author: {'steamid': '76561198058287257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 987, 'last_played': 1566098319}
review: A dreamy atmospheric game with a tight Zelda-like design with an enjoyable freedom of movement and lots of great exploration and secrets. The gameplay is simple but it uses its elements well. It has a distinct identity from Zelda through it's sometimes peaceful and sometimes forboding and mysterious atmosphere with the excellent OST, but calls to mind the charm of the gameboy Zelda games with charming NPCs, and the snappy, replayable nature of the gameplay in the dungeons. It is far more than just a "Zelda clone", there is a lot of heart put into this game. I'll admit the story had me kind of lost since it was somewhat vague, but it was fun to attempt to analyze and theorize what was going on as I played through. And despite not really getting it, I enjoyed the writing in general, and there were bits that made me feel good and  waxing a bit philisophical. I was very happy with my purchase by the end. It was a very relaxing and enjoyable experience that just pulled together a lot of my tastes together in a succinct, tasty package. If you're into speedrunning, I think something like this would (most likely?) be a great speed game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063811792', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1565174512}
review:
My opinion about this game is relatively mixed. Everything in Anodyne is so jarring and juxtaposing that it really goes against my expectations, both positively and negatively. There will be spoilers, but I will censor them out. 

Let's start off by mentioning the gameplay, considering that it's the easiest thing to talk about. The game plays as an excruciatingly off heart Link's Awakening clone. You have your "sword" and your "Roc's Feather". I mean, sure, they are obviously changed to be other items... that are more random than Link's Awakening, but it plays like Link's Awakening, feels like Link's Awakening, and I could not stop thinking about how this compares to Link's Awakening whenever I had to do a tough jump or when I was in combat. However, the combat feels slightly more stiff due to the animation while attacking, and the fact that there are upgrades for your weapon to extend its reach. However, the feedback you receive when hitting an enemy is oddly satisfying. 

To be honest, I'm not exactly bothered by the fact that it's fairly inspired by Link's Awakening, but the part about the gameplay that really ticks me off is how exploitable and buggy Anodyne is as a game. The movement feels extremely finicky due to the way that Young's sprite bugs around a lot whenever you change directions extremely quickly. The jump, while well explored with other mechanics in the game, I felt was a nuisance and wasn't necessary, and could be replaced by something else. Especially considering that the jump is simply ridiculous. The map design just doesn't complement the jump feature very well, you can skip into an extremely late section of the game using the jump, hitboxes are hit or miss with the jump, and when I felt like I actually needed the jump for a mechanic, I didn't really feel much satisfaction from solving a puzzle, more from the fact that I'd expect to land on a platform, only to fall through. I simply don't like the jump feature, and I feel like the game could have been better without it if the developers worked around other puzzle solving mechanics instead.

When I mentioned the game was buggy, I didn't just mean Young's sprite. There were a lot of instances where I felt like some parts weren't refined. I encountered:
[list]
    [*] Buggy interactions with enemies and gates, sometimes enemies would spontaneously explode for no reason, and the rules for opening an enemy gate often varied, confusing me significantly. "Why is the gate open when I haven't killed all the enemies? Why does one gate open but not the other?" To make matters worse, some gates would often reappear even though I cleared out the room and some gates were unsure of whether they were open or not (I literally just cleared the room, why is it playing the gate animation and sound effect when I re-enter?). Buttons for gates don't disappear when they are used as well, so it just makes gates more frustrating for me to deal with. 
    [*] A glitch which softlocked my game, jumping into a portal and returning to the Nexus at the same time results in a black screen that isn't interactable.
    [*] The "return to Entrance" button returns you to the actual entrance of each dungeon, rather than where you last entered the dungeon, which can break the flow of exploration.
    [*] The glitch that I feel ruined the game most, to the extent where I will censor it simply because it's that exploitable, [spoiler] the "Wiggle Glitch". If you keep going in between vertical boundaries while holding a vertical direction, Young will continuously be able to push himself further vertically with each transfer, until you can quite literally walk through a wall or over a pit. I despise this one because it was left in the game [b] on purpose as a puzzle post game.[/b] [/spoiler]
[/list]

That was a bit of a tangent on the gameplay, so I'll move on to music and sound effects (because I can transition). I can't really say that I'm into the soundtrack, the soundtrack is just a bit too melancholy for me, which makes sense for the game, but at the same time I just didn't feel like the tunes held any complexity or significance to me. I felt like the music never really coexisted with the area I was in. I did notice some leitmotif of the main theme, but otherwise, the music tended to juxtapose and change mood way too quickly for me. I do notice some people saying that they like the soundtrack though, and I can respect that. The sound effects are mostly crisp and nice, but some are penetrating or have a bit too much noise in them. 

So the real elephant in the room I have to deal with are the themes of the game, I have no idea as to how I'd describe Anodyne as a game thematically. The game just 0-100's it with the graphics, on one end of the spectrum, you have beautiful, lush, ambient landscapes akin to games in the SNES era such as Chrono Trigger, however, while you're enjoying that area, the game quickly pulls the rug underneath you throws you in the face areas that are grotesque, blunt and rather dull, almost describing the title of the game... The themes too, change with this drastic extent, the dialogue and characters are most of the time extremely cryptic, philosophical or existential with their dialogue, but then you never feel that the game ever takes itself seriously in regards to that. The game can literally go from cute to murder in the snap of a finger. It feels semi-surreal, but themes are never explored to full detail, which I found disappointing due to the potential and psychological impact some of the events and areas have over you. Speaking of these areas, they're tough to navigate due to how little the map gives you in terms of information. The map only marks whenever there is an entrance to another room, or an entrance to a dungeon. And there can be multiple entrances in the same direction, which is further omitted by this basic map. I found a lot of frustration in trying to navigate Anodyne due to how little information the map gave me.

It's a shame that I have mostly negative things to say about the main game, because I feel that the game gets significantly better once you finish the main part. Going into spoiler territory, [spoiler] near the end of the game, you are given the ability to swap any tile in a room, including walls, allowing you to go out of bounds in specific areas. This concept by itself is so humbling and intuitive, as the idea of the developers hiding hidden easter eggs, areas and collectibles just out of sight is intriguing, and it shows their appreciation for their project and how open they are to interpretation. It also acts as a semi fix to the jump and is a lot more fun as a mechanic to explore due to its originality and power over the game than the jump. I hate the jump. [/spoiler] 

To conclude, I still feel like the game is feasible. The surreal and jarring nature of the game grabbed my attention for most of the time, and I appreciated the efforts from the developers (who are a two person team by the way), but there are a significant amount of flaws that detract from this experience. I'd say get the game, but maybe on a sale or something, or only if you're confident you'll really like it.

I'm looking forward to see what the sequel will bring on the table.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148620362', 'num_games_owned': 430, 'num_reviews': 502, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1564208852}
review:
《Anodyne》，有“镇痛剂”之意，是一款冷门的像素风格，俯角2D探险类游戏。商店页面也说了，是一种类似塞尔达的模式。

作为一个穷学生，我并没有真的玩过塞尔达，也没玩过类塞尔达的游戏。但是一种类似模式的游戏我却玩过很多——类银河战士恶魔城。诚然两种模式还是非常不同的，但我们还是可以发现这两种模式有很多相同的地方，而且两种模式给玩家带来乐趣的主要原因是相同的，就是允许玩家在一个互通的世界中自由探索，而不是用某种“选关画面”让玩家脱戏。

那么这款游戏做到了什么样的程度呢？

......其实就像我说的，我以前没玩过这样类型的游戏，所以对我来说，新鲜感应该会更多一些。

这款游戏的主角Young，使用扫帚作为武器，在一个迷幻的世界中进行冒险。有多迷幻呢？说老实话，我通关了这款游戏，但仍然想不明白这个游戏想表达什么，包括剧情本身。地图的风格会在明亮和阴暗之间反复横跳，而且我说的阴暗，是真的很阴暗，包括[spoiler]自杀，杀人，血[/spoiler]等内容，会引起一定的心理不适。诚然这些内容在像素画面下的“表现力”肯定不如专门的恐怖游戏，但是还是挺膈应的。

正如上面所说，这款游戏主题十分怪异，有时就像是正常的明亮RPG风格，有时血刺呼啦不可名状就像是恐怖游戏。基于这一点，游戏中的一些细节（一些明显不应该在某个地方的某种东西，或者说出了明显不符合这个世界的“现实”的话语），以及“镇痛剂”这个名字，我只能差不多理解到，游戏的主题和[spoiler]精神疾病/妄想[/spoiler]应该是有点关系。

虽然游戏很怪异，但是jumpscare还是没有的，如果你的心理承受能力不错，可以接受一定程度的阴暗要素，那就可以说到游戏性的方面了。

本作如同塞尔达一样，拥有探索、战斗、解谜这些要素。而且其实还做得非常不错，至少我玩得非常开心。地形、谜题、敌人和BOSS的设计都非常不错，很有意思。

不过有一个位置稍显不足，那就是游戏的通关需要收集37个收集物中的至少36个，而我认为游戏内部没有任何对于这方面的提示，也就是说，如果你错过了什么东西，那找起来可就不是一件好玩的事情了。所幸收集物之间是有分别的，可以查社区指南来找到某个特定的收集物的位置。不过如果你有精神洁癖，不想查攻略，那我还是建议你，第一次到某个地方的时候，尽量直接把所有的支路全部探完。基本上，只要你能进去一个区域，所有这个区域中的收集物都可以收集到。否则，游戏体验会有点差。

这个游戏据说有post-game（也就是通关后专属）的内容，然而我不太想打了，貌似也就是一些收集，和一个额外的关卡之类的？

这样就评价完了这个游戏。至于我是怎么找到这个游戏的，那真的是阴错阳差。Twitter上面的一则推送让我看到了在今年8月发售的《Anodyne 2》的宣传片（顺带一提，续作貌似多出了一个2D/3D切换的机制，看上去很NB），于是我就先买了一代玩玩。目前看来，续作除了3D建模好像有一点......复古，还是值得期待的，希望续作能够继续抓住塞尔达式的乐趣，并利用2D/3D切换来达到更加高的成就（只要关卡设计不崩坏就好......）。

（虽然因为学习原因我不得不在2020年6月之后才能玩到了）

author: {'steamid': '76561198857410560', 'num_games_owned': 417, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 955, 'last_played': 1562520610}
review:
Great game! In the start, Anodyne may feels like just another 2D Zelda-like game, but it sure stands out for its own thing later in the game.

Amazing soundtrack (which helps a lot with the bizarre/strange/enigmatic atmosphere), enigmatic story, nice progressive difficulty and a lot of post-end game content. The combat is also nice (although the main focus of the game is not the combat) and the puzzles are fun.

It requires a lot of exploration, which can be classified as "boring" to some people. However, this exploration plays a big role in the enigmatic narrative. Once you get in the vibe of the game, it only gets better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033604792', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1039, 'last_played': 1590328050}
review:
Fun game. 
Gameplay is a lot like Zelda (people say its especially like Link's Awakening, a portable Zelda game I haven't played) but with a different atmosphere. You explore a wide variety of environments, many of which are surreal, bizarre and sometime eerie (inspired in part by Yume Nikki). 
There are some tricky puzzles and combat sections that took me little while to get through. One gameplay element I liked was the map you're provided with that helped me figure out places I hadn't gone to yet.
The graphics are retro/NES quality and the music is really good--I would listen to some of these pieces on their own. 
Some reviews I've read complain about the story: at first we're presented with a generic RPG excuse plot (save the world from encroaching darkness). But its presented with a bit of humor. Later dialogue and text suggests there's something else (more psychological) going on--its kept vague. Maybe there's an element of mystery which is never explained. I didn't have any expectations story wise (consider the games that inspired it) so this didn't bother me.  
It's a short game--maybe this is good as it doesn't "overstay its welcome"--but after you defeat the final boss you're given a tool that allows you to access more of the map and discover new secrets meaning you can have more fun exploring. And some of the areas you explore doing this are just as developed as what came before, sometimes with added difficulty. 
I will admit I "moved on" from the game before I discovered every secret but I can see coming back to it and I enjoyed my time playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995382124', 'num_games_owned': 2868, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 859, 'last_played': 1373338213}
review:
The main storyline of the game was decent, if nothing special (and to actually get to the ending you had to collect every last hidden collectible in the entire game). What I'm here to talk about is the 'post-game' half of the game.

When Anodyne ends, it gives you an item to switch floor tiles, making you able to work places you couldn't before. This is done with the promise of further exploration and an entire (hidden) second half of the game. The thing is; you're meant to use this tool to exploit glitches that occur when moving outside of the maps, to get you to secret glitchy areas. This requires abusing your controls, and works about 1% of the time, essentially making the whole experience extremely frustrating.

What is equally as frustrating is the fact that so much work seemingly has gone to making these glitchy areas, with 99 doors you have to try and pass by jumping into holes that kill you at different spots of different levels, but bringing up the menu, teleport to the waypoint area, and hope you hit one of the spots that has floor tiles to land on, and is on the right side of the doors.

If this was truly meant to be optional, it would have been hidden away as secrets, not be your reward for completing the game, and it would definitely not have about as much content as the main game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202913131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 408, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1565066923}
review:
《Anodynel》一款像素风格动作冒险游戏，游戏将大地图分割成一个个小区域，玩家每探索完一个小区域，要么消灭全部敌人，要么完成机关触碰或者是物品收集后，便可以探索下一个区域。游戏中玩家需要收集卡片和钥匙，来开启特殊的大门解锁新区域。游戏某些场景还有不少有趣且颇具技巧性的解密流程，非常有意思。游戏中的战斗环节难度不大，但是BOSS战也不容易，不过游戏中有很多存档点，多试几次，通常硬扛就行。

[h1]神奇的扫帚[/h1]
游戏中主角在一开始会得到一把扫帚，也就是主角的武器了，可别小看了这把扫帚，用处可大了，除了击打敌人，我们还可以用它铲土，你说铲土有啥用，可以挡攻击，没错这个算是推箱子的变种吧，设计的很巧妙，有的场景需要交替反复铲起和放下两堆土，来开辟道路。后期可以剪刀一些加强扫帚的配件。

[h1]需要反复尝试的BOSS战[/h1]
游戏攻击机制的问题，给玩家无形中增加了不少难度，平时的小怪还好，但是攻击样式多样、血量又厚的BOSS们，就显得十分手残了，有些BOSS战设计的还挺有意思，不过无形中也增加了难度，比如红色大陆那个BOSS，就需要玩家利用尘土作为漂浮物载体，然后还要克服水流的影响，和一个想大章鱼一样的BOSS战斗。
不过游戏的BOSS战一开始难度大，多试几次一般都能过，只是浪费了时间，会影响一个3小时内通关的成就，我看那个成就达成率也不高，获得的也都是高玩吧。

[h1]充满恶意的陷阱[/h1]
游戏中的一些场景设置了各种而已满满的机关，地上的洞就不说了，注意一下就好，可是覆盖了松动土壤的洞那不是害人嘛！这种区域站久了就会掉洞里。还有没有护栏的窄道，一不留神就掉下悬崖。主角在河水里也不能久待，不然会下沉。还好这些陷阱及时不幸踩中也无太大影响，玩家也就是在本区域重生，耽误点时间罢了。不过游戏成就里有一个3小时内通关的成就，奔着这个成就取得玩家就要多加留意了。

游戏中还有一种不会攻击你但是会被你吸引跟随你并且推你的小生物，好吧，你很可爱，但是别把我往沟里推啊。。。

[h1]卡片收集[/h1]
游戏中玩家需要收集各种带有生物信息的卡片，这些卡片是推进游戏的重要道具，有些门需要收集的卡片数达到一定数量才能打开，有些BOSS需要收集卡片数量达到一定值后才会遇到。

[h1]零散的剧情叙述[/h1]
游戏中的剧情获取主要通过npc 的对话，npc可以反复对话，不过都太过零散，感觉剧情似有似无的，很是散乱，有些npc说的话也天马行空、不知所云的。有一个转红色法师袍的npc总是在关键时刻出现指引玩家，应该算是主要的npc了。

[h1]总结[/h1]
游戏还是挺不错，但是由于玩法和叙事方式，显得非常小众，而且不为人所知，游戏现在推出了2代作品，不知道销量会如何，届时也不知道会不会有更多人来了解这部作品。

review:
I'm not usually one for RPGs, but this one managed to hold my interest, so that has to be worth something.

It's not overly complicated, and whilst it is mostly fairly whimsical and silly, it does have some incredibly dark moments especially if you dwell on certain situations for too long.

People often seem to compare it to "Yume Nikki". Plus, tons of secrets!
