author: {'steamid': '76561198864927864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1551324298}
review:
Amazing game. Bought it because it was on sale and I was in the mood for a simple 8bit game. This game immediately hit me right in the nostalgia. It reminded me so much of the old LoZ game boy color games that I played as a kid. 
First off I love the characters, I love the pixelated style (and no, not all pixel styles are created equal) and I love the mood this game sets. The mechanics are simple; you fight with one weapon and you can jump. The strange characters you meet are interesting. As far as the story goes, it's kind of vague and doesn't make a ton of sense. From what I gathered from other reviews, it was intended to be that way. Kind of like it is what you make it out to be sort of thing. Personally I really enjoyed the game and the odd story. I loved the style, the mystery of everything and the random characters. The whole thing feels very imaginative/dream like. 10/10 would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977031634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1551141973}
review:
Pros:

+Charming art style
The art is of varying quality but is generally very pleasing to the eye, with a lot of texture differences between zones.
++Atmospheric Music
A good musical score that can flip flop between happy forest romps and foreboding horror.
+Intuitive, fun puzzle design
Much of the puzzles are inspired by Zelda, but that doesn't make them any less fun to solve.
+Intriguing post-game content.
There is about two hours of extra optional content after the final boss for people who like exploring and finding secrets.
+++Environmental Storytelling!
This game does a very good job at giving you a lot of pieces to work out what's going on in the Land by yourself, and doesn't insult your intelligence by spelling it all out in the end. I strongly disagree with the other reviews saying the story falls flat, and recommend players to look at things from an allegorical perspective.

Cons:
-Price compared to length
If you don't care for finding the extra secrets, the game is only about six hours long. It can be beaten in three hours if you know what you're doing. I would say get this half off as I did, there are a lot of ten dollar games that last longer.
-Enemy design
As has been said, the enemy attack patterns are very standard fair with nothing much special.
-Rough edges
There can be problems with hit detection for both being struck by enemies and landing on platforms, more noticeable in the later platforming areas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044994133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1667, 'last_played': 1551007903}
review:
[TLDR]: You probably wouldn't regret trying it There's some good moments and the game is solid all around

[How i found the game]:Saw nitro rad's video on this game... 
halfway through the video i stopped before the spoilers started rollin out
Said to myself "Hey i wonder if this game is on steam?" it was And was on sale for 50% off

i picked it up for 5$ and it was a great experience for me
There were a few lines of dialogue here and there that really spoke to my personally in ways that actually brought tears to my eyes in one circumstance ( and its not really a dialogue heavy game )

[Gameplay]: was Fantastic its basically what if a classic zelda game was stripped of all dungeon items
(Which in alot of games become completely irrelivant after the dungeon they are required for is over)
Turns out the concept is Really Solid and you go into every puzzle KNOWING you have the tools for the job on hand always

[Design]: was pretty great through most the game... some mechanics were a tiny bit clunky but nothing i couldn't handle 
Also the game has that expertly crafted Super metroid eqsue Megaman like tutorial where  They show you the elements
How they interact and why its important... All without any dialogue , Text , Hard stops in gameplay Giving you a natural learning experience and keeping you immersed

[Etc... ]: Atmospheric Music and Simple pixel art with some Visual effect overlays give this game quite an appealing look.
Excellent soundtrack to boot there wasn't a singe track i didn't like. All of the music fits the theme of the area perfectly

Combined with all the elements done so well in this game i pretty much couldn't do anything on my free time other than play it until it was done it captivated me and my mind. it gave me a distraction, another world to sink into a trance
And Thats really quiet fitting given the theme's in the game and the name of it.. its as if we are represented in the story
The player of the game the person taking a break from reality

Also it has some semi unsettling aspects too but they are subtle.
Like the game doesn't seem entirely "Right" its got this eerie sense about just the tittle screen...
the way it makes you scale the window on Boot up. Stones sitting about all over the game with extremely strange cryptic messages that don't seem to have anything to do with the place you are in

in closing: Good game unique experience  Very amusing concept.      ( i wrote this review after being up all night )

developer_response:
For what it's worth, the game does say 'Partial Controller Support" on the store page. This is due to engine limitations. Because the controller support is *Partial*, and not *Full* - which would be a lie -  I recommended a 3rd party app so you can still enjoy your playing experience. I like to think that this is a kind gesture, rather than saying something like "just refund it." I am trying to reach out with kindness.

Calling it a 'cash grab' is rude. I am not in this business to scam people. We worked very hard on this game, so people could enjoy it!

Anyways, as demonstrated by the many positive reviews and videos, the game clearly works. I encourage you to keep playing despite the problems from the partial controller support! I think you will enjoy it. 

--Update--

For what it's worth, I did find a new Controller thing for Adobe AIR, so it's possible a fix might happen.

review: I picked [b]Anodyne[/b] a few months after finishing [b]Even The Ocean[/b], and boy, I was [b][i]not[/i][/b] disappointed. [b]Anodyne[/b] has a [b]mystical air[/b] to it which clearly resembles that of a dream: there is no real direction, but you still feel like you are somehow moving forward. In that regard, the game tells a [b]story through cryptic interactions with npcs[/b] and leaves the [b]interpretation [i]entirely[/i] to the player[/b]. It's [i]chaotic[/i] in the best way, and has a [b]balanced humor-to-drama ratio[/b] overall. All of this topped with an [b][i]old school[/i] soundtrack[/b] and [b]pixel look[/b], [b]basic controls[/b] and [b]various areas to explore with plenty of enemies and obstacles[/b] to sweep away - after all, your main weapon is a [i]broom[/i]! Undoubtedly a [b]winner title[/b] for your library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054216330', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 774, 'last_played': 1561725643}
review:
[b]Anodyne[/b] ist ein Action Adventure im Pixellook.

 [h1]Gameplay[/h1]
In Anodyne ist das vorrangige Ziel meist das [b]sammeln von Karten[/b], die überall in der Umgebung verstreut sind. Manchmal bekommt man sie von NPCs, durch das besiegen von Bossen oder man findet sie in Truhen, die nicht selten in den teils kniffeligen Dungeons zu finden sind. Die Karten werden benötigt, um in der Welt von Anodyne bestimmte Tore zu öffnen, die hierfür eine bestimmte Anzahl an Karten vorraussetzen. Es ist also nicht nötig, bestimmte Karten zu besitzen.

Um verpasste Karten einzusammeln muss man nicht umständlich backtracken. Es gibt eine zentrale Anlaufstelle, von der aus man die gesamte Spielwelt erreichen kann.

[b]Kämpfen[/b] muss man in Anodyne auch, nur dass die Waffe des Helden nicht etwa ein Schwert ist, sondern ein Besen.
Mit diesem kann man Monster vermöbeln und Staub aufkehren, der für viele Mechaniken im Spiel verwendet wird. Unteranderem kann man auf einem Staubfloß Gewässer überqueren. Ebenfalls in Anodyne vorhanden sind zahlreiche Rätsel und Geschicklichkeitspassagen.

[h1]Grafik, Soundtrack[/h1]
Die Grafik von Anodyne besteht ausschließlich aus Pixelgrafik, die aus der Zeit des ersten Gameboys erinnert.
Der Sundtrack ist recht angenehmen zu hören

[h1]Zusammenfassung[/h1]
[b]Pro:[/b]
[list]
    [*] ausgeklügelte Dungeons
    [*] einfaches, aber gutes Gameplay
    [*] zentraler Anlaufpunkt, um alte Gebiete erneut zu besuchen
[/list]

[b]Kontra[/b]
[list]
    [*]Es gab nix zu bemängeln
[/list]

[b]Fazit:[/b]
Anodyne richtet sich vorallem an Action-Adventurefans, die eine gepflegte Pixelgrafik zu schätzen wissen.
Das Spiel ist zwar recht schnell durchgespielt, aber sehr abwechslungsreich. Von mir daher eine Kaufempfehlung.

review:
感触としては２Dゼルダですが、内容は鬱で不気味です。

ステージは暗い雰囲気のステージもあれば、明るい雰囲気ステージもあります。そのせいか、次に進んだステージとの雰囲気の落差が激しいので、プレイしてて不気味さを感じました。

BGMはどれもダウナーな感じですが、良いものが多いように思われます。

内容が鬱であるというのは、キャラクターのセリフや収集要素であるカードのテキストがすこし考えさせられるものであると感じたからです。

個人的に不気味で不思議な感じを楽しめるゲームが好きなので、ダークな雰囲気のゲームが好きな人や２Dゼルダが好きな人はプレイしてみてもいいかなと思います。また、上記にも述べてあるとおり、収集要素としてカードがあるので、クリア後も多少は楽しめるかと思います。

review:
HIDDEN GEM WARNING!
Anodyne is a top down 2d adventure platformer. The story is intriguing, sporting that mysterious tone, further supported by the music. Speaking of the Devil the music is top notch. Eerie tunes will haunt you throughout this wonderful adventure, setting up some great atmosphere.Starting off, you will get your main weapon, a broom, exploring what that device is capable of, in terms of utility. Later on you gain the ability of jumping, which opens up the platforming part of the game. The platforming sessions are great, resulting in a bit of challenge on some parts, but never to the point where you feel like it cheated you off of a death. I would recommend this game to everyone, even more so if you are nostalgic of 2d zelda games.

Tl;dr: It's pretty much a creepy Link's Awakening DX, buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101605281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1488220439}
review:
This is a really weird game, I like it. Gameplay is mostly based around puzzles and action using a broom as your main weapon. The story is one of those "interpretive" ideas where you get a general idea of what's going on but it's up to you to figure it all out. Which means it gains lots of theories and it's supposed to grow a kind of underground following, but honestly that kind of story concept always seemed lazy to me. 

Luckily the story does have enough of its own plot (disregarding the earthbound esque you figure out what it means storyline) to keep you interested and engaged, with a very small cast of weird friends to meet up with, a wide cast of interesting enemies, and a varied locale from a black and white town to a demonic hell hole. The puzzles are fun and engaging, if a bit confusing at times, and the action is simple but enjoyable. Music is haunting, if not very memorable, and the art style is good, but nothing amazing. If you're looking for a weird, esoteric version of LOZ then this will probably work for you, and since that's pretty much my thing, it worked for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188664927', 'num_games_owned': 1601, 'num_reviews': 385, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1534387355}
review:
[h1] Game Summary: [/h1] 
I've seen the phrasing Zelda-lite being tossed around to describe this game, and I can appreciate the concept, though you certainly don't acquire the number of items such a description would suggest.  You get a few basic boosts to your abilities, some optional equips to your primary weapon, and extensions on your health bar.  The other main component are the various cards, which does seem reminiscent of the trading cards on Steam; especially since they represent in-game sprites, many of which have random or cryptic descriptions.  Otherwise though, as you take on this top-down style adventure game with platforming and combat elements interspersed throughout, it does come off like a basic Zelda game.


[h1] Pros: [/h1] 
•	Even after you beat the game and get everything you'd normally expect to find, there's more to keep exploring for.  In the trademark style of this game, these wind up being in off-the-wall areas because you unlock an item that lets you swap tiles and go behind otherwise dead-ends and impenetrable walls.  One downside is that these sections weren't clearly defined, as many of them are extra areas you challenge for another card, but I found one or two randomly without doing the area as intended because I was blindly stumbling around to find them.
•	This is somewhat of a spoiler, but it happens fairly early on.  While exploring a pier, I came across a guy fishing, and wanting to interact with him wound up pushing him off the pier.  It developed into a whirlpool of his blood.  I didn't see myself in a mirror, but I knew I had a shocked expression on my face.  He was a random person and your character didn't say or do anything beforehand suggesting he had a beef with him, but it happens regardless.  Such a powerful moment due to its randomness and simplicity.
•	The game develops an interesting setting and world that has the character traveling across various terrains and even a few different themes.  For instance, a more pixilated area that seems to be like a torture-chamber or dungeon/maze, and a place that's completely black and white.   
•	There are a good assortment of baddies and bosses to contend with.  You also come across stuff that may or may not be an obstacle or just something unusual you have to deal with.
•	It's kind of silly, but I like that your weapon is a broom.  Even those who have theories for the game don't really give a great reason for why that'd be the case.


[h1] Cons: [/h1] 
•	This isn't a huge complaint, but I did get stuck a few times trying to figure out where to go next and what to do.  The reason it's not a huge complaint is because it's an adventure game, and without any prior experience, you would expect some uncertainty and confusion.  Especially as this isn't the type of game to hold your hand or explain things in-depth.  
•	Some areas are a bit frustrating due to how the game is designed, as you don't have many options on how you address situations.  You either platform around something or you kill an enemy in the way.  Nothing is too difficult, unless you go for secret areas, but dying is fairly common nonetheless.
•	The game is pretty short, clocking in at only a few hours.  I'd say seven or eight hours max, depending on if you refuse to resort to a guide and try to get all the achievements.  Probably not worth the full asking price, but it is a trip.


[h1] Conclusion: [/h1] 
If you go into this game expecting to find Zelda, you're going to be very caught off-guard.  The game's setting and atmosphere are far too surreal and unsettling to feel like the normally light-hearted adventure of the Nintendo classic.  Throughout most of the game, I really felt creeped out and on-edge.  It isn't the sort of game to be oozing horror, cheap jump scares, or even anything scary.  However, as I played, I never really felt comfortable, like everything was alright.  Helping to fuel that is nothing ever gets explained properly about what is going on or why things would be so fast and loose with the rules of reality.  Based on what others have said, including the developers, it seems that this is supposed to represent some form of abstraction, but what it all really means is up for the player to decide.  Personally, since so much doesn't seem to directly relate to each other amongst the different areas and NPCs you come across, I don't try to put a box around the experience.  It's random and weird, giving a great example of how to make a game that's unsettling and creepy without having to resort to tired tropes and themes.  If this game had thrown in jump scares or horror elements, I'd have bailed immediately, because it would have been far too effective with what it already manages to do without shouting boo.  I certainly recommend this game for those who like an eerie experience and don't mind ambiguity about what's really going on, because I certainly don't have a clue.  Plus, a sequel is in the works.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029280275', 'num_games_owned': 3685, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 933, 'last_played': 1516305310}
review:
I really enjoyed this game. It's got a strong Gameboy Zelda vibe to it, yet it really does its own thing. Atmosphere is good. Music is good. Surreal tone is good (if you like that sort of thing).

Where the game really starts to struggle tho is at the mid-game where the enemies and puzzles start to get very repetitive. Repetition really bogs down the gameplay. A greater variety of powerups might have gone a long way here. There are also several situations and puzzle types that rely on a level of jumping precision that this game really doesn't lend itself to. Finally, while most collectables are reasonable to find, there are quite a few "Guide Dang It!" moments in the late game if you are a completionist.

For all its clever ideas and great atmosphere, Anodyne's greatest failing is its inability to keep it all interesting and engaging after about the first 3-5 hours. If you push through, however, you'll find a very thought-provoking and well-constructed game. I'm definitely looking forward to Anodyne 2. Overall Score: 8.5/10

If this game, as an old-school top-down 2D action-adventure game, looks like something you’ll enjoy, it’s worth picking up even at all full price. If it’s something you are less familiar with, you might be better served starting with more well-known titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963358821', 'num_games_owned': 1021, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1533525980}
review:
Pretty good.  Has a good snes action adventure/rpg style that I like.  Can be frustrating at times, but worth it. 

There are a lot of secrets to find.  Some of them are not too hard to find, but others, I have to ask myself how anyone found them.  I used a guide.

I played it on windows, but I also tested the Linux version.  It doesn't run right out of the box, but I ran the install.sh file in the game folder and it ran fine after that.

I played it with a controller.  On an xbox controller, confirm would be X, cancel would be A, and menu would be Y.  In-game confirm is called C and cancel is called X, because those are the keyboard controls.  The cancel button is used for jumping and confirm is used for attack.  The controller dialog that pops up every single time the game starts is a little annoying, but the game works out of the box with my direct input controller, so I can't complain.

The hours steam reports are wrong.  I didn't spend that much time playing the game.  My in-game time says about 8 hours, but I think that's wrong too; it may have been more like 6.  I did go for, almost, full completion including most of the secrets, though.   The main campaign would certainly have taken much less time.

I also played the android version of this game, and it works ok, but I feel like a controller is kind of a must.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016913653', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1529356932}
review:
[h1]Easy to Tedious[/h1]

The game was pretty straight forward for the most part. It claims to be a Zelda-Lite and it pulls that off. There are some additions like jumping and card collecting.

[list]
[*]Would've liked to see more power ups.
[*]Early game is easy to get you acclimated, but late game just seems tedious. It's gets a little harder but just more time consuming.
[*]Left to figure out everything yourself. A couple barriers but mostly free to complete in any order as far as I can tell.
[*]The story didn’t grab me.
[*]Just felt "meh" to me.
[/list]

I did like that jumping was adding in this type of game. I think when a certain game becomes a “genre” like Zelda has then people don’t take chances because they are trying to stick to what works. There were some chances taken there. It could be that the game was aimed at a more casual and/or younger demographic. If in fact it was aimed at those demographics then it makes sense to be "liter" on puzzles and challenges and to make everything be more time consuming than punishing. Looking at it this way I can see Zelda-Lite completely. A revelation I'm having as I write the review. Anyhow...

Play it if you are really into the playstyle of NES/SNES Zelda’s, but don’t go in expecting those games. This is truely a Zelda-Lite.

[url=https://www.twitch.tv/collections/SFz4TL4fOBUhyA]If you want to get a sneak peek at Anodyne you can watch my Twitch playthrough here.[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198059125167', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1527377198}
review:
Anodyne sure is something. The story doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but it's interesting at least and the characters are entertaining enough for the most part. The graphics and sound are charming and gorgeous in their simplicity and really help build a mysterious, surreal and sometimes creepy atmosphere. 

What really stood out for me in this game though was the gameplay. It's so addicting. Sure, it's Zelda inspired but it still works very well. One thing I really liked was how there's so much to discover and explore. The combat and puzzle mechanics were creative and slick, albeit a tad simple, but it all worked great mixed in with the exploration that made me keep coming back for more. In many ways the game reminded me more of Yume Nikki than Zelda. 

There's a bit of a difficulty curve at times, but I didn't think it was too steep. There are some parts that felt frustrating, but I don't think it's a big deal in the larger scheme of things. The humor was a little... odd? at times but it wasn't too off-putting for the most part. (The writing and story really aren't anything to write home about overall)

It's a weird, dark, and bizarre game for sure, and it's probably not for everyone. It's a bit difficult to for me review; I'm sure other reviewers made excellent points that I don't really know how to articulate. The game is far from perfect, but I sure had fun playing it. 

Check it out if it's on sale and/or you'd like a game that mixes Yume Nikki and Zelda, pass if you aren't super interested.

review: Anodyne is an excellent top-down platformer adventure game, much like the old Zelda titles. You’ll fight monsters and bosses with a broom, complete platforming jumping sections and solve some puzzles. Exploring the various maps and dungeons is always interesting, while you search for cards and other collectibles in order to progress. There’s also a hub world connecting everything. Gameplay, art and music are nice. As a bonus, there’s a lot of post-game content secrets to be found, although you’ll need a guide in order to 200% the game. And also some patience. If you like those old-school games, then you can’t go wrong with this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027013569', 'num_games_owned': 888, 'num_reviews': 434, 'playtime_forever': 812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 812, 'last_played': 1525871133}
review:
Je joue sur Linux. Version Linux : moyen.

[h1]Le jeu[/h1]

Un petit jeu d'aventure, où on explore le monde avec pour toute arme notre fidèle balais. Ca commence assez gentil, mais plus on avance, plus l'ambiance devient graduellement oppressante, ce qui va bien avec l'histoire.

La musique d'ambiance est plutôt cool, les graphismes ce à quoi on s'attends avec le style 16bit. Le gameplay est standard, rien de spécial à signaler.

[h1]Rejouabilité, achievements[/h1]

Quelques achievements, mais sans guide pour la collecte des cartes par exemple, bonne chance... Il y a aussi des zones accessibles avec des glitchs, pour ceux que ça intéresse.

[h1]En bref[/h1]

Principalement axé sur son ambiance, Anodyne est un jeu d'aventure tout à fait correct. Je ne le recommande pas car il est basé sur Adobe AIR qui est une plaie sur Linux. Mais sur une autre plateforme, oui, recommandé.

[h1]GNU/Linux[/h1]

La version Linux est très bien si vous arrivez à installer Adobe AIR, qui n'est plus supporté sur Linux depuis 2011. Sur les distributions basées sur Ubuntu, c'est possible au moment où j'écris ce test (Mai 2018). J'ai terminé le jeu il y a longtemps, mais j'ai refait le test. Il existe un script bash pour des Ubuntu/Mint récentes ( https://www.noobslab.com/2015/05/adobeair-is-now-available-for-ubuntu.html ), il y a les packages de devolo ( http://update.devolo.com/linux/apt/pool/main/a/adobeair/ ), et aussi des PPA (par ex: https://launchpad.net/~andykimpe/+archive/ubuntu/adobeair )

J'ai testé les trois solutions ci-dessus car au démarrage l'écran était noir... mais après avoir testé un peu toute les touches du clavier, j'ai réalisé qu'il suffit d'appuyer sur 'c' au démarrage pour que ça continue. Après avoir réalisé ça, quelques tests plus tard, j'ai eu un écran rouge qui m'indiquait de redimensionner l'écran avec les flèches puis d'appuyer sur 'c'. Ca a l'air d'être aléatoire, la majorité du temps il n'apparait pas. Donc appuyez sur 'c', et le jeu se lancera de toutes façons.

Pour les achievements, vu que je les ai déjà, je n'ai pas pu refaire le test, mais je les avais eus sur Linux à l'époque, donc il est fort probable qu'ils fonctionnent toujours.

Une petite note, le dev semble suivre les forums, et il a fourni un SWF standalone du jeu, si vous n'arrivez pas à installer AIR. Je ne sais pas si les achivements fonctionnent avec.

OS: Linux Mint 18.3 x64, MATE edition.
Hardware : i7 7700K OC@5Ghz, Nvidia 1080GTX, 32GB ram.
Screens : Dualscreen, 1x 4K & 1x 1920x1200, un seul screen X.

review: Anodyne has a lot of very interesting stuff going on.  It takes the classic 2D Zelda format, turns it on its head and plays with the tropes.  That said, actually playing the game just winds up frustrating me with difficulty, not in the sense of, "This is a difficult challenge," but more in the sense of, "Why did that just happen?"  The game has a lot of sections which rely on top-down jumping with more precision than is really possible with the controls.  A lot of the rooms are set up in such a way that you're nearly guaranteed to be hit by an enemy, especially the first time you enter it; if that's your last hit point, then too bad.  I want to like this game a lot more than I do, because there really is a lot to love.  Just expect to go through frustration to get to those lovable bits.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075061111', 'num_games_owned': 1156, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1518812731}
review:
16.2.2018. Game #16

Well this game is… interesting.
I already played a bit of this game a couple of years ago but have never finished it until today and I am glad I did because Anodyne really hit the spot. 

[h1] A game that looks like The Legend of Zelda [/h1]

Right from the start Anodyne looks like one of the early Legend of Zelda games. It’s a 2D game, you have bird’s eye perspective, when you go to the edge of the screen it moves to the next zone and you progress by fighting enemies. You also go through dungeons, you sometimes get power ups, there is an over-world that is fun to explore and you always have a boss fight at the end of each dungeon. It’s clear what this game was based on and the game is fully aware of this and doesn’t even try to hide it.

[h1] You are a boy called Young and you must find the Brair [/h1]

So what is the game about exactly? Well… I’m not sure myself. The game clearly has a story hidden somewhere deep within it but the game wants you to work for it a figure it out. 

You play as a boy called Young. You don’t know where you are and how you got there. You aren’t scared nor confused, you are just … there. Also, you don’t speak but the NPCs have no problem talking to you. You meet a sage who tells you that you are supposed to find the Brair, and that’s the plot… basically. 

From there, you get your weapon and you set foot into this Zelda-like world to find this “Brair”.

[h1] It's dangerous to go alone. Take this... broom![/h1]

So what is young Young’s weapon? Well, here is where the game quirky humor comes to shine. See, like I said before, the game is based on Legend of Zelda games and it knows it and it also knows you know it (hopefully). Seeing how Zelda is a popular series that has been going strong for years, players expect certain things to happen in the world when playing Zelda. You have these same expectations in Anodyne and the game just loves toying with you because of them. So, instead of getting a sword, you get … a broom.

Not a magic broom, not a Nimbus 2000, a regular sweeping broom. Despite this, it works just like a sword and it even has some other uses too. During the game you can find dust balls which you can pick up with your broom and use them to progress further into the game. You can use them as a platform as an obstacle for blocking enemies and, my personal favorite, as a raft. It sounds silly, but it’s really cool and it gives the game its own unique mechanic. The game is also much easier than any Zelda game I have played. You will probably die a few times but not once did I get frustrated because each death is your own fault. Not even the bosses were that much tougher.

[h1] The game is fully aware where it takes inspiration from and enjoy toying with your expectations [/h1]

Toying with your expectations doesn’t stop there either. There are bushes that are begging to be cut down which you just can’t cut. There’s a Rock in your way and there is a clear path behind the rock? Too bad, there are no bombs in this game. Want to buy a power up or an upgrade in the game? Lucky for you the game has a merchant that sells things. The only problem is that the game doesn’t even have any currencies. You see 9 rocks where one is clearly misplaced and needs to be pushed? Too bad you can’t push things. It’s little things like that that make me smile. 
So all of this might seem bad, but the game stands on its own with its dust mechanics and it’s simple but functional combat.

[h1] Unique levels and weird locale [/h1]

What really drew me into the game is the levels, or rather the zones. Instead of having Death Mountain or Zora’s domain, this game has a haunted circus, a rundown hotel, a cave in the swamps and other bizarre locals. Being a fan of bizarre and weird worlds, I was immediately hooked.

As you go through the game and as the story “unfolds” you start to realize and question the motive of the main character Young. Where exactly is he? Why is he doing all this? Is he even a good person? It doesn’t help that the rest of the game seems to know Young better than he knows himself. About half-way through the game, the locals start getting really dark, twisted and almost morbid. 

[h1] A short experience [/h1]

The game is very short (it even has an achievement for beating it in less than 3 hours, which seems very possible) but it’s very conveniently packaged. After you clear the first area, you are free to go where you want and exploration is highly recommended. In fact, exploration is necessary since you really need to find (I think) all collectables in order to beat the game. Luckily, none of them are cryptically hidden so it wasn’t such a hassle to track them all down. Once you beat the game, you can continue exploring the world with the new power ups you have and unlock a few more collectables. 

[h1] I've had fun with this game [/h1]

So, that’s Anodyne. I know my description may not have made much sense but that’s the beauty of it. While being a very solid game, it’s fun to just wonder and create your own story about why Young is on this adventure and what do all of his adventures mean. It’s fun to find a Zelda themed area and get frustrated when you remember that you aren’t really playing a Zelda game. It’s fun to explore all the strange zones and locals. 

And that’s the final verdict. Anodyne is strange, bizarre, knows that it looks like Zelda, but most importantly, it’s a lot of fun. It may be short and you can beat it only a few hours, but it’s definitely worth your time.

Next game: Antichamber
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198075061111/recommended/219890/

[h3]If you liked my review, feel free to follow my curator group. I’m trying to review every single game in my library. Seeing and interacting with fine folks, like you, keeps my motivation up. 
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/RevAMG [/h3]

author: {'steamid': '76561197969880352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1514574268}
review:
Anodyne is a Zelda clone. Your weapon is a broom. You need to collect playing cards to progress.

It sounds familiary yet quirky - and it is - which I totally expected to enjoy.

Anodyne is not my thing.

Based on all the over reviews it must work for a lot of other people. So maybe I'm the outlier, but I was not entertained by this formula. It felt like a pointless slog most of the time.

Like most Zelda-esque games, fighting enemies in Anodyne doesn't actually matter. Sometimes you have to clear a room to progress. Sometimes there's a boss. But the vast majority you can simply ignore. There's no experience. There's not even money, whereas at least in Zelda there's usually some currency you can apply to upgrades. Instead the only possible drop is health, which you won't need if you don't fight. So the game is basically motivating you to run past all the enemies you can. When you do fight, there's literally only one move: stab with your broom. So chalk up a big negative for the combat system.

The rest of the gameplay is focused on progressing through dungeons, most of which involve collecting keys by exploring (which was ok) or navigating jumping puzzles. The puzzles were bad because they would often require precision to complete, while the controls are so far from precise as to be on another planet entirely. I can't explain why a game designer would do that. It's simply a bad decision.

The one saving grace is the bosses. They are generally well designed and tough, but in a fun way. They're pattern based, so you just need to learn their moves and then nail a good attempt. However, my enjoyment of the bosses was marred by glitches. After completing them my character got stuck on a tile in the boss room not once, not twice, but three times during my play through. It really takes the fun out of the experience and the fulfillment at beating a boss when you have to immediately do it all over again because of bad programming.

Finally, the story is incredibly weak. If it had been better it might've overcome all the other issues, but it's simply non-existent for the most part. There are [i]hints[/i] at something deeper at the very beginning and the very end, but most of the game is devoid of any larger meaning than "move from point A to point B."

I went in wanting to like Anodyne, but it was not fulfilling in any of the ways I hoped it would be. Maybe other people can enjoy this sort of thing, but it's not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995733340', 'num_games_owned': 685, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 607, 'last_played': 1515363550}
review:
This review? Honestly, just the health upgrading animation should be enough to make you buy this game. I might just have entomophobia, but man that's painful.

Whenever I see a lot of creepy RPG maker games, I feel like there's something missing that makes it so generic. Something that removes the wall between me and the game is missing. Love. I think this game loves its player. And that's why it hurts so much.

Very subversive and mind-bending, maybe a bit too on-the-nose about being subversive, but I think its heart is in the right place. I actually really had so much fun playing this game. You go around collect items and stuff, yknow the drill. Classic.

"A mantis shrimp can perceive UV light. Can you imagine seeing a wider range of colors? Maybe it'd be beautiful. Then again, we already found ways to hate each other with the colors we have."

Yeah, it might be a bit on-the-nose, lol.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132503739', 'num_games_owned': 599, 'num_reviews': 543, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1514651253}
review:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 08:41:18 + 02:04:16 (based on in game clock, 100% achievements)
[b]Grindy Achievement:[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement:[/b] Yes (3 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement:[/b] No.
[b]Developer Response:[/b] Yes (~1 month).

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Anodyne is an action game where you explore dungeons and defeat bosses. There are 6+ dungeons in the game. The "plus" referring to those dungeon-like areas without bosses.

[h1]Music[/h1]
Most (if not all) of the musics in this game give off the relaxing vibe. I really like the musics and they blend with the environments perfectly

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game uses 2D pixelated graphics. The areas look beautiful and the mappings are decent. The level designs are also good, except for some dungeon areas that are not "square shaped" which makes the map looks confusing with the area being connected to each other or not.

[h1]Story[/h1]
To be honest, i don't really get the story. At first, you're told to protect the Briar, and all you end up doing is going to dungeons for "training". There isn't much interactions for the story to clear it up (and i think the main story is only in the near beginning of the game and the near end of the game), although there are some facts written in the stones (which is scattered in the world) which holds some info of the game's setting.

[h1]The Game[/h1]
The game will start by teaching you the controls. After you finish the tutorial, you'll be moved into an area called nexus, which is a gateway that lets you to teleport to all areas easily, provided that you have opened the portal. After you finish the first dungeon with a boss, you'll be able to finish the other major dungeons in any order that you want. However, i'm having some trouble in accessing these dungeons because i don't know how to reach to some places [spoiler](i don't know that you can step on dust to travel in water)[/spoiler] until i move around between the areas a lot of times.

There isn't that many areas in the game, although i like how you can finish the dungeons in any order that you want. The bosses in the game isn't very hard either; i usually just keep on attacking the boss until it dies, without caring much about my HP (the bosses will usually die faster than me). The only exception for this is the last boss where you need to think a little to beat it. There is also one boss that's super easy that i don't really need to move in order to kill it [spoiler](the second boss in the apartment / hotel dungeon)[/spoiler].

There are also some reaction based puzzles in the game. Some of them are quite easy, but some, especially in the [spoiler]debug[/spoiler] area is quite hard that you have to retry the puzzle several times if you're not that good. This makes it worse since you have to go through a long walk to the puzzle area again if you fail. There is also a ridiculous area where you have to wait for like 2h in order to get a secret (one of the collectables in the game). Luckily it's not required to beat the game.

If you play this game thinking because you want to play some Zelda-like games, then you have to stop. This game isn't really on the same genre. Sure, you have a weapon, a few health bars, and some dungeons to explore, but that's all there is to it. There isn't any puzzle in this game that requires you to think (most of them are reaction based), and you can only utilize your main weapon to kill enemies (there isn't any additional equips for you to use, except for some weapon upgrades that can help you kill enemies easily). Most bosses can be beaten in the same way; you don't even need to remember their attack pattern. But even without that, the game itself is enjoyable-

Except for the post game content. After the game introduces the last weapon upgrade, you basically can move everywhere, including to "glitched" areas that's not supposed to exist. This poses a problem when you end up having non walkable tiles on the other side of the screen and the screen where you came from, since you'll have no other choice except by teleporting to nexus and start over from scratch. Plus, you also need to spend a very long time by going through the glitched areas to find the secret items without using a guide. Just for a measurement, it too me ~4h to finish the game for the first time and it took around 2-4h to collect the other collectables. This is not including some secret collectables that can only be obtained with a glitch since i read somewhere that you'll lose all of your collectables if you collect it.

Speaking of collectables, there are some cards and secret items that you can collect in the area. The cards are usually easy to get since they are in the treasure chests. The secret items, on the other hand, might be hard to find since you'll have to explore to all possible glitched areas with your weapon upgrade in order to find the secret areas which has the secret items in it.

Pros:
- 6+ dungeons
- Collectables
- You can finish most dungeons in any order that you want

Cons:
- Most of the bosses are too easy to kill
- Annoying "puzzle" where you have to wait for hours just to get a secret item
- "Glitched" areas can be annoying if you want to explore the map

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This is an action game where you explore dungeon and kill bosses. The game's main content is quite short, around 4 hours, which can be shortened if you're doing a speed run.

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]I were actually wondering whether i should recommend this game or not. The game might be quite expensive based on the game's play time, so you might want to think about it before buying. I only recommend it if it's discounted heavily though. If you don't really like the price, i suggest you to buy [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/342490/Shipwreck/]Shipwreck[/url] instead, which imo, is better and cheaper than this, minus the good music.[/i]

review:

The Short of it: Here, take this broom. It's dangerous to go alone. Imagine Legend of Zelda, but hella' creepy. Like Zelda inside a nightmare of a clinically depressed person lost in space. Very organic, and artsy, and unnerving to be honest. I oddly liked it.

- Controls can be just a bit clunky at times, making some difficult fights a bit frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198335439102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1021, 'last_played': 1508256896}
review:
[h1] 冒险与想象力的交汇 [/h1]
本来是抱着消减一下喜加一罪恶的心情来玩这个游戏的，不过没想到这个其貌不扬的像素游戏却给我留下了很深的印象。
整个游戏充满了meta元素，在一周目你可能不会感到很惊讶，但在游戏通关之后你才发现新的未知世界的大门向你打开了，你能去之前不能去的地方，拿到之前拿不到的东西，还有很多有趣的彩蛋。整个游戏充满着恶搞、调侃和创意，游戏的氛围也给我一种很特别的感觉。听说这个游戏当年在参加某场独立游戏比赛时只拿到了三等奖，现在我倒是很好奇前面两个游戏是什么了。PS：这个游戏的bgm也做得很不错[strike] 这年头果然做个独立游戏都得要全才 [/strike]
当然作为独立游戏，这个游戏也是有不足的，一个是游戏的难度可能对于某些手残玩家不够亲切，另外就是整个游戏的剧情部分感觉交代的不是很清楚，没有一种代入感。
总体来说我还是挺喜欢这个游戏的，就如奶牛关的一片评测说的那样，对这个游戏最恰当的一个描述词可能就是[b] 沧海遗珠 [/b]了

author: {'steamid': '76561198076536812', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1509836102}
review:
+ A lot of the game is pretty to look at, with a nice color palette and little details here and there
+ Pays homage and feels similar to Link's Awakening, including a direct reference in the first 2 minutes or so
+ The characters and dialogue are reminiscent of Earthbound in their sort of quirkiness and self-awareness
+ Lots of save points

- There is a lot of empty space, and you'll spend a lot of time just wandering around the map. The same was true of Link's Awakening to a certain degree, but it was exciting to explore Koholint Island, whereas I found Anodyne's exploration tedious.
- I only got through the first two bosses, but the dungeons are repetitive and rather dull
- There are a lot of little ways that the developers waste your time. Lots of paths that lead to nowhere, or you're given a choice between two paths, and one of them leads to a dead end while the other is the right way. And there won't be an item or something, it's just that you chose the wrong path, and now you've wasted a few seconds. This happens constantly, which is part of what makes exploration boring and frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009351113', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1509071778}
review:
I picked up Anodyne as someone who grew up in the 80s and was looking for indie games inspired by the era. I'm a programmer by trade and have been planning an indie game of my own for several years now but wanted to find some titles  of a similar style to play through for inspiration and as a way to critique my own ideas. At first glance Anodyne seems overly simplistic and I wasn't sure if I'd like it but after giving it a few hours there is far more depth here than I expected and I'm truly enjoying it.

The devs for this game are huge fans of the original 8-bit and 16-bit Nintendo (and Super Nintendo) Entertainment Systems. The clues are everywhere in subtle and no so subtle ways, like the inclusion of a certain NPC who is heavily inspired by one of Nintendo's most memorable characters (no spoilers here).

Anodyne is heavily influenced by the original 8-bit and 16-bit Zelda games. From exploring dungeons and collecting power ups, to solving puzzles and revisiting areas to explore them further once your new items have unlocked new capabilities - Anodyne plays in a very familiar fashion. But while Anodyne may have been heavily influenced by Zelda the devs have definitely crafted a unique adventure of their own here.

I've not yet finished the game but I'm curious where the story is going. The dimensional gateways and certain story elements, such as the depth of dialogue between Young and some of the eccentric characters he meets along the way, as well as certain areas I've explored with unexpectedly dark subject matter suggests an ending with a bigger punch than I could have anticipated when I first purchased the game.

Summary: Anodyne is a surprising gem of a game with great music, classic retro-styled graphics, familiar (simple) gameplay mechanics, lots of beautiful and unique regions to explore, puzzles to solve and what appears to be some deep existential subject matter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198181175874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1465428967}
review:
This is, without question, one of the most beautiful sendups of Link's Awakening available right now. What made that game appealing, both visually and sylistically, has all been brought into higher resolution, and with richer, more vivid colour palettes. 

Worst comes to worst, if atmosphere and pixel art interest you, this game is worth your time.

But I can't promise that that time will be good.

The game is unpolished. Every jump I made had me sweating because I could never tell if the distance would be enough, and enemy encounters left some rooms feeling starved for space to dodge.

But the story may be the worst of it. At best, it feels confused. At worst, what major themes the story can be recognized to have make the narrative as a whole into a poorly executed attempt at self-reflection and escapism; leading to the story reward at the end of a frustrating dungeon being a critique the act of playing video games.

But maybe it's some post-modernist crap. I mean, I definitely wanted to take a break from it all and go outside, once I was done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044332306', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1507675263}
review:
The game's very sweet, nostalgic, and creepy. It's not strictly linear, but it's also not *too* non-linear; you do have to backtrack at times, but not excesively as if you were playing a Metroid, plus you have convenient warp points. The mechanics are pretty simple while the story and art are the focus of the gameplay. It's a short game (I finished in under 8 hours and I'm a slow gamer), but it feels complete.

The only negative qualities I can think of, are 2 or 3 platforming puzzles that were a bit frustrating for me. Other than that, it's a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123545988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1515120027}
review:
2Dアクションと謎解きゲー。懐かしいドット絵グラフィック。音楽はいまひとつ…。
ストーリーはあってないようなあいまいな感じです。
主人公がコミュ障設定なのか少しほの暗い雰囲気です。が、綺麗な景色や音楽もあります。
謎解きはわりとカンタンですがアクションはなかなか歯ごたえがあり、できそうでできない感じが歯がゆくついついムキになってやってしまうような、絶妙な難易度に仕上がってると思います。
（私のような平均的なプレイヤーにとっては）

ちょっと不満だったのはアクションに失敗すると、セーブ位置関係で何度も同じところを繰り返し通らなければならない箇所がいくつかあったことです。そういう細かいところでイライラしてしまう人には向かないかもしれません。
私は8時間ほどで全クリしましたが、クリア後の要素もあってデバッグワールドで遊べます。

もう一つ、特筆すべきはなんとも味のあるテキストです。
日本語のローカライズが素晴らしく、まるで日本人が作ったかのような自然さ。
多くのレビュワーが書いているように「ゆめにっき」の影響や2Dアクションのゼルダの影響を感じますが、個人的にはテキストのほの暗くも生温かい感じが「マザー2」を思わせました。

いろいろツッコミどころや不満点もありましたが、テキストから製作者のゲームへの愛情が感じられ、やり終えた後はいいゲームだなぁ…と思ってしまいました。
ゲームにはやはり作っている人の思い出や愛情が感じられることも大切なんだなぁと思わされた作品でした。
これからもゲーム制作続けていってほしいです。次の作品にも期待しています。

author: {'steamid': '76561198075335802', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1506702640}
review:
note, this games not for everyone.  

Pros: very simple, bewildering exploration into these surreal worlds.  the characters themselves can act unpredictably, like walking by a bunch of normal npcs, but suddenly one looks over and runs after me to attack.  the world, dungeons, and puzzles are all very very connected and have shortcuts if you ever wish to backtrak.  its quite a unique experience and im glad i actually bought it.

>>> Gamplay:  the biggest draw of this gmae to me is the exploring, the dungeons, puzzles and brutal enemies wihtin are all very well doen and get hard in their own right with puzzles and mazes makign you have to think outside the box to see how the areas you are in are connected.  but aside form all that the experience of thes eplaces as a whole was the most fun for me.  if youre not exploring a dungeon, youre explring the otuside world or some area without enemies.  but all areas have plenty of paths and variety in music and play to amke them feel unique, it really helps for not getting lost as well.  the music and the off tone of the game and the text youll get from people really gives you this unsettling feel, you're made out to be a protagonist as you go off into this world and commit horrible acts, some good some not, but the game doesnt tell you if what youre doing is right or wrong.  you end up pondering it yourself and makes it a much more rmemeberable expeirence imo than say "heres the bad ending, bad things happen" or such or even consequneces.  yeah there are consequences for some certain actions but it comes off as geniune from the characters themselves. 

The asthetics pull you in well enough if you enjoy 8bit, the music is unsettling with each new unsettling place you wander through, enemies are dangerous and clever, you will end up having to use your wits a good bit to get through unscathed without being lucky.  as i've said before the game is well done in all its areas, its quite fun as well and a great experience.  however as ive also said, its not for everyone.  people in the review section hate how the puzzles require you to figure shit out rahter than be meaningless wastes of time, people argue that the events inside mean nothing, its all nonsense and that may be true but the experience of it all is still worth playing through.  people are complaining about the lack of upgrades when you can get 4x your starting health and a few upgrades to help you out and decide your mode of combat, normal broom, narrower but longer 2 sqaure reach broom, or the defensive 3 sqaures in front of you broom.  its all basic yes but its all you really need.  the game wouldnt improve by throwing in more and more gimmicks or useless upgrades.

EDIT:  there is a series on youtube that compiled the remarks and happenings of the plot and analyzed them.  it was also quite cohesive after all, the issue is simply that you would get these messages and snippets of the plot and what your character percieves and is going through every few long hours of gameplay.  not a bad choice imo but much like final fantasy tactics, when the story is so split up among hours or even days of gameplay and offtime, people will forget what is said and happening and will have a faulty recollection of the plot (example of ffta is that Marche the main character is seen as a douche for wanting his friends to come back and restore reality, he knows they cant live in this fantasy world forever, its unhealthy to hide from life's troubles inside a fantasy world, aside from that but never brought up, every other friend or family member outside the small group of frineds that was there for the opening of the book have been transformed or may have even vanished, the bullies at school became zombies for instance,  its quite unsettling to think what may have happened to your own famliy in this fnatasy world if they can even turn into monsters of all things.   but yeah most people that played the game forget the dangers of leaving your actual life behind and wnat to jump into the fantasy world.  partly the games fautl but it gave you the freedom to ignore the plot missions indefinitely, and partly the players for forgetting the plot.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198026459618', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1491633424}
review:
If you want a simple, interesting little zelda clone you can't go wrong here. Controls are simple, combat is what you'd expect from a zelda-clone, and the graphics do an excellent job of that retro feel. The story is a little too vague and relies too much on the player's inferences to be called good or even really coherent. It has a dream-like quality to it but with so few characters to really interact with and few scenes to detail what's going on, you're left guessing even through the end. 

Still, it's a solid little game and a nice enough time sink. Would love to see the developer do a follow up with more character/story to it and build on the systems here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073972405', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1500531448}
review:
+ Excellent quick travel system
+ Intriguing, beautiful world
+ Clever puzzle design
+ Rewarding variety of enemies

- Repetitive soundtrack

After playing through a few metroidvanias and other games with endless upgrades, Anodyne's simple gameplay was a breath of fresh air. You [i]can[/i] find a handful of improvements for your weapon, but they're entirely optional. What's important is learning how to read enemies' attack patterns. Monsters in general are used sparingly, often as part of the carefully-crafted puzzles. They're part of the environment, rather than mere obstacles. There's never the sense the developer is throwing enemies at you to arbitratily raise the difficulty.

Speaking of difficulty, the puzzles are exactly as hard as they should be. I only had to go looking for hints online twice in the entire game, yet I never felt like I wasn't being challenged. I can't compliment the level design enough.

While the gameplay is remniscent of classic Zelda, the writing and atmosphere reminded me of the bizarre dream exploration in Yume Nikki. Anodyne is an unusual story about relationships, and how far we're willing to go to hold on to people even when we know we can't always make them happy. At least, that's what I got out of it. It's cryptic at the best of times, but thankfully it's not just garbled nonsense. There are recurring themes and motifs that tie everything together, and what we see of the characters and their relationships is enough to stay invested over the course of the plot. Your mileage may vary, of course. Personally, I felt quite fulfilled by the ending.

TL;DR: Anyone who's willing to play along with the surrealism, or who's just in it for the puzzles, should pick up a copy of this game ASAP.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993131324', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1499793531}
review:
The game feels distinctly incomplete.  To describe this game in one word, it would be "tedious."

The good:

+Interesting exploration

+Few limits on where you can or can't go.  

The bad:

-Combat is extremely basic, few upgrades and it's easy enough for skillful play to feel unrewarding.

-The exploration is forced.  You need to get just about everything to actually beat the game.

-The story is incohesive.  The characters say arbtirary things that are not especially clever or unique, they're just odd.  Now at first I found this amusing, but it remains just odd thorughought the entire game.  I want things to connect together and make sense, and sometimes they do, but usually they do not.

Reccomendation: Skip this pile.  Pick up Undertale, Secrets of Grindea or even Earthbound instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198297929701', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 1685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1684, 'last_played': 1500460052}
review:
[h1]评测同时发布在【奶牛关】[/h1]
[url=https://cowlevel.net/article/1897447]人们常常不知道，这，也是metagame —— 镇痛 | Anodyne : 千字简评[/url]

[h1]前言[/h1]

若要用一个词描述《镇痛》，大概应该就是——
[b]沧海遗珠[/b]
这个词的意思是，有些东西极具价值，却又机缘巧合地被普遍忽略了、错过了。

[h1]整体观感[/h1]

“pixel画风”、“rogue-lite”，这些关于游戏形式的标签在独立游戏之中越发泛滥的现在，《镇痛》这一强个性、高质量，又不热衷于给自己贴标签的作品，可算是难得一见又惊艳动人。

有一类独立游戏常常会被自己或人们贴上“meta”这一标签，严格地讲，它们中的大部分其实是名不副实的。人们更像是混用了[url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breaking_the_Fourth_Wall]“破第四墙”[/url]、[url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-deprecation]“自我反讽”[/url]、[url=https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%8F%99%E8%BF%B0%E6%80%A7%E8%AF%A1%E8%AE%A1]“叙述性诡计”[/url]、[url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metagaming]“metagame”[/url]这几个标签。从标签的字面含义上看，其实，我的Steam游戏库里只有《镇痛》与《[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/420530/OneShot/]Oneshot[/url]》这两部可以算入“metagame”标签之下。
这个意义上，《镇痛》可以算是属于一种[b]珍稀[/b]的游戏门类。写下这篇文章，也算是为了纪念《镇痛》的那别具一格的个性，也纪念我那 [strike]半途而废的[/strike] 奔着100%完成度所付出过的努力。

顺便一提，《镇痛》制作人的另一款游戏《[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/265470/Even_the_Ocean/]Even the Ocean[/url]》也很有个性。我没有玩过，但主角的人设（与《镇痛》的人设风格一脉相承）给我的印象不得不说是过目不忘……

故事方面，《镇痛》的剧情很是隐晦，甚至有些意识流的味道。好在，玩家不必须弄清楚故事在讲什么也能好好玩下去。因此，剧情方面，我就不讨论也不评价了。

[h1]如何玩（表·Anodyne）[/h1]

玩法上，一看就知道《镇痛》显然属Zelda系。流程推进机制与2D的Zelda几乎一样：到达新区域 → 探索 → 攻略地下城 → 得到新道具 → 走向下一区域。同时，《镇痛》对2D Zelda系的游戏机制与游戏要素做了一些精简化，只保留了2D Zelda系游戏的精髓。例如，实际上[b]可使用道具[/b]只有一种：退魔圣剑 扫帚（可解锁两种进化形态），各区域中NPC只有一、两个。总的说，在玩法上在内容上《镇痛》与初代Zelda会比较接近，甚至似乎比初代Zelda更简洁（Steam评测区有人说是“简陋”）。另外，关于流程与故事的信息在游戏中并不很显著，玩家可能会常常陷入“莫名其妙来到了新区域不知道怎么的就过了一关接着还没准备好就通关了”这样的状态。嘛，这个过程其实并不折磨人，倒是常会让人感到迷惘。
这个到处乱碰的过程中，玩家很快会察觉游戏流程的主线索：[b]收集卡片[/b]。

所谓卡片，它们的存在是为了被收集，与剧情道具作用类似，当收集数满足一定的标准后，可以解锁一些剧情锁或地图锁（如：要见最终boss，要求主流程36张卡片全收集）。
实际游戏中卡片总数是49（见上图；全卡片图鉴：[url=http://anodyne.wikia.com/wiki/Category:Cards]Anodyne Fandom Wiki[/url]）。然而，在主流程中能通过正常手段获得的卡片，总数只有37=36+1；剩余的12张卡片要到通关以后解锁新道具Swap手环，才能通过“特殊手段”进入隐藏区域获得。

“特殊手段”指什么？
总的说，都是些meta gaming的玩法。

[h1]玩什么（里·Anodyne）[/h1]

与一周目（Zelda系冒险）时不同，post-game流程（为免与new game+混淆，我就不叫“二周目”了）中，主角解锁了神器Swap手环（作用是[b]交换地图网格块[/b]），于是，他几乎是一夜间化身成了游戏管理员，从此踏上破地图、造glitch、玩bug、撕NPC等大胆而奇妙的冒险。游戏目标变成在各个隐藏“里关卡”穿梭，集齐49张卡片。其中有些环节还必须借meta玩法才能完成，例如，有张卡片要求玩家激发[b]“场景切换glitch”[/b]才能获取。

光是文字描述也许还是有点抽象。举个有剧透的、直观一点的例子吧。
区域Woods（树林）的地图隐藏了一个post-game卡片的获取方法的提示。若不借用meta玩法，基本上不可能发现这个提示。若不介意剧透，可以点击下方链接瞄一眼地图全景。当然，被剧透了的话，惊奇感也自然会被[b]破坏[/b]；未通关请慎点。

[url=http://anodyne.wikia.com/wiki/Woods?file=Woods_map.png]Woods - Area Map - Anodyne Fandom Wiki[/url]

将bug、glitch、wiki、PC文件夹等“机制外”元素视为游戏内容的一环——而且本身不是kuso游戏——这类游戏并不多见，做得恰到好处而不矫揉造作的更是罕有。
我认为，我的游戏库中只有《镇痛》与《Oneshot》这两部够资格被称为metagame——在metagame中，玩家把玩的[b]对象[/b]不再是[b]内容[/b]（故事、任务、谜题、战役，etc.），而是[b]形式[/b]（规则、玩法、机制、贴图，etc.）。如果说通常情况下玩家是在[b]玩游戏[/b]，那meta gaming就是在[b]玩如何玩游戏[/b]。认识层次的错位与跳升，往往可以使得多数metagame给人感觉“不平凡”。虽然《镇痛》的精华多在post-game的meta部分，但是商店页面却没有标示这方面的信息。对公众忍住不提自家精华，这种做法与《[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/391540/Undertale/]Undertale[/url]》《[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/536890/Glittermitten_Grove/]Glittermitten Grove[/url]》很像，遗憾的是《镇痛》的名气远远不如此二者，因而无法借助名气在不剧透的前提下推广自己。

[h1]结语[/h1]

游戏的精华大多在post-game环节，这使得一周目的体验有些平平无奇，甚至枯燥、无聊。很多玩家（包括我 =_=）也许会因而一不留神错过了这部佳作。
试一试本作吧（记得要通关哦~），若你在追求有趣体验的话，也许会是一份意外惊喜。

Exelente titulo que nos ofrece un poco mas de 10hrs de duración.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973084271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1500526693}
review:
Really enjoying my time in the various landscapes of ANODYNE: some pastoral and charming; others, creepy and surreal. Collecting cards makes the game feel like a scavenger hunt across the varied worlds. This is giving me a much more exciting reason to explore the beautiful maps in depth (especially since the plot so far is very very very very light).
Some dialogue and texts make me wonder if there is some sort of meta story going on, but if there is, I haven't quite discovered it.

I'd say this plays like YUMI NIKKI, but it's not as "out there" and there are also jumping puzzles and light combat that I'm finding enjoyable; nothing strenuous. You can't zone out, but this isn't Super Meat Boy, either! I enjoy the way the character moves through the screen, important for these 2D games! 

But! I have a warning for parents or the sensitive: on the first day, I spent about 2 hours on the game and encountered no cursing. On my second day of playing, I was surprised to discover some R-rated language in the dialogue of some NPCs. Since the game so far had appeared extremely family-friendly (I mean, you're not even given a sword to fight with!), I was really thrown by that. It felt very out of place to me. 

But so far that's my main complaint. Overall, this game scratches the right itch for me. Need to escape for a while but still be engaged and challenged? ANODYNE's a great place to visit!
* * *
Update: While I still recommend this game, the 2nd half turned tedious and frustrating for me. After I fought the boss, I tried the new ability out, and just got frustrated some more. Some would say that means I missed most of the game. Being a bit of a completionist, that bugs me, but not as much as playing more of the game would have. So...first half: great! Second half:...hmm. YMMV.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111308315', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1498773307}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023216972', 'num_games_owned': 564, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 738, 'last_played': 1483833733}
review:
The "normal" playthrough of this game is a fairly typical puzzle-adventure with some cool mechanics. Although I found that part of the game fun and interesting as well, after the final boss is when it gets really good. In fact, if you want to do 100%, most of the game takes place after the final boss and it's like a completely different game from the "normal" playthrough. If you like games with minimal direction and a lot of exploration + discovering things for yourself, you'll love the endgame. It's like the ultimate collectathon.

In terms of story, there wasn't much. This is one of those games where the story is only hinted at and it's more about the setting and atmosphere. But it works. It's creepy, surreal, and quirky. I really liked the music and sound effects; they're slightly unsettling and really add to the atmosphere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039666431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 880, 'last_played': 1421713005}

Anodyne est assez court (6h, un peu plus pour les 100%) mais propose des environnement très éclectiques, on regrettera juste le manque de boss et le scénario très léger.

author: {'steamid': '76561198206401395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1493881881}
review: Anodyne is a good work of art. There's a great blend of tastes permeating this game's mechanics, and a lot of decisions the creative duo behind it made have given it a great soul. The puzzle solving is rewarding, the challenges aren't disrespectful of your time (excepting one particular platforming sequence in a later dungeon), and the combat doesn't reach outside of its bounds to achieve difficulty. All in all this game is a fantastic accomplishment, and a lot of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011514523', 'num_games_owned': 2039, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1494051547}
review:
Anodyne is like a bizarre, surrealist old-school Legend of Zelda game.

If you're looking for a game that expertly combines good old fashioned SNES style 2D top-down adventuring, collectibles, a little humor and more than a little spookiness, Anodyne certainly provides. Just don't expect to figure out what the hell is going on anytime soon.

review: I liked this game. It's a good Zelda-lite game. It's a tad harder than most 2D Zelda games, but it's also more forgiving with saves and checkpoints. The later platforming challenges were hard to execute from a precision standpoint, but overall I really enjoyed my time with it. The puzzles are about what you would expect from a Zelda game, even though they use drastically different mechanics. The game does a good job of teaching you as you go how the puzzles work so that when you come back to old areas you see answers to puzzles you didn't know were there. The soundtrack is really relaxing, even during Boss fights. Overall just a fun time with a fun game.

review:
Anodyne is a simple, fun experience. It's easy to compare to Earthbound, but more structurally similar to The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening, with items functioning as puzzle-solving elements within the world that you can use to advance through the otherwise non-linear game world. 

Anodyne is light on story and leaves most plot threads dangling, but it makes use of a dreamy atmosphere and an almost-otherworldly soundtrack to fill its worlds with character.

Definitely worth the buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061249750', 'num_games_owned': 1173, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1406400239}
review:
Anodyne is an excersize is surrealism with a fairly well executed Zelda-style design. There is a story to be had here, one that you'll have to both look for and make assumptions to grasp. There are rooms filled with muttering duplicates without reason, and there is a circus deep inside a cave. Your weapon of choice? A broom. 

It's engaging and exciting to see what oddities come your way throughout the game, and the aesthetics are sublime. Sound design is great, and while I'm not a huge fan of the vertical slice the game is framed in (nor some of the initial keybindings, but you can change that in the options), it creates a unique little space for one to explore and plenty of interesting perspective tricks that might not've been as effective were it presented differently. 

The gameplay can be a bit stodgy, but the dungeon design never fails to stay interesting, and the odd urban aesthetics in the later stages craft a near eldritch experience in their odd familiarity, filled with abstract shadows that chase you and bizarre conversations. It borders on dadaism, honestly. The earlier dungeons fit more standard tropes, albeit with increasingly fascinating design. The puzzles are generally simple, and never made me pause for more than a few moments until the very last few on the main path. The collectables and their puzzles tend to be far more interesting, and the farther off the beaten path you go, the more complex they become. All for what amounts to cute car!

It's not life changing, but Anodyne captures a niche space phenomenally well. Give this little guy a shot if you haven't already. It's worth it just for the creative decisions alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015152713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1050, 'last_played': 1656986218}

author: {'steamid': '76561198002124849', 'num_games_owned': 2059, 'num_reviews': 363, 'playtime_forever': 366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 366, 'last_played': 1487652817}
review:
Really not sure what to think of this game.

At first play, it's a quaint little Zelda clone where you use a broom instead of a sword.
Once you go a bit deeper, it's a depressing manifesto of the dev's psyche.
Once you beat it though, it's pretty disappointing. You'd think that with the story setup and the way that the dialogue progresses from the mid- to late portions of the game, the narrative would evolve and culminate into something worthwhile at the end.

It doesn't.

Pros:
+Decent writing (mostly)
+Good pixel art
+Good music
+Solid Gameboy-era Zelda gameplay

Cons:
-Too easy, though occasionally frustrating (not exactly challenging, though)
-Too short
-Pointless ending

If you need to waste 5 hours and 5 bucks, go for it. Definitely not worth 10. Given the default price point, I have to unfortunately rate this game "not recommended", as it caused me just as much frustration as it did joy. Not quite worth it for the narrative, not quite worth it for the gameplay. Pick it up on a really, really good sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198275002021', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1487392049}
review:
Wow, this game captures everything you love about Zelda! ... except for the "fun" part.

The overworld is twice as big as an old-school Zelda game, and ten times more empty. Just because there's a lot of space on the map doesn't mean that walking around it is "exploring." There's not much to discover, not many enemies to fight, and well over an hour in I don't understand who I am, where I am, what I'm suppoed to be doing... which would be fine, except that there's also no compelling air of mystery. I don't WANT to know those things. I don't WONDER about them. All there is is a bunch of lame "meta" jokes that would be charming if the game itself were interesting enough to get meta about it.

I'm sure it gets better if you play it longer, but why would you? It's PAINFULLY boring.

Music and graphics are legitimately great though, I'll give it that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966063004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1487358125}
review:
I bought this game based on the stellar reviews of the art, music, and story--the three things I go for in a game. This game falls short in 2/3 categories.

Art: 6/10. The vistas in the cliffs were lovely, but many of the outdoor maps left something to be desired. You can design a pixellated tree and call it a tree, or you can design a pixellated tree and it will be freaking-beautiful-how-can-one-squeeze-that-much-detail-into-a-pixellated-tree sort of pixellated tree. So while I wasn't blown away, or even mildly wowed by the art, I love bit-style games, period. But they're difficult to bring to life unless paired with a solid, captivating story.

Story: 2/10. Anodyne drops you into the game without any back story, any context of the worlds you visit or creatures you speak to, any idea of what to do, any inkling of a purpose, not matter how you might search. "That's alright," I thought, "I like open world exploratory games. This'll be fun." The difference between an exploration game and Anodyne is that if you decide not to participate in the main quest line, it's assumed there are other quests around to pique your interest. Anodyne is not only devoid of a main quest line; it is devoid of any quests at all. The closest thing I found to a quest was a talking bear that asked me if I had any berries. The game is generally light on text, and those creatures that do speak to you have no information, useless or otherwise. (Edit: Okay, I lied. There is a main quest line in which a creepy mage person (can't tell if it's male or female) tells you that you must do something to save something, a quest which your characte blindly and wordlessly accepts. It happens so quickly and so casually that I can't even remember the specifics of it all.)

Music: 8/10. The music has been the saving grace of Anodyne. They did a fantastic job creating atmosphere and differentiating one map from another. Only one song was catchy enough to get stuck in my head, but I found all the music to be very enjoyable. (Applause!)

I've seen reviews that the controls were a bit clonky. I found them to be decent at best, tolerable at worst. My only complaint is that it's extremely tough to judge where a jump will land when one jumps north or south. The amount of times I died attempting to get a feel for it over some chasms in a cave is embarassing.

Overall, this game had a lot of potential for me but ended up being a disappointment. The lack of direction left me wandering in circles across several maps trying to figure out how to progress in the game, resulting in loss of interest. Kudos to the developers for creating a cool game, but their abstract method of storytelling (giving them the benefit of the doubt here) isn't going to be for everybody.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027887874', 'num_games_owned': 1172, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1483187060}
review:
This game has a good recipe for  success, but poor level design really makes it hard to recommend. Pretty much all of the "puzzles" in the game are a fork in the road. One way leads to the gate, the other way leads to the switch to unlock said gate. You have to constantly backtrack because you either take the way with the locked gate at the end, making you backtrack to the switch, or you go the way with the switch to open the gate, in which you have to backtrack anyway to get back to the locked gate. It's pointless and annoying and the game makes you do it over and over and over and over and over and over throughout every puzzle. Why? Why? Why? Why? Why? Why? Why? Why? Why?

There are also tons of dead ends in the overworld map, and a large amount of empty spaces that serve no purpose other than to make the map bigger. The overworld maps also have gates and switches in them, and a lot of them just make no sense. There's one that's literally four connected tiles, and if you go clockwise, you run into a gate. If you go counterclockwise, you run into the switch. There are no enemies in the way, and there is absolutely nothing even in the area to collect. Why do they exist there? It's the most asinine padding ever.

This game loves to waste your time for no reason. There are other ways it wastes your time, but I've wasted enough time talking about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128945961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1480057963}
review:
First off, I would say this game is worth the $10 price tag, but ONLY if you are a Zelda fan and/or indie adventure games. Otherwise, WAIT UNTIL IT'S ON SALE!! The combat and puzzle solving elements were good, but pretty much only because it was like that of Legend of Zelda's from the various Gameboy/NES games, a few of which I have played before and loved. So only get this if you're feeling nostalgic and want to feel like playing a Zelda-like game.

I played Anodyne from start to finish, and overall was disappointed because I was expecting a lot more out of the story, when it turned out that there really wasn't much of one. You have no idea about the the world around you, your character's motive, the main villain, or any friendly NPC. Anodyne isn't even bolstered with loveable characters, since there are very few major ones and you rarely interact with them. Almost every piece of dialogue is a dumb pun or a lame ironic joke, which was endearing and cute in the beginning in small doses, but was VERY overused throughout the entirety of the game and ended up being obnoxious and empty quips.

The game tries and fails to form a backstory by inserting weird item/descriptions and strange character dialogue in an attempt to be cool and mysterious (much like the Dark Souls games do, except Dark Souls actually succeeds at doing so), but these numerous parts don't actually amount to anything except a pile of vague foreshadowing that alludes to nothing. One glaring example of this is the title of the game, which a quick Google search resulted in the definitions "not likely to provoke dissent or offense; inoffensive, often deliberately so" or "a painkilling drug or medicine." Neither of these definitions has any apparent significance to the story, characters, or setting of the game.

The game seemed cool because I like adventure games, especially those in the Zelda series, but the game seemed to lose direction the more I played it, concerning the story and the world that the creators were trying to build. This resulted in a mediocre game that I finished only because of cool monster designs, Zelda-like gameplay, and my unhealthy love of puzzles.
