review:
Do you like The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening? OK. Then play that.

Honestly, it's not terrible, but it borrows too heavily from a game that's much better than it is, and it suffers from the comparison. The biggest problem with it is that the overworld is too sparse and empty, whereas in Link's Awakening, every single screen was memorable. Finding things in Anodyne's overworld feels like combing a beach instead of being fun thing to explore in and of itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036596415', 'num_games_owned': 566, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1405120554}
review:
Recommended if you like open-ended exploration/adventure games.

If it weren't for the graphics, most of Anodyne could have been done as a ROM hack of the old GameBoy game Link's Awakening. The basic game mechanics are very close in look and feel to a Zelda game, particularly Link's Awakening. Like that game, the levels are laid out as a series of static screens which scroll when you reach the edge. The main character can move in 8 directions and attack in 4 directions, as well as jump over 1-tile sized pits and patches of spikes. The game controls are simple and responsive and best played with a gamepad or joystick.

Like most of these types of games, Anodyne can get boring at times especially if you get lost or stuck at a point where you don't know what to do next. There's no leveling up or even an economy in this game so if you don't know what to do next or where to go, then you are pretty much going to be stuck wandering around aimlessly with nothing to show for your time until you get back on track. Fortunately the game has a central "hub" world with lots of warp points which makes it relatively painless to navigate from place to place. Additionally there is a good auto-map feature to reduce backtracking, and each of the warp points has a red gem above it which lights up when you have gathered all of the quest items within a given area, so you won't spend time needlessly re-exploing a region if there's nothing else to find.

The core experience consists of exploring puzzle-filled dungeons in search of treasure chests containing "cards" which are used to open up numbered gates which block off different areas of the overworld. Each gate requires you to have a certain number of cards in your collection before it will open. You explore dungeons to get cards, and you use cards to access new parts of the overworld so you can access more dungeons and hence more cards, etc. A few of the dungeons have boss fights as well.

Combat is not as frequent or as intense as in a zelda game - the enemies are mostly slow moving, fairly passive, and come in small numbers. Later in the game there are a few challenging sections, but for the most part enemies are essentially "obstacles you can kill". They do however factor into many of the dungeon puzzles in interesting ways.

Within the dungeons, progress from room to room usually requires some combination of defeating all the enemies in a room to lower a gate, using a key to open a door, or solving a puzzle to remove some obstacle.
Unlike a Zelda game, Anodyne has very few treasures or special items to expand your abilities. Instead, puzzles are solved with the standard ability set and whatever is in the envirionment. Most puzzles involve devising ingenious ways to trigger multiple pressure plates at the same time, while other puzzles require precision jumping and are essentially top-down platforming. I have to give the designer a lot of credit here as the level layouts and puzzles are really very well done and better than most of what you see in the zelda series. One puzzle involves chasing giant silverfish creatures, which retreat from you when you cross their line of sight, onto pressure plates. The silverfish change their facing by 90 degrees at regular intervals, and you have to make sure to chase them in the right direction lest they be driven into spikes or full down a pit. I was reminded of sneaking past groups of guards in the Metal Gear games, except in this case instead of trying to sneak through an area undetected, you are sneaking around to ensure that you will be detected at the exact right place and time. Another creature-based puzzle reminded me of the Dreamcast game Chu Chu Rocket, and involves toggling a switch to raise and lower obstacles within a maze-like area so that a giant rat will pass over a pressure plate. Upon bumping into an obstacle, the rat will turn 90 degrees and keep moving forward. The trick is to time the raising and lowering of obstacles so that the rat turns in the direction you want it to go and doesn't run off to its own destruction. Other types of puzzles involve leaping from moving platforms, riding rafts made out of dust, or luring armored creatures into the path of turret fire so that you can use them as shields. Conspicuously (thankfully) absent are puzzles where you have to push blocks around, pull a series of levers in a specific order, or toggle a timed switch and then run through an obstacle course before the timer runs out.

Visually, the game is 8-bit style pixel art but with a considerably expanded color palette. The scenery is varied from area to area and very well done. Music is minimal and perfect in that it adds to the atmosphere but does not intrude. Sound effects are very zelda-ish, with plenty of audio cues when you discover something or solve a puzzle or anything along those lines.

The overall theme and story was incomprehensible to me. None of the characters or settings fit together in a way that I could understand, and the overall feeling of the game is less like the exploration of another world and more like wandering through a dream. Whether the creator was attempting at some kind of post-modern symbolism with all of the elements in the game or was going for literal surrealism, I don't know. It all went over my head but I will say that the mood created by the various locations and characters was interesting in its own right even if it didn't end up amounting to much of anything (at least to me).

Upon completion of the main quest you are given a special ability which makes it possible to explore previously inaccessible areas of the map and collect additional cards. I didn't bother with this but for completionists it's nice that there's some additional content there.

Overall a positive experience and a good contemplative sort of game to play when you don't have the energy for a faster paced game, nor the attention span for an RPG. It's the rare sort of comfort-food game that you can settle into and play in a relaxed state of mind.

review:
箱○PADでプレイ　クリアまで６時間

author: {'steamid': '76561197972745621', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1404534013}
review:
Anodyne is pretty much Zelda: A Link To The Past.
It plays the same and it feels the same. Thoug, it has it's own art style and graphics, it's own battle system and enemies, and another story of course.
This makes Anodyne a complete different game from Zelda, while it will guarantee nostalgia and fun.

The screen size is a bit weird in the beginning, because Anodyne is also availabe on Android and iOS and is a simple crossover with no big optimizations, at least not for the user to see.
It still plays in full screen and it is easy to get used to the screen format after some time.

The story itself is a creepy pile of nightmares, and I have yet to find out the subtle messege, the game seems to deliver.
The surface of the story is easy too follow, so even if you're like me and need some time to understand things (duh!), you will have a good time with it.

7 out of 10 points for this well made game with much love put into it.
I highly recommend to check it out.

review:
Anodyne is an incredible experience!
Anybody who enjoys classic Zelda-style games is likely to enjoy Anodyne as well. The controls are clean, responsive. The true plot of the game is beyond obscure, but offers countless deep insites for everybody, depending on their own modes of cognition. The music is discordant and unnerving; but beautiful, fantastical.
Many of the game's post-game secrets are likely impossible to find without some type of online guide for assistance. Especially one (I recommend saving it for last) where the player must enter an area and allow the game to sit untouched for approximately two hours. Yes, two hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028635556', 'num_games_owned': 1079, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1496609322}
review:
Anodyne is a Retro Action/Adventure/Puzzle game. The dungeon design is phenomenal, the gameplay is exciting, and the soundtrack is superb. The game is akin to The Legend of Zelda: Oracle of Seasons/Time. The game refrences many times the games in which it is emulating and does so in a whitty way that makes you laugh and reflect on the times spent in older games. If you enjoy Retro Action/Adventure/Puzzle games I would recommend picking this up and playing through it as you will not be dissapointed.

Pros
- Soundtrack
- Retro Style
- Challenging Puzzles
- Great Map system

Cons
- Confusing Controller Support
- The Controls are dated because it is trying to emulate gameplay that of a Gameboy game.

It has been a long time since I have needed to check out a walkthrough to figure out where I was. I consider that a "Pro" in my book but it could be a "Con" to others. You won't need a walkthrough to beat the game, it was just a little bit useful when I got stuck trying to find the next dungeon.

I would give the game a 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197979742265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1404060858}

author: {'steamid': '76561198066269351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 463, 'last_played': 1404312520}
review: A great game done in a 16-bit overhead action RPG style. It has an insteresting plot, one that isn't spelled out to you, but that you have to work at. author: {'steamid': '76561198041984970', 'num_games_owned': 1266, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1403975129}
review:
As far as "heavily influenced by The Legend of Zelda indie retro pixelly meta games" go, this one is pretty good. Sure, there are flaws (platforming requiring pixel-perfect timing and execution may not have been an overall good idea in a top-down game for instance), but the game keeps on being interesting until the end with enough extra content to go back for more.

The metaphorical layer may fly over many heads or just be forgettable/hard to relate to but at least it isn't shoved into one's face every so often. Expect a good four to five hours for a regular playthrough and double that for the extra mile (bonus items, achievements and whatnot).

author: {'steamid': '76561198014931005', 'num_games_owned': 803, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1400629258}
review:
I played all the way to the end of this game, and I still don't know what it's about, yet I am entirely okay with this.  The game captures this half-awake dream logic where you aren't quite sure what you're trying to do but you know it's very important.  

When describing this game, I am inclined to contrast it with the average violent FPS; the violence is superficially disturbing, but the repetetive motions and reflex-based action is relaxing.  This game is the opposite, superficially relaxing yet on a deeper level it is vaguely unsettling.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198136678317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1403320163}
review: While the dialogue can be excessively ambiguous, the gameplay is decent 16-bit fare.  The multiple dungeons offer a moderate challenge and there are some nice secret items and easter eggs.  Finding the next places to go after starting the windmill was unnecessarily difficult.  I did like the music and retro graphics and the game was satisfying, overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995873046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1404648430}
review:
Il s'agit d'un Zelda-like qui m'a séduit par ses graphismes et sa bande son. On est plongé dans une aventure remplie de monstres et de dongeons dès le début. L'histoire est très basique mais efficace. Pas besoin d'en faire des tonnes pour ce genre de jeu.

Cependant, la durée de vie est relativement courte. Tout dépend si vous aimez explorer et parler à l'ensemble des PNJ. En moyenne, il se termine entre trois et cinq heures.
Les énigmes sont très simples à résoudre voire inexistantes. L'aventure consiste principalement à explorer les maps et à tuer des mobs.
La maniabilité n'est pas évidente lors de certains passages. Ou alors c'est moi qui galère avec la perspective du jeu... De plus, quelques bugs font leur apparition de temps en temps.

Au final, Anodyne se rapproche plus d'un jeu sur navigateur ou sur smartphone (d'ailleurs il est disponible sous Android). L'univers est sympa mais sans plus. Je vous le conseille mais en promotion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001458742', 'num_games_owned': 882, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1406518990}
review:
My full review is available at http://www.danilopianini.org/anodyne along with screenshots and a guide on how to run the game and how to configure a gamepad under Linux.
Steam does not allow me to copy the full review here (too little space), so here are the conclusions.

Conclusion
Anodyne is a below average game, and I do not recommend it. Authors are probably much more creative artists than game designers. The atmosphere of the game is nice, but it is technically too below the threshold of niceness, and the gameplay is not innovative nor addictive. If you find it for a very convenient price may be worth the money, but for sure I would never ever spend $9.99 to buy it at full price on Steam.

Final rate: 4/10.

How much is worth™: ~1 Euro.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053339406', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1539190910}
review:
This is by far the best indie adventure RPG I've ever played. It is heavily derivative of top-down Zelda games like A Link to the Past, so fans of Zelda and Zelda-like games will enjoy Anodyne.


[b]Gameplay[/b]

Anodyne's controls are very well-designed. The fact that the game is controlled by a grand total of seven buttons (arrows, select/attack, back/jump, and menu) is an excellent design choice: far too often have I played games with separate buttons for every tool or weapon or action, or so many items that additional controls are needed to cycle through them. The menu very rarely has to be used to play the game, only needed to equip the occasional broom upgrade.

The card system is cute and unique, with each card having a funny little quote about the featured character. NPC and enemy design is well done; the sprites are simple and fit the aesthetic of the game, and the AI, while sometimes frustrating, works very well.

Level design, while not exceptionally innovative, is well-thought-out and well-executed, although a compass item for dungeons would be helpful for keeping track of what went where in previous rooms. The overworld is expansive and elaborate, with intricate, winding pathways in some areas and wide, open expanses in others. Again, the menu map could use some improvements, such as region labels, but it may just be a design choice.


[b]Aesthetics[/b]

Anodyne's 16-bit style is the perfect fit for what it is, and the idea of a Zelda-like game with modern and surrealist twists is certainly charming. The sprites and tileset are all well-drawn and aesthetically fitting, and the selective use of lighting and effects in some areas of the game is a small yet powerful touch.

One of the best parts of Anodyne is its music. The music is calm and distant, yet drives the gameplay in incredible ways. The player cannot help but nod along to the groovy, eccentric beats and melodies of the Hotel, the somber, melodic sways of the Temple, or the hesitant, ominous notes of the Cavern as they roam the halls and corridors and solve the grand puzzles contained within each unique dungeon.


[b]Cons[/b]

While overall a fantastic game, it could use a bit more in the side quest department, as the game, while nonlinear in layout, is fairly linear in terms of objective.

The bosses, while generally a bit tricky on the first or second try, are overall fairly easy and simple, without much variety in fight style (dodge its attacks, strike strike strike, wait for its anger phase to pass, rinse and repeat until dead).

There is not much incentive to stay alive in the game. Death means being sent back to the last checkpoint, which in a dungeon can be fairly common. Checkpoints are easy to find and easy to use, and saving at a different checkpoint from the previous one fully heals the player, which seems a bit cheap. There is no currency to be lost, and dying does not reset progress, just position: any items collected will stay collected after death, and saving is only really needed when quitting, as there is no volatile progress in need of saving.


[b]In Conclusion[/b]

If you are a fan of Zelda-like games and have 10 bucks to spare, give the game a go. As with any Steam game, however, waiting for a discount is probably the best course of action, as the $5 I bought the game for was the perfect price for the game in my opinion (but then again, I don't like paying for things, so there's that).

--
P~M

author: {'steamid': '76561198056468609', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1583624957}
review:
I'm not sure how I would categorize this game. Adventure? Surreal? Psychological? I simply can't decide.

But that's not important. Not really.

This is a game that makes you think. About life, about dreams. You play Young, a man whose story I am not privy to; but, like the kind of game it is, this, at the moment, is unimportant. I am interested; that is all that is really needed.

The gameplay, as you could gather from the description, is much like Zelda: A Link to the Past. It is simple, dungeon filled, puzzle-ridden fun. You wander the land in search of keys, cards, and items.

Scattered around the land are signs. Some are faded; some simply state thoughts.

Thoughts like "I think you are reading a rock because you don't have any friends."

You will meet interesting people along the way. Some will have something to say. Some will not.

I have not finished this game yet, but I look forward to it; and when I do, perhaps, I will write another review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076219837', 'num_games_owned': 3111, 'num_reviews': 294, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1502332918}
review:
Un juego interesante sin duda, es muy similar al primer zelda o a los zeldas de Gameboy en terminos de jugabilidad(no es algo necesariamente malo si te gusta el genero); la historia , la ambientacion y la musica son raros y creepys, pero en el buen sentido.

Lo bueno:
+Exelente ambientacion.
+Recompenza la exploracion.
+Es barato.
+Tiene un buen sentido del humor
+Muchas referencias freaky si te gustan los rpgs y la ciencia ficcion.

Lo malo:
-En los puzzle de saltar es muy frustrante.
-Los boss no son dificiles, la mayoria consta de encontrar el lugar ciego donde no pueden atacarte.
-Un sistema de checkpoints no muy bueno.


Personalmente le doy un 7/10 es un buen juego pero tiene sus fallos que no te permiten disfrutarlo plenamente

author: {'steamid': '76561198025723079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1216, 'last_played': 1549085347}
review:
A top-down adventure game like The Legend of Zelda, but with a darker and more mysterious atmosphere and a lot of hidden content at the end. For $10, I was really happy with what I got out of this game. It's a pretty solid adventure game, but what really fascinated me was the stuff you can find if you poke around after you beat the game. It's hard to say more about it, really. The only downside is that if you're hoping for some kind of deeper meaning to the story and the darkness that permeates it, well...you're not going to get one, and that's a shame, I think, because it feels like there should be something.
I really enjoyed it anyway, though, so don't let that dissuade you too much. I definitely feel like I got my money's worth, I can say that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967992446', 'num_games_owned': 1178, 'num_reviews': 543, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1402069102}
review:
It's definitely a nice, well-detailed game exploring the subconscious thoughts of Young, the main character. If it were just that, I would definitely recommend this without a second thought.

However, when the game gives up on providing even the basest amount of a narrative, tells you to 'just fetch these 36 cards, then we'll let you finish the game', and starts throwing out some of the most irritating jumping puzzles I've seen in a while, I kind of start thinking about how much better this would be as a novel. Mainly because it's undesirable and almost impossible to implement a jumping puzzle in a novel.

It's a very narrow 'not recommended', because there were more jumping puzzles that were irritating than there was crazy shit to justify continuing to play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992536847', 'num_games_owned': 1969, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1478840747}
review:
Anodyne is a top-down action/adventure game largely drawing from the SNES/Game Boy type of Legend of Zelda games for inspiration. You move between individual screens both in overworld and in dungeons, and fight enemies and solve puzzles in order to unlock new items which allow you to proceed.

Anodyne is a rather charming, laid back game, but it didn't leave any particularly lasting impression on me. It was a nice throwback to a style of game which I once enjoyed, is a little self-aware but not annoyingly so, but the story seemed secondary to everything else and was more there to string together a series of set-pieces. The music was quite good.

It's alright. If you enjoyed Link to the Past or Link's Awakening back in the day, it's worth a look, although moreso on sale when you can.

review: It's a fun throwback to games like Oracle of Ages/Seasons but none of it feels fun or memorable. It tries to have some hint of a horror game with the abstract dialogue and storytelling, but it misses the mark due to the fact that sometimes it will try to be "funny" which fails to be charming in any sense. The movement and buttons work, but early on a jump mechanic is introduced that just does not work most of the time, and can just be downright frustrating when they require you to do fairly precise jumps. If you're really interested in it, try and get it for dirt cheap otherwise I'd pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056106380', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1091, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1091, 'last_played': 1388900105}
review:
Anodyne has a great atmosphere and decent gameplay, but its slow pace will be off-putting to many players.

What was awesome:
As I said above, the atmosphere was wonderful. The music really sets the tone the developer wanted and the pixel art was beautifully done. I also enjoyed the diversity between the worlds you explore.

What was okay:
The mechanics the game supplies you feel fresh, but leave you feeling over-prepared in the often empty environment. The ambiguous storyline may be a deal-break for some, so know what to expect before you purchase the game.

What was bad:
Your initial visit to each world is exciting, but the backtracking gets old. The problem is that Anodyne never enthralls the player enough to want to stick around. Just when you start to get immersed in a boss battle or a puzzle, the game decides to slow down.

If you like games that focus on exploration and have the patience it takes to explore the entire game, give Anodyne a chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040985268', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1400664564}
review:
Игра шикарная, но хочу сразу отметить, что она для узкого круга людей. Не стану советовать ее тем, кто не испытывает теплых чувств к играм прошлого поколенния. 

Так же не советую играть в нее без геймпада.

Теперь о приятном. Игра просто затягивает своей, на первый взгляд, простотой и отказывается отпускать долгие часы. Игра, которая возвращает тебя в прошлое. Помимо теплых чувств, игра предоставляет нам очень насыщенный геймплей и много головоломок с ребусами. 

Пройти игру полностью - далеко не из самых простых задач. Подумать и попотеть тут точно придется.

Великолепная игра, 10 из 10 для игры подобного жанра.

review:
見下ろし型の探索アクション。画面端に行くとエリアが切り替わるタイプ。
森、町、寺院など複数のフィールド、ダンジョンは丁寧に構成されており、美しいドット絵マップチップとあいまって、十分に探索を楽しめる。BGMもとても良い。ただ、ゼルダ風とは言われるけども謎解きの幅はさほど広くはない。
難易度は易しいほうだと思う。時々難所はあれども何回かチャレンジすれば抜けられる程度だし、ともすればライフを上げてゴリ押しもできる。
一見穏やかで静かだけども、狂気をはらんでいるかのような悪夢じみた世界観も特徴的。雰囲気を崩さない優れた日本語訳のおかげで、その面白さは余すところなく味わえると思う。

author: {'steamid': '76561197998754194', 'num_games_owned': 1111, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1448862485}
review:
Not going to rehash when other reviews will state the obvious. Not a perfect game, but at least a 7.5 as the meta score indicates.

If you liked Link's Awakening you might want to check this out.

My only gripes are that there is little direction, but the early Zelda games were like that as well, and I feel that there were too many screens with nothing to do.  Yes, Link's Awakening had you trudging along, but I feel Anodyne could have had less treking between places, and because of the hollow nature, I felt my time was being wasted for no reason.

I don't know if this was to add to the mystery, or to kind of feel empty on purpose, but without a decent waypoint marker, I felt lost and I was worried I was missing something the entire time I was playing.

Have not completed it yet, but I plan to keep playing.  Might help to have a map or something on your tablet or phone, so you can have a bit of "security" while you go.

Is it worth 10 bucks? I dunno, that is on you.  I think I got it in a bundle, and I am not disatisfied at all.  I have very little to complain about, and I appreciate the throwback feel to it.

Again, if you liked Link's Awakening, you will probably enjoy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130010819', 'num_games_owned': 1416, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1399764587}
review:
Un petit jeu bien sympathique qui vous promet quelques bonnes heures de détentes si vous vous le procurez.

Anodyne est un jeu dont le gameplay et le style n'est certe pas nouveau mais qui as le mèrite d'être très bien travaillé et agréable à découvrir au fil de votre aventure pixélisé.
En effet ce petit Zelda-like possède un univers intéressant et riche de surcroit. Vous aurez autant l'occasion de vous promenez dans une bucolique forêt, que d'explorer de sombre cavernes, tout en faisant un détour par un labyrinthe original, un grand gratte-ciel et pourquoi pas une balade sur la rivière. Les créatures rencontrés au cours de votre périple sont également très variés et de nombreux boss bien différents vous donnerons peut-être du fil à retordre.
Un élement original dans ce jeu : votre arme. En effet celle-ci est loin d'être une banale épée sacré des Dieux que l'on retrouve dans tout bon jeu du genre. Non dans ce jeu vous serez armé d'un balais. Pourquoi un balais me direz-vous ? Eh bien pourquoi pas! Vous devrez donc partir explorer ce monde dangereux armé de cette seule arme qui, bien évidement, pourra être améliorer avec le temps. Ce balais vous permettra également d'utiliser la poussière comme principal élement de gameplay.
Un autre élement intéressant et celui de devoir collecter et débloquer des cartes indispensable pour accéder à la zone finale du jeu. Et des cartes supplèmentaires (bonus) peuvent être obtenus pour les joueurs souhaitant finir le jeu à 100%.
Enfin pour terminer un petit mot sur le style graphique et sonore du jeu. Graphiquement le jeu est très bien fait (à partir du moment ou l'on apprécie ce style pixélisée) et la bande son sans très grande prétention s'intégre parfaitement aux environnements et se laissera écouter sans problèmes.

Je pense donc que la diversité des environnements proposés, le bestiaire bien étoffé ainsi que le gameplay utilisant l'action du balai sur la poussière rendent ce jeu fort sympathique à jouer pour toute personne désireuse de faire son acquisition. 
Donc à toi qui regarde la page de ce jeu et qui se renseigne parmis les commentaires, avec l'hésitation de l'acheter. J'éspère que mon évaluation t'aura été utile et te permettras de faire ton choix plus simplement ^^

author: {'steamid': '76561198102492245', 'num_games_owned': 490, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1407032220}
review: When I first heard about this game on the Humble Bundle, I was a bit confused. How much can you get away with with the main character's weapon being a broom. Apparently a lot. From the very beginning, your loyal companion travels from a deranged fetus to the depths of space. The gameplay is always changing, creating new uses for old tools as puzzles and action alike keep the game alive. It is well worth the 100% achievements' time (which I have yet to earn). I will continue to play and enjoy this little indie RPG, from its gameplay to its story. 5 stars, more if possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043091668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1398573270}
review:
This is for all of the people who are calling this game a Zelda rip-off:

Look, I understand where you're coming from.  At many times I would see something in the game and go "OH, really showing your roots there Anodyne, might as well just call your last boss Ganon and slap on a green hat..."  but then, I did something that really helped me appreciate the game, and games in general, for that matter.  I stopped evaluating it with respect to other games.  I considered it by itself.  

The art style is beautiful, and it's not fair to say that just because other games have succeeded using a pixel art aesthetic that Anodyne is just riding their coattails.  Is it true?  Maybe.  Is is a fair criticism?  No.  It's really not.  Look at the game again and tell me it isn't beautiful.  I spent so much time in the world of Anodyne not because I miss my old Link's Awaknening game, but because it was a world in which I truly enjoyed to be.  

So, the moral of the story is this:  you can tell me that the game lacked meaning, or didn't appeal to you, or that you didn't like the art style or humor or direction or pacing or any other legitimate complaint.  Just at least give it the credit to evaluate it by its OWN merits.

The platforming is fun and challenging, the myriad of ways in which the designers have you exploring the broom mechanic is brilliant, the characters are quirky and fun, the world is gorgeous, and I truly enjoyed every part of this game.  I would recommend this game a thousand times over.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971255616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1369473525}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001213715', 'num_games_owned': 927, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 863, 'last_played': 1398014489}
review:
Тёплое ламповое приключение "Anodyne" как будто заключает вас в обьятья старенького Game Boy Color вырваться из которых не рассчитывайте ближайшие часиков эдак 5, и то если вы знаете о "Legend of Zelda" не понаслышке и сноровка былых дней не успела атрофироваться. Игра если ставить её рядышком с вышеупомянутым колоссом на котором находится  весь action_adventure таки покажется мелковатой в связи с чем игровой ачивмент "наваляй им вcем за 3 часа" это оправдывает. Но не надейтесь на этой в первый раз :) Выход к финалу распологается едва ли не на старте но вот незадача - циферки 37 на дверцах.

В этих цифрах укрывается дальнейший концепт собирайки внутри предложенного нам игрового пространства. Вам необходимо собрать 37 артефактов-карточек спрятанных в различных точках мира, эта нужда заставит вас увидеть практически каждый закоулок будь то классическая пещера вкупе со сталактитами или некое подобие подпространства с голографическими проекциями разумной жизни. Исследовать мир очень интересно, вольная  и открытая человеческая фантазия по прежнему является обителем для игр подобной этой, диалоги между в основном статическими персонажами обновляемы, многочисленны и конечно-же любопытны. Ни одной избитой шаблонной "я конечно бы мог но мне нужно что бы ты сделал это.." впрочем в этом нет необходимости за полной отсутствии квестовой системы. Игра не нуждается ни в чём подобном предлагая чистый и незапятнаный адвенчурный дух классических историй о противостоянии стихий. О трудностях. Тягчайших следов насилия над моим думательным органом замечено не было что позволяет вывести заключении об упрощении неизменной атрибутики подобных игр  - пазлов на уровне youtube check. Зато будьте готовы к акробатике на уровне мясо-парня как только ваш герой научится прыгать, вот здесь с не любителей быстро нажимать кнопки стечёт 7 потов. И остаётся только порадоваться о заботливо оставленных во всех ключевых местах точек сохранения.

Стоит отметить что игра располагает впечатляющим резервом пост-плея предлагая собрать ещё 11 карточек для ачивмента, вот где я преллагаю замазать корректором мой опус про отсутствие ребусов в угоду ловкости. Некоторые решения и даже более - целые секретные миры очень неочевидны и поднимут из памяти полный перечень разговорных заклинаний и уйму потраченного времени что приведёт вас в итоге к одному из игровых гайдов. Таким образом игра сумела угодить сразу обеим общинам оценивающим в приключении суть атмосферы или тернистой запутаницы.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010970704', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1397667316}
review:
This is what you get when you mix the gameplay of the 2D Zeldas with the surrealness of something like EarthBound. I wasn't expecting much going in, but it ended up being enjoyable by the end of it. (Now if only we could open that 50-card door...)

Anodyne has some strong points and good moments that I won't spoil here. It's worth the asking price if you're a fan of the 2D Zeldas, but it needs some polish to be truly *great*.

For example, when first running the game it asked me to adjust the window's size with the arrow keys (what game does this?), which couldn't even be held down to change the size and then proved to be completely useless when I could just change the settings to presets in the menu later. I understand this was originally made in Flash but the PC port should be more standardized with the resolution and other options.

There's quite a few dead-ends that *look* meaningful, but are really nothing of use and that makes the world feel more empty than it should be. Also the overworld could have been much more interesting but instead is just a bunch of mostly arbitrarily-placed portals to the different levels, of which have no labels to identify them aside from the small screenshot of the area (heck, even the signs in the levels are worn away and as such don't tell you where you're going).

My other critique would be that the pacing/story should be stronger. Finding the protagonist's signature broom is simply a plain chest in a plain room. The item itself is hilarious because there's nothing special about it and yet it's the weapon for the whole game, but the moment of getting it shouldn't have been so plain.

Overall, Anodyne is fairly imprssive considering it was made in 10 months by 2 developers, but it could have used more polish to really stand out as something greater than a Zelda-inspired dungeon-crawler.

review:
This is a game that has a lot of promise, but ultimately falls flat. It's delightfully atmospheric and the game's creators are masters of tone, making clever use of classic visuals and music to evoke feeling very well. However, gameplay quickly grows repetitive, and the exploration is much more confined than the games it was clearly inspired by, such as the Legend of Zelda series. The story is bare-bones yet still interesting, with interesting moments woven into the gameplay, such as attempting to talk to a fisherman but ending up accidentally murdering him because the game makes you attack instead, resulting in a bloody whirlpool in the ocean.

The game ultimately feels more like a rough draft or a demo of a much more fascinating, fully fleshed out game. I wish I could like this more than I do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068294296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1396199799}
review:
Event though I finished the game with all the cards and *almost* all the achievements it left me feeling empty. The 8 / 16 bits graphic style is great. The music is ok for the most part. The levels are all fun and somewhat frustraiting, but not enough to make you rage quit in the middle of the game. However none of that is enough to counter the biggest down of this piece: its complete lack of story, or should I say, its completly lack of sense.

Don't get me wrong, a game doesn't require to have any profound meaning to be entertaining, but this one is just too much.
The zones or levels have no relation between them. It's as if they were a bunch of levels from different games put together. Young (the main character) just appears in this word for some unknown reason. It seems that he might be dreaming but you have nothing to expand this theory.
In most parts of the game the NPCs present you with filosophical issues, but all of the dialogs are void and empty and provide nothing that your mind can "munch" into, failing to give any "deepness" to game. It's almost if the game was designed so that only the developers can fully understand it.
And most important, for start to end, you are left with the unanswered question of "what is this game about?"

author: {'steamid': '76561198019205444', 'num_games_owned': 4251, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1482018417}
review:
This is a top down action adventure game ala the original Zelda or more specifically the game feels like Zelda: Link's Awakening with the simple color pallet, and music. The screen doesn't scroll. When you get to the edge, you go into a new screen, just like Zelda. Its very simple, with an attack button, movement buttons and a menu button. 

It has simple combat with a good variety of enemies, but there are also good puzzles that feel unique to this game. Things like using a broom to collect dust to place that dust to block things. Again, its very simple and easy. There is no hand holding with this game and you are free to figure things out yourself, BUT when new things are introduced they will bluntly tell you yes you can do this. Such as when you attack dust, it tells you, you've collected dust, attack again to place the dust. It will spoon feed you new things as most good games do, but it doesn't force you to do several tutorials. Once to test a new skill and that's it. The game lets you loose. It doesn't feel like you'll get lost, areas are pretty confined and you have a Zelda 1 like map, there are portals that let you quick travel.

Like all Zelda games, there are keys that you'll need. Not just normal keys that open most locked doors, but specific keys to enter new areas. If that wasn't enough, you'll be collecting enemy cards. Enough of these cards will unlock specific gates with numbers on them. Along the way, you'll also find fairies or red insects that will not only fill your health, but also increase your health overall.

The atmosphere of the game is very surreal or creepy, which is awesome, its a different flavor to Zelda that makes it feel unique. You're a janitor in a dark, surreal world. In fact, I think the game is trying to subtly hypnotize you with its music and sound effects like clicking, tick tocking and chimes. Nothing is really explained, it just is and I'm okay with that. I don't need a story, even if there are NPCs every so often to talk with.

One drawback to the game on PC is that the screen is tall and narrow like an old school arcade cabinet. This tall resolution is because Anodyne is also an Android OS game. A fun Android game, but it doesn't help it on PC.

In all, this game feels good and enjoyable. If you're into simple puzzles, action adventure and a SIMPLE old school Zelda that lets you explore a lot; this is for you. If you're into a complex, deep Zelda experience with a rich story, this game isn't for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976178495', 'num_games_owned': 503, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1396108149}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049037214', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 636, 'last_played': 1396051224}
review: A bit like Zelda, but not as clear about where you're supposed to go or what you're supposed to do. Maps are unclear and upgrades are misleadingly useless and few on top of that. Store keeper does nothing, so it's pointless. Many things in the game seem to be like that, now that I think about it. It seems like it attempts to be epic or mystical, but it just ends up confusing with no resolution to the legend it tries to create. Another disappointing mistake in the game is even the most minute incorporation of sexual dialogue and vulgarity when no other classic game epic (that Anodyne pathetically mimics) includes such explitives at all. Overall, it was fun in the moment, disappointingly confusing more often than not, and in the end just sad. Glad I got it on sale! Definitely not worth $9.99, or I'd ask for my money back!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010395257', 'num_games_owned': 3304, 'num_reviews': 463, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1371762506}
review:
What do you get when you mix one part Zelda, one part Cthulhu, and one part…well, I’m inclined to say Earthbound, but somebody already has and while it’s certainly odd and funny at times, it comes off as more bizarre than anything. Anyway, you get Anodyne, a game about…well, I’m not really sure. I do know that it has a similar look and feel to older Zelda games, but it’s way darker.  The game pokes fun at various videogame tropes, but also throws a few of its own out there, such as collecting cards in order to proceed because doors are apparently…shy…and won’t open if you don’t have them.

No, not keycards either; collector cards for different monsters. Yeah, the game is definitely bizarre.  It’s also very fun and intriguing. There are a number of things that happen in the game you certainly don’t expect, but that’s not saying much from a game like this. Really, I’m halfway between not wanting to spoil anything and also not really understanding what I’m looking at all at the same time. It’s cheap, it’s fun, and it’s definitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023891248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1598832854}
review:
This game isn't for everyone, but hardcores and nostalgics will both be mystified by Anodyne. This game is not at all what it looks like and it really is greater than the sum of its parts. At times playing this game struck such a chord in me that I couldn't really sleep at night. It gets you thinking, and it's not a comfortable experience.
In order to get the full experience of this game, you'll need to play it obsessively. Then again, if you're not a completionist, this game's message wasn't really written for you.

TL;DR: This is a must play for hardcores, but don't expect it to be fun all the time and don't expect it to make you feel good. Ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069515213', 'num_games_owned': 259, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1387221581}
review:
Anodyne is an action-adventure game by [url=https://twitter.com/seagaia2]Sean Hogan[/url] and [url=https://twitter.com/jonkittaka]Jonathan Kittaka[/url], released in February 2013. The game seems to be inspired by the old Zelda games in terms of gameplay and features a nostalgic pixel art. The game is all about exploring the dream world of the protagonist, who goes by the name of Young. The player uses a broom for combat and very few other items to proceed through the story. The goal of Anodyne is to collect a certain amount of cards, which are spread all over the world and often require solving puzzles and fighting enemies to progress to the end area of the game.

My first playthrough through this game went fairly fast, there were only a few stages that required some grinding. Considering that, I was happily surprised by the final boss fight, which in my opinion had an adequate level of difficulty. Also there were a few cards that required to solve rather challenging puzzles, but you don't need to collect all cards to finish the game, so that only comes into consideration if you intend to complete the game 100%. If so, the secret "???" items are also very difficult to find and obtain, even if you use a guide.

I really liked the story of Anodyne, even though the dialogues sometimes screwed that up for me, but that's just a small downside to the otherwise so mystic atmosphere and the dream-like feeling which this game provides. All that is underlined by the enchanting pixel art and incredibly suitable and admirable music. This game possibly has one of my favourite gaming music pieces of all time.

All of this matches up to the foggy surreality that makes this game so fascinating for me and which is why I would recommend this game to you. I don't want to spoil anyone's appetite too much, so all I can say is: If you like exciting stories, you should get this game.

review: Anodyne is a old school Zelda clone with piss poor gameplay but really, really cool atmosphere. The atmosphere in this game is really well done, the music mixed with the 16 bit graphics and unusual level setting made it a really interesting game to play. That being said the gameplay is just terrible. Unlike the SNES Zelda games the combat feels clunky and unprecise but nothing that I couldn’t suffer through, that is until I got the ability to jump. The jump mechanic and the jump puzzles in this game are game ruining. author: {'steamid': '76561198004664608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1390275609}
review:
Anodyne has plenty going for it in concept -- it's inspired by the great Link's Awakening, it has nice graphics and a good soundtrack, and the dungeon design is excellent (the one exception being the circus-themed dungeon). Unfortunately, the best I can say about the sum of its parts is that it's merely an "average" game -- perhaps worth a playthrough if you're desperate for a Zelda-like gameplay experience, but better off left on the proverbial shelf otherwise.

At its best, the gameplay is enjoyable and reasonably challenging. While not nearly as polished as its inspiration, it's not too difficult to look past things such as the lack of hitbox refinement, flighty controls, and strange overworld design. Other flaws are a little harder to dismiss.

Perhaps Anodyne's most glaring flaw is its story and character dialogue, which are all but incoherent. Yes, the dreamlike setting and premise of the game explain this design decision, but there are two kinds of dreams in life: First, there are the strange or eventful dreams that we relate to family or friends for a good laugh or an interesting tale. Second, the kind that are so bizarre that we wouldn't bother retelling them, because all we'd get in return are blank stares. Anodyne is more the latter than the former. The game would have been more enjoyable with no story at all.

Lastly, I'll note that the game is not particularly family friendly as the themes get darker (and the profanity stronger) further into the game. Obviously that's more applicable to some audiences than others.

In closing, while I can say I enjoyed the game enough to go for all the achievements, it's not something I'd want to play again in the future. Buy it on a sale if you must buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027351576', 'num_games_owned': 603, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1387246095}
review:
Stylistically, this reminded me a bit of Space Funeral, in a good way. It uses tried-and-true mechanics (with a bit of a spin) as part of its storytelling, but in a very subtle way.

The story itself is difficult to follow. The main theme certainly seems to be about some self-centered individual who is in a constant cycle of breaking and mending a friendship with someone else. The story begins with us in the middle of one of the "breaks" in the friendship. Young, the player character, expects it to be easy to fix the friendship, but the friend, Briar, is savvy to the cycle and won't be so quick to forgive. Young's journey is a humbling one, as he has to come to terms with his imperfections in order to show Briar he has changed. However, we can assume the cycle will continue. At least... that's what I got out of the story.

It's always tough with these sorts of surreal games to tell if it's just being weird for weird's sake or if everything has a specific meaning. However, this game at least stays consistent in its presentation, and for that much it's commendable.

The writing is excellent, the visuals are gorgeous for pixel art, the soundtrack is great (and surprisingly deep), and though the game only has one real mechanic for puzzles, it continually finds ways to keep it fresh. Unfortunately, the game is VERY formulaic. It doesn't take long to figure out exactly how each area will play out: enter a region, explore every cell on the map, enter a dungeon, explore every cell on the map, collect cards, fight a boss, repeat.

The dungeons themselves are designed impeccably and the overall pace is good enough that the predictability isn't too problematic. But occasionally I did roll my eyes upon entering a new area, thinking "Well here we go again."

Still, if you like Legend of Zelda and games with a deeper thematic experience than average, I can't recommend this highly enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039750899', 'num_games_owned': 738, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 3726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1031, 'last_played': 1455719051}
review: Возврат к старой нисходящий легенды Zelda игр. Из-за длины относительно короткий рассказ, повторный характер боевой и головоломок не стать разочарование. Я лично комок не любитель некоторые из bossfights и несоответствие сложности между большинство ранних боссов, являющихся легкой прогулкой, но несколько, в том числе финального босса, будучи раздражающе трудно не adequite причине. есть только 6 достижения и три из них приходят из основной истории, в то время как другие три из дополнительного achieveable содержания и геймплея. В общем я дал бы эту игру в 8/10, было хорошо написано и в конечном, как только он должен был не злоупотреблять его приветствовать. by SmeJIbIu^

author: {'steamid': '76561197972130959', 'num_games_owned': 927, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1386093997}
review:
Anodyne is an action-adventure game in the style of Legend of Zelda. You play Young, and your goal is to kill a bunch of bosses so eventually you could save Briar. That kind of sums the whole plot of the game.
The strength of the game comes from it's gameplay and the simplistic puzzles you are to solve, given a limited, but solid arsenal of powers. From the start you get a broom with which you can hit monsters and collect dust. It might sound funny, but dust actually has several uses like floating on water and blocking monster projectiles. Another power is the ability to jump, which will allow you to cross gaps and jump over monsters.
But, for me the strongest part of the game was the endgame. Yes, you actually have new content after finishing the game. You will be able to visit zones you been through already and new zones which are unreachable otherwise.
In conclusion Anodyne brings enjoyable gameplay with some jokes of the genre. I had a lot of fun with it, and it's a good value for the price.

this was a fun game! review:
Beautiful atmosphere and artwork. Awesome Music. Pure SNES Nostalgia!
Short sweet Zelda-esque open world adventure. Definitely worth adding to the retro games collection.

At the end of the game you earn a Tile-Swapping tool which allows you to go back and actually leave and explore outside of the gameplay area. When you leave the map you can find hidden areas which hold easter eggs and hidden characters. It was a nice touch.  Gave a reason to come back and play some more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988757543', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1390003637}
review: Armado com uma vassoura e com poeira, você tem que salvar o mundo de sei-lá-o-que. Com uma trilha sonora atmosférica, intrigante e grotesca. Claramente inspirado nos jogos antigos do Zelda. Esse jogo tem um charme que é difícil de encontrar em qualquer um. Novamente: intrigante. Quando os NPCs te falam coisas como "por favor, não defeque nos cereais", "Eu tenho tanto cereal sobrando para comer! Eu amo cereal." e "Até agora eu fiz intercurso sexual 18 vezes nesta estação", você começa a duvidar da própria sanidade. E como eu adoro isso! Não terminei de jogar o jogo, mas até agora não sei direito o que eu estou fazendo. Coletando cartas, abrindo portas... Eu só sei que eu quero fazer isso. Esse é o charme das "histórias mal contadas". E por favor: não tenham preconceito com a simplicidade tecnológica do jogo. Não significa que não há diversão.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004343616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1384378661}
review:
I'm generally a fan of old-school RPGs, I'm all in for supporting indie game developers, but c'mon! This entire trend of shitty games sold as "Indie", "Retro" or "Old-School" is really starting to get on my nerves! I don't mind the lack of voice acting, I don't need long and gorgeous cut-scenes, I can live with the shallow storylines, I can also deal with the shitty graphics in general. But what really drive me nuts are the small things, such as, for example, me being able to hit an enemy from 100 miles away.... with a melee weapon! Nevermind the fact that all I really hit was air, the monster on the other corner of the screen just dies and disappears.

For me, this is a game breaker. It's like the game devs are telling me, "Hey, it's a fantasy game, right? You only imagine you're an adventurer, you only imagine you're fighting monsters, so what's wrong with imagining you really hit the bat right before it died?"  Well, at this point I put on my Grumpy Cat mask and shout, "NO! I won't friggin' imagine that! It's your job as game devs to illustrate at least the most basic stuff!".

Needless to say, that if in the past I generously shelled out money for indie games without digging too deep, thinking to myself that even if I won't be enjoying the game, at least I'd be supporting the games industry, that is not the case anymore. I'm tired of lazy game devs selling me crap as "Indie". I'm willing to pay for good games, but I work hard to earn that money, and so should everyone else, including game developers.

As far as I'm concerned, Anodyne is a bad game. I can't remember how much I paid for it, I just hope it wasn't much. Oh well, at least I'm wiser and more careful now, when it comes to choosing what games to buy, regardless of how cheap or expensive they are.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991145957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1389432443}
review:
"Anodyne"とは、鎮痛剤という意味。

クリアは5時間程度。
16bit時代のアクションゲームを想起させる作り。世界観はある人物の無意識下ということもあって、おどろおどろしい雰囲気を漂わせていいる。
SFC時代の"ゼルダの伝説"よろしく、ジャンプと攻撃のみのアクションで、様々な仕掛けの施されたダンジョンをクリアしていく。
一定のタイミングで火を噴き出す床、ポールの周りをぐるぐる回る火の玉、乗ったら一定の方向に動く床、時間制限で落ちる床等々、ダンジョンごとに独特の対応を要求されるのでプレイヤーを飽きさせない工夫が施してある。

……しかしながら、フィールド及びダンジョンのマップがなんとも見にくい。
同じ大きさの部屋が碁盤の目のように隣接している構成になっているので、小マップではなく都度全体マップを開く必要があり、それによって自分が全体のどの位置いるかを把握する事が必須事項となる。
加えて問題はもう一つあって、部屋が隣接しているからといって、そこを通り抜けられるというのは全く別問題であるということだ。
未探索の部屋が隣だと思ったら、反対側からぐるりと外周を回らされたなんてことがあったりするので、プレイ時には注意が必要だ。
とはいえ、一度目的を果たしたギミックを何度も繰り返させないようにマップをショートカットさせる配慮が見られるのと、いつでも自由にダンジョンの出口に戻れる機能は非常に助かった。
もしかしたら、製作者もマップの複雑性を感じていて、その救済策として用意しているのかもしれない。

また、本作にはカードという収集要素も有り、カードの集めた数によって開放される扉があったり、後々物語に関わる大変重要な要素となっている。マップやダンジョンのあちこちに宝箱という形で落ちているので、マップやダンジョンの隅々まで、くまなく探しておくことを強いられる。これが結構煩わしく、過去にクリアしたダンジョンで取りこぼしてしまうと、カードの枚数を数えながら、あちこちを東奔西走する羽目になる。
余談だが、間抜けな筆者はその取りこぼしで面倒な思いをした。

その様子はまるで宮沢賢治著"雨ニモマケズ"の如くで、

"東の森にカードの取りこぼしあれば、行って茨に体を裂かれ"
"西の浜辺にカードの取りこぼしあれば、行って砂に足を取られ"
"南の池にカードの取りこぼしあれば、行って泥にまみれ"
"北の高山にカードの取りこぼしあれば、行ってはしごを登り"
"取得済みだった時は、ここでもないと涙を流し"

そんな感じでsteamフォーラムガイドには何度も世話になった。

本作は敵のバリエーションも豊富である。
出会った当初は苦戦もするだろうが、動きにパターンがあるのでそれさえ見きってしまえばどうとでもなる。通常の敵はマップを移動するごとに復活するので、雑魚敵を倒し続けることで落とすライフを取得し続ければ、常に体力満タンの状態を維持することも可能。
敵も自分も攻撃を受けた直後は無敵時間が存在するので、ヒットアンドアウェイ先方が基本戦法となる。
そして、マップの終わりには個性的なボスも存在する。初見では厳しいこともあるが、体力次第ではごり押しでどうにかなってしまうこともあるので、積極的に攻めてみるのもいいだろう。

操作キーはデフォルトでは微妙なところに配置されているので、ゲーム開始直後に以下を例とした割り振りをした方がやりやすい。
もちろん、プレイされる方のお好みで設定してしまって全くかまわない。
(ちなみに筆者はFPS操作に慣れ親しんでいるので、すべて左手でプレイできるようにキーバインドした)

* Up = W
* Down = S
* Left = A
* Right = D
* Jump = Space 
* Attack Command = Enter
* Menu = Tab

セーブポイントはマップのそこかしこに点在しており、ボタン一つで簡易セーブが可能なところは非常に便利。
セーブポイントは、どれも「ここまで来て死んだらあの面倒くさいアクションをやり直しか……」と思うところに用意されているので至れり尽くせりであった。ちなみに初回時に限りセーブポイントは体力を全回復させてくれる。

最後に、これは世界観に合わせて"あえて"なのだろうが、音楽がとてつもなく退屈、かつ単調なものの繰り返しとなっている。
はっきり言って聞けたものではない。
いいゲームには花を添えるようにいい音楽が存在するものだが、この単調さははっきり言って苦痛の類い。クリア後に何一つ頭に残らなかった。

ストーリーについても特筆すべきものはない。無意識下という状況の中なので、夢と現実が混在した違和感を感じさせようとする努力はうかがえるが、残念ながら脚本が追いついていないように感じる。例えるならば致死性のない毒。一部のマップなどにはセンスを感じるだけに残念。

長くなってしまったので総じるが、温故知新なアクションゲームとして巧みに作られており好印象。ストーリー、マップに不満も残るが、破綻するほどではない。

だが音楽……お前はダメだ。

review:
If there is one thing that comes to mind playing this game, it's the Gameboy Colour Legend of Zelda games. The art style calls back to those games with a sense of fondness and love, paying plenty of tribute to style of spriting and the dungeon design. However, it is not a flat out imitation of the handheld Zelda games, there is plenty of originality with its beautifully vivid art palette, and the more psychedelic musical score that burrows into your brain and puts you in a dreamlike state. Which is quite fitting, considering that the entire game takes place in a dream realm.

I'd highly recommend this game, especially if you're looking for a game that is like the classic Zelda games, but is also original in its own right. For best results, Use an NES controller with a USB adapter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044600422', 'num_games_owned': 624, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1388185233}
review:
A bit quirky but oddly familiar is one way I would describe Anodyne. It felt sort of like an inside joke that that, while not entirely in on, I could still relate too and appreciate on some level. The same goes for the plot specifically, there is little to no back story or context given but I suspect this was a conscious decision as it leads each player to get a different meaning from various parts based on the context of their own life. Unfortunately it is a little subtle and you're never hit with that moment of introspective clarity that other games manage to deliver.

Mechanics wise the puzzles are nicely balanced between single room puzzles and exploration/ labyrinth puzzles. A few of the platforming puzzles were a little rough, mainly because of bad spawn points, but overall it's straight forward and satisfying. The worlds and dungeons are nicely varied, very nicely actually, and interesting, as are the enemies.

In the end this is probably not for everyone but if you're looking for a throwback to the heyday of adventure gaming or are looking for something a little different with a lot of heart just to burn a few hours then this is as good a choice as any.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043358482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 849, 'last_played': 1387152290}
review: A fun little game. Very nostlagic to retro games, which I enjoyed.  Very interesting story, I just wish there had been a bit more presented to me, and that the game hadn't been so short (you can beat it under three hours pretty easily). The secrets are alittle hard to find, but thats part of the fun.  If you're looking for a long RPG this is not the game for you. If you want a quick romp through an interesting world give it a shot.

review: A lonely game set in a strange environment reminiscent of a bad dream or a dark dimension. The characters seem oddly gloomy with few exceptions, and some enemies are simple while others administer a slight shudder and raised hairs to the player. Not much thought seems to have gone into this game at first until, as you progress, you feel more and more alone and divided from your comfort zone. Immediately you are thrown into a world of darkness and despair; locations and enemies have odd names, people seem friendly or derranged and harmless, and you yourself - named Young - access the world of Anodyne through a strange dreamlike overworld on a weird quest given to you after being rudely awoken. Although rather short, Anodyne is a great game for those who want a simple, not-so-relaxed indie game that will keep you playing and guessing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057158858', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1248, 'last_played': 1655247908}
review:
There is so much I could talk about in this game, so I'm going to try to simplify it in two ways: as a game, and as a piece of art.
This game is obviously inspired by the Legend of Zelda, and it takes this inspiration well. It's an overhead adventure, in which you explore the world and dungeons as well as you can. To progress throughout the game, you generally must find cards that will help you unlock gates throughout the game that require different amounts of cards. In order to get to the end of the normal, story-section part of the game, you have to investigate places well to find every last card, giving plenty of playability and exploration that doesn't grow too stale or ambigious as new challenges arise to getting each card. You may have to pay attention and give patience, but if you're trying, nothing during the normal gameplay is impossible to find out. In what is technically post-game, you gain no real rewards for what you do except unlocking a few interesting levels. A lot of the post-game items almost guarentee that you use a guide, as they are very hidden and cryptic. However, you don't have to do any of this post-game, and most of these items are pointless anyway unless you're a completionist freak. All of the post-game cards (not hidden items in general) must be found to unlock a special last area, which again doesn't serve too much of a point, but it's a sweet area and gives a sense of accomplishment. There are only two things that I would shame the game in terms of gameplay for, and that is that: 1. when you gain the jumping ability, you cannot jump over enemies or projectiles as you would logistically think, and 2. you can only have one save file, meaning that if you want to replay the game  for a speed-running achievement, you must give up your long and hard progression of card collecting. However, those serve as minor details, and the game is still extremely enjoyable.
If you ever wanted to do the famous "are videogames art?" argument, this game would be an excellent example for proving so. Everything about this game is beautiful, to the point where I'm still thinking about it almost daily, even when I have completed it several months ago. This game is intended to be the exploration into the mind of Young, which means that everything is somewhat of a pre-set dream. And Hell, it truly is like a dream. The soundtrack is absolutely beautiful, and fits each individual event or area all too well. The graphics are purposely 16-bit-esque, which gives the atmosphere a surreal sense and further helps move the game's intentions of the whole story. The whole plot is an ambigious exploration throughout Young's mind, which brings up so much symbolism. You could hire the most advanced English professors of the world to try to dissect this game, and even then there would be so many possibilities as to how you could interpret almost anything. Even the very existence of characters in this dream world are controversial as to what they mean. Some themes of the game are given to you on a plate, and whether or not some purposes of the game are clear or ambigious to you, they all share ideas that the most troubled in life may have, and they may easily reflect into individuals on a personal level. This is not a "princess is captured, go save her" kind of plot for the thick-headed, and that is definitely an up-side.
This game is a masterpiece. If you a few good hours to sit down and play videogames each day, or if you ever wonder about your dreams or life in general, you have to play this. The ten dollars are so worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997557430', 'num_games_owned': 405, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1510862818}
review:
아무도 없는 한적한 철제 방 내부에는 그저 테이블과 스피커와 마이크만이 있었다.

 오게 된 경위는 간단하다. 이곳은 가상현실이다. 모든 것이 자유자재로 변화하지만, 프로그래밍된 행동 패턴이 따로 있다. 나는 그런 세계에 놓여 있다.

 “가상현실도 게임인가?”
 내가 테이블 위에 놓인 마이크에 대고 묻자마자 스피커에서 기계화된 무미건조한 목소리가 자연스럽게 흘러나왔다.

 “Anodyne.”
 애너다인, 영어로 편안함, 평화로움에 가까운 뜻을 가진 단어이다. 나는 내가 물은 질문의 답변이 고작 이것이라는 사실에 의문을 가졌다.

 “이건 게임인가?”
 “그렇다.”
 거의 묻자마자 되돌아오는 목소리에 나는 감탄했다. 음성인식은 둘째치고 추상적인 질문에 이 정도로 빠른 대답을 할 수 있다니.

 “그렇다면 이것은 어떠한 게임인가?”
 “우리가 가졌던 의문에 대해 다시금 고찰해보는 게임이다.”
 신기했다. 내 성대에서 시작하여 목을 통해 울려 나오는 소리는 철제 방을 진동시키기에 충분했지만, 스피커에서 나오는 기계화된 목소리는 말이 끝나도 전혀 메아리 치지 않았다.
 하지만, 나는 왜 그가 ‘우리’라고 했는지에 대해 의문을 가졌다.

 “’우리’란 누구지?”
 “게임을 게임대로, 목적을 목적대로, 하나의 클리셰에 처박혀 사는 게이머를 뜻한다.”
 답변은 의외로 간단했다. 아마도 답변자는 사람이 틀림없었다. 그러지 않고서야 ‘우리’라는 표현을 쓸 순 없으니까.

 “이 게임의 목적은 뭐고, 어떤 스토리를 갖고 있는 거지?”
 내가 질문을 했는데도 스피커에서는 아무 소리도 들려 오지 않았다. 나는 질문을 해도 곧장 튀어나오던 무미건조한 목소리가 나오지 않자 약간 초조해지기 시작했다. 나는 1분도 견디지 못하고 의자에서 일어나려고 하자 갑자기 스피커에서 목소리가 나오기 시작했다.

 “목적은 없다. 그저 주어진 대로 행동할 뿐이다. 그건 당신의 몫이다. 스토리조차도 난해하며, 그것을 어떻게 이해하느냐는 게이머에 달려 있다.”
 과연 가상현실, 이라고 나는 생각했다. 그리고 나는 나가고 싶었다. 나는 이곳에서 나가 좀 더 많은 게임을 즐겨보고 싶었다. 과연 이 철제 방 바깥은 어떤 세계일까? 난해하며 내가 생각하는 대로 흘러갈 수 있는 게임이란 무엇인가?

 “더 이상의 질문은 없는가?”
 갑자기 스피커에서 음성이 흘러나왔다. 나는 “이 공간에서 나갈 수 있는가?” 라고 묻기 위해 입을 열려고 했다.

 “그렇다면 좋다. 이상 Anodyne이라는 게임에 대한 질의응답을 마친다.”
 나는 입을 벌린 채로 당황했다. 그가 뜻한 것은 이 방, 이 세계가 아니었다. 그가 지금까지 대답한 것은 Anodyne이라는 게임에 대한 답변이었다.
 
 나는 그저 입을 벌린 채로 멍하니 스피커를 지켜보았다. 생각해보니 이 방에는 문 조차 없었다.

 “여긴 어디지?”
 “참… 평화로운 곳이죠. 안 그렇습니까?”
 그 말을 끝으로 스피커에서 목소리가 나오는 일은 없었다.

review:
My feelings on the game are as follows, I appologize for the poor formatting:

I really, really wanted to like this game. I enjoy the visual style and the classic Legend of Zelda type gameplay. There are many interesting areas in the game and amusing little tidbits that come from dialog and secrets, but they are spoiled by the convoluted, often repetetive parts that come between them. The mechanics always feel kind of off (you fight with a broom that you can only thrust forward, making combat feel awkward, *spoiler* the jump mechanic is introduced a little while into the game and to me, the length of the jump felt weird, etc.). You can play for a fairly long time without any story elements popping up, and when they do they're vague and make little sense, so I was personally not drawn in by the story, though others apparently were. I'll admit that I didn't finish the game, so maybe it comes together more closer to the end. 

If you have any questions, comment them and I'll try to respond (though this is my first review, so I don't even know if I can comment in response to your questions, I guess we'll find out).

review:
2013-11-04

这是一个相当不错的马赛克游戏，画面不需评价，音乐不错，但是引擎有些软肋（Adobe AIR/Flash），这个引擎会导致存档难找、Steam Overlay呼出困难，以及Linux下对手柄的支持不力。另外就是界面过于简陋，暂停时计时仍然继续，还有某些关卡设计过于冗长等（还好3小时通关成就不比以前某些游戏变态，算简单的），画面维持竖屏等等。
如果界面再加强一些，换一个C++的引擎，把画面弄成横屏， 允许正经暂停（停止计时），评级会上升。
还有这游戏的彩蛋真算多的，比如开发者连Debug界面也做成隐藏关卡了。

author: {'steamid': '76561198019327616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1388637618}
review:
Can I give a thumbs-sideways?

The word "anodyne" in a literary sense can mean "soothing" or "blandly agreeable," and I can certainly give the game the bland part.

For the better part of three hours playing the game I did not know if I could stomach finishing it. I'm getting ahead of myself.

It's a Legend of Zelda-like with a ton of strange thematic choices, poor writing, too much dialogue and tonal shifts that will give a player whiplash. What few inventive game mechanics it employs are spread throughout an atrociously long and dull climb to nowhere. You might pass through seven screens just to get to the next place: no enemies, no obstacles to speak of, just a march. As if the designers (credited indie devs Sean Hogan Jonathan Kittaka) couldn't be bothered, having come up with the overall map of an area, to fill it in with things. This becomes very apparent when retracing your steps. You will find a checkpoint at the beginning of an area, putting you on guard for the trials ahead. Then those trials never manifest and seven screens later there's another checkpoint.

To what end? Was my adversary through that place boredom? Will checkpoints at the beginning and end of a stretch really help me combat that adversary?

The few basic enemies you encounter are all laughably simplistic. Many pose no threat at all. Some cannot even harm you. This led me to think perhaps they were more of a rhetorical device than a game object, really. The only rhetorical question that sprang to mind was "why am I still playing this?" Then later I encountered fire-breathing lions and they shot my dandy theory to hell.

But I do know the answer to that rhetorical question, as the game is a little more than a poorly-written, bland, easy Zelda clone.

First, even though the various mechanics are spread out way too far, the few that the game offers are very neat. Even with all the crummy verbosity, the game does not tutorialize, rather giving you the tools and letting you figure things out. A good bit of design. The nugget of a good game. I would never have thought that piles of dust could have so many uses, but there you go.

Second, there is at least one boss in the game that requires a neat bit of fooling and approaches a reasonable challenge. Shame that I can only honestly say that about one of perhaps eight or so bosses, but that one is very good and fun.

Third, there are a few counter-intuitive design choices that I won't spoil that I do admire as choices. It is this last point that keeps my thumb pointing up with all I've said about the game to this point. What I will say is that it's a shame you only get the full, mechanically complete game after playing through the whole thing.

Heck I guess that's a second way it reminds me of Fez. The first was the music and sound effects. Which I didn't mention. Okay.

The music is fine if you're into chiptunes and oscilloscopes. Tones, mostly sine waves. Some triangle. There are several good tones.

Which is more than I can say about the jokes. Those are all tonedeaf. And just grating given everything else that happens. I want to say that, as a rule, you don't get to make crappy puns about bicycles with names in the same game where you murder a man and jump into his corpse-portal to go commit an abortion on a tentacle monster. Which is part of what I mean when I say the game is tonally all over the place. Anything vaguely interesting as a narrative point just gets dropped somewhere; crushed away by screen after screen of nothing happening.

Things I didn't like:
bad jokes
boring, longwinded dialogue
blandness
useless screens
lack of difficulty

Things I did like:
inventive mechanics
post-game elements
certain specific challenges
cute enemy names
no navi

Buy it on sale. At the time of this writing it is half-off the ten dollar list price, which still feels like a bit much for what you're getting. Do not pay ten dollars for this game, at any rate.

review: This game was great from start to finish. Reminds me a ton of the 2D Legend of Zelda games, but it has lots of charm and enough unique items and personality to be more than a lookalike or clone. It's obviously a bit shorter than LoZ, and the few puzzles are pretty simple, but the simplicity is part of what makes it attractive. I might replay this to get all of the achievements one day, and to do that, I'll have to attempt a speedrun. With most games, that's a scary thought, but in Anodyne, it sounds like a great way to spend a night and soak in any details I missed.

review:
Zelda meets Earthbound. The dungeon design reminds me a lot of Link's Awakening and a little bit of Megaman Legends. Solid gameplay all around. Now, the Earthbound part? It's wierd. Most of the time the setting is just unusual. Occasionally it's disturbing; I started mentally referring to one area as "Murder Town."

It's a Zelda-like. It's short and sweet. I had a good time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044999554', 'num_games_owned': 281, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1387564442}
review: I got this game with the humble bundle I purchased and had the lowest of expectations and was still disappointed.  It seems like this game was made 10 years ago by people who didn't have the game's best interests in mind. The enemies are always easy to defeat including the underwhelming bosses. Your character's weapon is a broom, which is amusing at first, but the novelty quickly wears off. I did not complete this game or in fact get very far as I found it extremely boring.

review: This is a game that I haven't really talked about ever since I beat it, and I'm not quite so sure about why. This game is easily within my top 15 favorite games of all time. Even though it was very short, it was extremely good. It is based on the same gameplay as Legend of Zelda games. There are many great puzzles, really cool story, and amazing boss fights. The main character is easily the most intense protaganist in a game that I've seen thus far. He fights darkness from all dimensions with a broom. Yep, a broom. He kills monsters with a broom. That aside, you can beat it in one sitting, but it makes you want to play it over again just to challenge yourself. I hope to see more from this team again in the future.

review: First game I've played through to the end in a while -- in only a couple of sittings, too. The atmosphere kept me drawn in the most, and the variety in the different zones. The puzzles are simple but engage your brain just enough to be fun without being frustrating (looking at you, Myst). It's a small detail, but the character moves fast enough that traversing through territory you've already explored isn't a burden. There's a lot of creativity here, and it's well polished. Definitely deserves a beer and a play through. Sound track sounds awesome with a subwoofer.

review: На удивление затягивающая инди-игрушка в стиле old-school action-adventure. Красочные локации и множество загадок готовы увлечь на несколько часов. Боссы в целом достаточно просты, что минус, но вот добираться до них приходится через хорошо продуманные лабиринты полные врагов и ловушек, что большой плюс. Радует наличие порта на андроид, но управление на сенсорном экране все же менее удобно, так что рекомендуется играть с пада или клавиатуры.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042023224', 'num_games_owned': 1587, 'num_reviews': 1027, 'playtime_forever': 893, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 893, 'last_played': 1401633170}
review:
/2014년 6월 1일 수정/

빗자루 하나 들고 적들을 무찌르는 영의 모험. 게임 자체는 꽤나 할 만 하다. GB판 젤다를 아는 분이라면 재미있게 할 수 있을 듯. 상당히 비슷한 부분이 많이 보인다.

적당히 카드 모으면서 진행해야되니 콜렉션이 조금 강제되는 부분이 있긴 하다. 다만 맵 하나가 그리 큰 편도 아니고, 적당히 다 돈단 느낌으로 돌다보면 어느새 카드 콜렉션은 얼추 완성되있기도 하고.
생각보다 체크포인트도 많아서 좀 죽어도 이어 하기도 어렵지않고.
컨트롤이 조금 뻑뻑한게 문제가 되는데, 이건 아무래도 플레이어가 적응해야 할 문제이지 싶다. 

그리고 스토리......
사실 한글패치가 이루어지고 나서 다시 즐겼던 이유가 스토리 때문인데,
막상 한글판으로 즐겨도 그 스토리를 제대로 이해하기가 어려운 게 사실.
취향을 조금 탈 만한 스토리다. 불행히도 내 취향과는 살짝 다르고.
아무래도 스토리에 크게 신경 안 쓰는게 나을지도 모르겠다.
