author: {'steamid': '76561197977871703', 'num_games_owned': 971, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1535826965}
review: On the surface, Anodyne looks like your traditional, top-down SNES-inspired action RPG. And while I'm thankful for this aesthetic, I'm even more thankful for what turns out to be a cerebral experience that evokes an array of emotions while playing. Many indie games do a decent job of this, but often at the expense of game-play. Not Anodyne. It looks beautiful, it sounds beautiful and it's FUN.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035667350', 'num_games_owned': 2271, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 665, 'last_played': 1383021800}
review: A throwback to the old topdown legend of zelda games. Because of a relatively short story length, the repetative nature of the combat and puzzles does not become frustrating. I personally wad not a fan of some of the bossfights and the discrepancy of difficulty between most of the early bosses being a cakewalk but a couple, including the final boss, being annoyingly difficult for no adequite reason. there are only 6 achievements and three of those come from the main story, while the other three are from the additional achieveable content and gameplay. Overall i would give this game an 8/10, it was well written and ended as soon as it needed to to not overstay its welcome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017485977', 'num_games_owned': 2353, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1386731390}
review: On the whole, if you want a fun and unique Zelda-like action-adventure game with puzzles you couldn't go wrong with Anodyne. The music is good, the look is interesting, the gameplay is generally solid. It's not without flaws. When it comes to jumping, you will probably be swearing a lot because the game feels "slippery" when it comes to edges. There's also a fair bit of tedious exploring at the end of the game to get the necessary items to progress to the final area. But overall, it's a pretty solid and fun game that will take you between 3-6 hours to beat on your first try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111811696', 'num_games_owned': 1567, 'num_reviews': 179, 'playtime_forever': 811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 811, 'last_played': 1386368773}
review:
Крайне рекомендую эту игру как поклонникам Зельды и ретро, так и любителям страшилок вроде Лимбо или Closure - и историй о том, как "однажды я купил на рынке странный китайский картридж, который...". Игра шикарно выполнена и довольно большая: хотя за 3-часовое прохождение дают ачивку, я потратила на неё более 13 часов, и то не открыла ещё все послеигровые секреты. Авторы не навязывают игрокам скучные простые испытания, общие для начальных этапов большинства приключенческих РПГ. Вместо этого они сразу предлагают врагов с достаточно необычным, бросающим вызов поведением, а также комнаты, действительно заставляющие подумать, а затем попотеть.

Сюжет игры, как это водится в таких играх, пространный и в конце толком не объясняется. Но это не оставляет чувства неотвеченности. Во-первых, в игре разбросано достаточно подсказок, во-вторых, игровой процесс достаточно увлекает, чтобы сюжет был вторичен. Но на атмосферу пожаловаться нельзя: игра вызывает умиротворение, беспокойство, любопытство и мурашки... Также, несмотря на низкую интерактивность, свойственную жанру, она награждает игрока за исследование мира, особенно после концовки (практически выводя игрока на новый уровень геймплея после концовки!). Любители ретро оценят, что даже глюки в игре - не знаю, намеренно или случайно - такие же, как в глючных играх на Денди и Геймбой.

Испытания в игре достаточно сложные, но персонажу даётся большой запас здоровья, и игра не слишком отматывает игрока назад в случае оплошности. Можно не волноваться, что игра покажется непроходимой. Довольно большую роль в ней играют секреты, но только необязательные секреты запрятаны действительно глубоко. Персонально я сверилась с гайдом только ради 6 карт из 11 дополнительных (необязательных), и то реши я потратить больше времени на поиски - наверняка обнаружила бы их сама.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024945377', 'num_games_owned': 1031, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1455514158}
review:
I was a big fan of the old 2D Legend of Zelda games like Link's Awakening, and Anodyne effectively recaptures their spirit with some...very strange new twists.

Um...minor spoilers, I guess.

So it's like...a broom instead of a sword? What? Like, one minute you're floating down a river on a pile of dust, the next you're falling down a whirlpool into a weird land with walking trees, and then you climb a windmill and get to outer space, which is ruled by cubes wih faces, but it's actually a hotel filled with evil ghostly cleaning ladies, and there's a town where everything's in black and white and shadows are chasing you and...well, don't get me started on the ending. It's ridiculously surreal.

Therein lies Anodyne's brilliance--unlike Link's Awakening, which had some weirdness but was always internally consistent, Anodyne perfectly recreates the fuzziness and weirdness of an ACTUAL dream. And it does it well! A work of art, really.

The gameplay is great too, of course, standing on the shoulders of giants and whatnot. If you've played the top-down Zeldas, you should feel right at home. Frankly, it's a better Zelda game than some of the actual Zelda games we've seen recently.

Anyway, thumbs up.

review: Reminscent of old-school zelda, anodyne brings a few unique concepts to the tried-and-tested isometric RPG elements. Namely, the ability to swap tiles late into the game. But what makes Anodyne incredibly special is the eery story that surrounds it. For the entire game, you feel as if something is slightly off about the world around you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047982414', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1706478710}
review: A really satisfying mix of The Legend of Zelda and Yume Nikki. Focused combat mechanics and fairly interesting enemy design, with a really nice system for exploration aided by the warp-gates and gate-switches and enforced by the card collection mechanic. Really thematically interesting, although is very varied and therefore probably not suited for those wanting a very cohesive setting? My only major gripe is that some of the dialogue is too self-referential or thematically breaking or whatever.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995225947', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1384772152}
review:
Fun but very buggy and the developer isn't gonna fix anything.

He actually told me it was unreasonable to expect bug fixes because he was working on his own and already busy with a new project. Apparently it's not his responsibility to finish his projects before starting on something else and apparently it's our responsibility to know that it's a one man team before asking for a game that works.

Oh yeah and the game itself is fun when it's not bugged out but there's a big luck factor. If you take a certain road you have to start the entire game all over again because when you take a certain route via a certain gate you get stuck while there's nothing to warn you about that. Not really thought through, or that way they can sell it as if it's got replayability. Because the chance you'll be able to finish it the first time is small.

In short very amateuristic developer and a great concept for a game that just isn't really finished. Too bad, it had real potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022108691', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1464893763}
review: Recommended to me by a friend who said it was very similar to the Legend of Zelda games of old. I fear he may have been being disingenuous because this is only superficially similar to those treasures. Gone are the varied and complex puzzles, the wide assortment of tools and weapons, to be replaced with tests that a monkey could solve and a broom, respectively. It tries to cover for weak gameplay with an assortment of meta humor but it comes across as kind of cloying. It admittedly does have some very interesting and atmospheric areas later in the game but I really only got there by trudging forward disregarding the fact that I wasn't really enjoying myself all that much. I bought it because I'd seen various people singing it's praises but in the end I wasn't at all impressed. It wasn't bad by any measure but it's also nowhere near as good as they say it is or as clever as it thinks it is. Buy it on sale, if at all because the one thing that I can applaud it for is that the developers have stated that they're fine with people pirating it if they want to play it.

review:
This is a soft yes reccomendation.  The controls are too snappy/twitch for my liking.  Lacks a lot of the finesse controls of a game like Zelda: LTTP

+ World building is interesting but the way its presented isn't always the best
+Cool take on the broom/dust puzzels at first

-Map can be far too confusing at times.  Often uninspired maze-levels with a few too many dead ends that just waste your time (would have been fine if there was something to explore or pickup at those deadends)

Overall, 6.5/10.  Good game to experience if the price is right, but nothing to really write home about.  Beginning of the game is the strongest imo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022997080', 'num_games_owned': 2137, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1371617095}
review:
The Legend of Zelda is without any shred of doubt one of the most important and influential games ever made. Nintendo’s landmark release has inspired hundreds of games and mechanics within them, and you can't take two steps without hearing a developer site it as one of their biggest inspirations when developing their own games. Indie game Anodyne is one such example of a very close replication of LoZ's core gameplay, which isn't necessarily a bad thing in and of itself, but unfortunately fails to bring anything new to a very crowded table that results in but another poor attempt to recapture the magic of a classic.

You take control of Young, a man who wakes up in an unknown realm called the Nexus. You are told that you must protect Briar from the darkness, but first must prove your worth by scouring the land for cards. And, that’s pretty much all you need to know. The story unravels in a nonlinear way, leaving much for you to deduce for yourself and numerous questions without straight answers. Unfortunately this initial air of mystery falls apart after you've progressed further into the game and come to realize the developers have no intention of ever answering or even elaborating on the many threads making up its haphazard plot.

You run into a lot of characters during your travels, but none of them have anything relevant or useful to say. One of my biggest issues I had is that the dialog aspires to far more lofty and philosophical heights than it has any hope of reaching, ending up feeling pointless and pretentious, while at the same time completely throwing off the tone of the game. A lot of heavy subjects are brought up, from antisocial paranoia, to self worth and parental neglect, but they are never expanded upon or even discussed beyond a cursory overview (which comes across as forced and in poor taste).

It’s clear this was a very personal experience for the writer behind the dialog, but putting all of your problems and insecurities into your game is a sure fire way to lose your audience. Adding to the disjointed tone is a bundle of worthless profanity that was unneeded and serves absolutely no purpose. I'm not sure why the developer felt the need to include random four letter words, as it doesn’t jell at all with the rest of the game, and even as someone not typically bothered by profanity felt a tad disgusted when presented with it in this context. The ending is the final nail in the coffin, coming completely out of left field and not giving even a remote sense of resolution. I will be the first person to advocate artistic expression, but the story fails on so many levels it had me wishing it hadn’t been included at all.

From a gameplay perspective Anodyne fairs a bit better, but on the whole still fails to do enough with what it attempts. You spend your time split between exploring an overworld, collecting cards and filling out your map, and then dipping into dungeons which comprise some basic puzzles and the occasional boss fight. 

It's a formula that works, but in this case quickly becomes repetitive as you neither gain any new abilities, nor encounter consistently interesting puzzles to solve. So much of the game is comprised of nothing but wandering, that many areas feel like nothing but filler, featuring no purpose but to elongate your adventure and keep you away from the handful of smartly designed dungeons that could have made for a much tighter experience on their own.

The extensive backtracking also contributes to much of your time feeling like a grind, occasionally even breaking the game as paths close and you become forced to retread even more ground taking the long way to wherever you were headed. Simply put, it's poor design that frustrates and belittles the player, dragging the experience on longer than it needed to be and making the enjoyable sections a lot farther apart. It's a shame because at times I really felt Anodyne was onto something, but each time my hopes were shot down as I cursed the many aggravating design decisions the developers made.
 
Truth be told, there were moments when I actually did enjoy my time with the game. The true problem is, to reiterate, the fact that Anodyne does absolutely nothing we haven’t already seen and not well enough to compensate for its lack of innovation. It has it’s moments, but by and large feels all too familiar, and ultimately had me wondering why I was playing it instead of so many other games. I never felt compelled to continue, and I doubt it will be finished by most.

If Anodyne does anything right, it’s the game’s music and art. The graphics wholly envelope the 16-bit era, with a wonderful pixel style that is both beautiful and varied. Each dungeon has it’s own look, from a noir inspired town, to a neon maze it is constantly evolving and giving you something new to look at. It may not all flow together, but it was the one thing that made me want to search out new dungeons.

The other half of the presentation is the music, which does a great job of selling the somber, lonely tone of the story, even when the dialog can’t. From gentle piano melodies, to a pounding jungle beat, it is just a great set of songs, and some I could actually see myself listening to outside the game. They are that good, and easily the best part of the game. 

In the end though Anodyne left me wanting. Wanting for better levels, a better story, a better ending, but mostly, a better game. When I first began, I had little idea what to expect and was actually enjoying myself more than I would have expected. But as time went on, the gameplay never evolved, and the story only strayed farther and farther off course making me want to jump ship before it had completely sunk (which by the end it had definitely done.

By the time the credits had rolled, I was all too happy to be able to wash myself of the experience. I don't say that lightly, and hate to have to be so critical, but I simply cannot advise anyone to play what was one of the most disappointing games I've experienced in a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000422381', 'num_games_owned': 826, 'num_reviews': 229, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1590142911}
review:
I'm not really sure I can explain the story of this one.. I'd go so far as to say that the game is like a cross between Link's Awakening and Yume Nikki.

The gameplay is very much reminiscient of the Gameboy era Zelda games (Link's Awakening, Oracle of Seasons / Ages), so much so that I'd say if you enjoyed those games then you might enjoy this one.  The game ran just fine and had good remappable control options.  The aesthetics and environments are quite nice, as is the wafting calm and melancholy music. The story is very bizzare and not at all straightforwardly sensical, but it didn't feel forced. I really liked it, to be honest.  

I really enjoyed this game, a lot.  I'd reccomend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966548041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1385016513}
review:
To put it briefly, Anodyne is a pretty decent game and definitely worth a quick run-through if you catch it on sale... but it's quite a bit underwhelming considering the potential it has.

It's baiscally Zelda: LInk's Awakening (or one of the Oracles games), but with a trippy, dreamlike vibe (including some very good and atompsheric music and some great visuals here and there), and almost depressingly watered down (though that's somewhat the point, I think).   It's not super fun or amazing or anything breathtakingly new, but it's not BAD in any way other than some questioable chunky jumping controls and a couple little glitchy / unrefined tidbits.

For a much wordier and detailed review of mine, check out:
http://hip-indeed.tumblr.com/post/67644130704/lil-anodyne-mini-review

author: {'steamid': '76561197965495281', 'num_games_owned': 838, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1484, 'last_played': 1558748133}
review:
Anodyne looks and plays a lot like the top-down Legend of Zelda games but under a much more surreal wrapper.

There's your typical dungeon exploring, boss fighting, key collecting, chest opening, and unlocking new parts of the game's world. Themes and environments, however, are cryptic and dream-like, and the weird characters that inhabit it aren't very helpful in trying to understand it... Perhaps to the point of pretentiousness, as even the ending leaves a lot to your own interpretation.

While there isn't as much gameplay depth as you might find in The Legend of Zelda games, gameplay is nonetheless solid, with tight and responsive controls, competent puzzles, combat, bosses and platforming. And exploration, which is an even bigger focus of post-game content. If you've enjoyed the game's theme and environments - completing the game gives you powers to uncover even more secret areas, puzzles, collectibles and easter eggs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995202841', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1006, 'last_played': 1384136019}
review:
All in all, Anodyne is a pretty good game. For better or worse, it cribs a lot of its style from Zelda. Clear dungeon, get items, progress to new area, rinse and repeat. While I feel that it works for the most part, I think the best aspects of Anodyne are the outlandish game play elements and presentation. 

The fighting in this game is fairly one dimensional, and virtually every enemy is best approached by attacking and retreating. Honestly, this gets old pretty quickly and with only one weapon to use, you don’t have much variety in how you play. Coupled with the game’s emphasis of platforming that relies heavily on timing, Anodyne can be a bit frustrating and is best played in short spurts. 

The greatest strength of Anodyne is its surreal presentation. Particularly, it’s bizarre scenery and dream-like setting, blending mundane and fantasy characteristics. Anodyne does a good job of providing a backdrop that feels like you’re exploring the protagonist’s subconscious. The off-beat aesthetics of the game are carried into the game play as well, as you’re given a broom (of all things) to use as your weapon. Some of the ways you can interact with puzzles and levels is clever, and really helps to make Anodyne feel more original than a Zelda clone. 

Having said that, the game is probably best reserved for a sale or bundle purchase. While it’s definitely flawed, Anodyne is worth checking out and I’m looking forward to seeing what the developers come up with next.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993255188', 'num_games_owned': 700, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1691544294}
review:
A curious 2d Zelda-esque game with an eerily dark tone to it.  It may mean something or it may be style over substance (with regards to the story anyway), but the game itself is solid and playing it you can't help but get an uneasy feeling that this world is off.

It's hard to really describe this because of how unusual the story and tone fit with the play itself.  It's quite dark and often makes you question the meaning or motivation of many of the characters - but is there a deeper meaning to it?  I don't know.

Whatever the case may be, I will recommend this if you like the zelda style of 2D action game.  It has some clever bits to it, as well as a rather different "weapon" that adds a neat little gimmick overall.  I like it, though I am still not sure how I feel about it, meaning-wise.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971205857', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1384572253}
review: A very interesting game, in my opinion, and one that definitely gives me a unique sensation when I play it. It plays like older Zeldas, but is much more about exploration, beautiful visuals (or at least as beautiful as 16-bit can get) and unraveling the story. If you want a game that's all about gameplay, you should probably avoid this. If you want to try something different, relaxing, and interesting, give this a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961167439', 'num_games_owned': 1579, 'num_reviews': 720, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1384378120}
review: Find cards and battle bosses--that about sums up this adventure. There's a good number of different environments to explore, puzzles to solve, and monsters to fight. The gameplay is on par with other games in this genre. The story doesn't make a whole lot of sense and is probably the weakest part of the game. This is a great game had it been released 30 years ago. Today, it's just one of many attempts to copy The Legend of Zelda and just falls short of being anything but a clone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981621715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1384093862}
review:
Dark and brooding, a malevolent atmosphere grips this charmingly pixelated game.

"Gee willikers! This is just like that fondly remembered game of my childhood - TLoZ: Link's Awakening!" you squawk at me, giddy to seize a shared pop culture connection.

Swiftly, I backhand you. Cheek rapidly reddening you slump to your knees "b-b-but why..." comes the choked utterance from that doeful shocked face.

I stare down  with pity at the uneducated oaf before me before sharing my hard wrought wisdom.

"This game, this game is so much more than "just like" Link's Awakening. This is a doorway into the deepest depths of the human psyche, an exploration of hithero unknown horror. To play... neigh, to 'experience' this title is to journey beyond your limit, recklessly opening Pandora's box in the search for enlightenment. In doing so you may be blessed with the briefest moment of clarity… before the abject terror sets in, that realisation that what has once been learned cannot be undone and that henceforth your existence must continue onward from this day burdened by such new-found knowledge."

The light in your eyes dims, you sought only to play a game, a small time sink in which to pass an afternoon, you weren't prepared for such existence trembling enlightenment. Your spirit wills your body towards the bedroom door, away from the computer, yet your flesh does not obey. With a flick of your hand the mouse cursor glides over to the "Play Now" button. 

A series of events is now in motion beyond your control.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011949271', 'num_games_owned': 983, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1383293036}
review:
Anodyne's story has been criticised for being pretentious. I cannot agree with this criticism as I couldn't even work out what the hell the story was. Signs and characters make cryptic statements, none of which gel with any other sign's or character's cryptic statements, leaving the player alternately baffled and bemused, and propelled only by the gameplay, which is fairly decent without being amazing.

Is it pretentious? I don't know, but it is most certainly extremely poorly told.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032788858', 'num_games_owned': 1105, 'num_reviews': 678, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1383198545}
review:
Добротный рогалик со слабеньким  сюжетом и неплохим геймплеем. 

Боевая механика, само по себе, довольно простая, но в то же время интересная. Сами игровые уровни крайне интересно исследовать и изучать в поисках специальных карт (секретных). Графически перед вами модный и стилизованный пиксель, не обделенный дизайном. Саундтрэк игры, в принципе, нормален, ничего скучного в нем нет, по крайней мере. А, конечно же, юмор практически во всех деталях. 

Прыгни в воду! 7 из 10 :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197975251269', 'num_games_owned': 723, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1383763468}
review:
I knew nothing about this game before trying it, I hadn't seen a single screenshot or description. The soundtrack was 'dull' and I didn't like how it only occupied 50% of the horizontal screen estate (it uses a display ratio suited for smart phones).

The story made no sense to me and I paid it no mind, but the gameplay! Gosh! It's heavily inspired by 2d Zelda games (snes, gameboy), has the same type of progressing and controls and does a marvelous job at blending those super simple controls with creative puzzles fun bozz fights. It's retro without the downsides, it's paced well and not greedy on checkpoints (the checkpoints isn't regular save points, you get teleported back if you die with full hp and any items found/puzzles solved since you saved stays with you.)

Anyone who enjoyed A Link To The Past or any of the GBC Zelda games (Oracle of Ages/Seasons etc) will absolutely love this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010203084', 'num_games_owned': 4613, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1382149724}
review:
Anodyne is a strange game, similar to Zelda but not as upbeat. As Young, you find a broom and use that as your weapon throughout, collecting cards and clearing dungeons. There are some very interesting puzzles, and the locations are very unique, with some being completely bizarre or unsettling. The story is a bit odd and I can't really wrap my head around it, but that is probably just me.

The music is also completely different than you should expect such a game to be. It is more... drone-like than it is upbeat. It can be pretty creepy at times, but it absolutely is something to behold and makes for a unique experience while playing.

A playthrough will take 3 or 4 hours first playthrough, and a full speedrun achievement asks for less than 3 hours, so it isn't too long, but it is very unique for what it is. I highly recommend picking this up sometime. You could do a lot worse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049650795', 'num_games_owned': 468, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1516048576}
review: Absolutely AWESOME game. Plays similarly to one of the old Zelda titles (Oracle of Time/Seasons for Gameboy Color) but with more humor. author: {'steamid': '76561197993304005', 'num_games_owned': 5464, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1382457601}
review:
From the presentation, to the game engine, to the mechanics, to the controls, everything is clearly crude and underdeveloped. While it tries to emulate the greatness of the Nintendo classics, it totally fails on every level, including that of storytelling and setting. The only enjoyable aspect is the music sometimes.

Anodyne is mediocre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079118677', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1382470020}

author: {'steamid': '76561197992911576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1378462722}
review:
I really enjoyed Anodyne.
It has great sound effects and music, solid mechanics and a well designed 16-bit retro art style.
The dialogue can be quite humerous at times, and the story is interesting.

Completion time is between 4 to 6 hours, so it never really gets stale. Perhaps a little short, but a great throwback that stands on its own merits... Did I mention the protagonist's primary weapon is a broom? Yeah, it's like that. Easily one of my favourite games of this style.

For any fans of action/adventure games of the early 90's (Zelda!), I highly recommend this one. For everone else: It's fun, polished and never takes itself too seriously. A+

author: {'steamid': '76561197997724945', 'num_games_owned': 4607, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1380730159}
review: Anodyne is a very strange game... When you look at it or when you first play it you get the feeling that it is an old game, similar to Zelda in some ways. The music is actually pretty charming and relaxing while you're exploring around. The gameplay is nothing spectacular nor does it have any unique mechanics, it is solid, it works, it basicly puts you on a quest to gather a bunch of cards in order to unlock certain doors and defeat certain bosses until you reach the final boss. Now what really intrigues me about the game is the actual storyline, as soon as you start the game you are given the task to fight the Briar who has spread the Darkness across the land but the more I played and progressed throughout the game the more I got confused. In the end I kinda got the feeling that Anodyne tells the story of 2 friends along with their upsides and downsides in their relationship. It's really weird and odd, hard to understand to me atleast. In the end I think that Anodyne has it's own merit and it's actually a pretty good title but only because of the story in my honest opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997210209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1413685573}
review: This is a fantastic game. Anodyne brings back the feeling of the old 16 bit games. It had a wonderful sound track that gives the player such a grand feeling, from joyous to heaping amounts of creepiness. There were parts that were directionless to me, but this only added more fun to the game. Anodyne is a game for you, if you enjoy exploring, fighting with one weapon, and changing themes. If not, oh well, too bad for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049661472', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1379285412}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999094484', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1404802753}
review:
I bought this game for a couple bucks during a sale and figured it would be a neat little time waster. What I got was so much more than that! To me the most important factor of a good game is something a bit intangible - the mood and atmosphere. 
And boy does Anodyne deliver in that regard.

The tone is mostly set by the super eerie and mysterious music. But the whole game feels like some kind of profound experience as you travel through this almost dream-like world. The game play is like old-school Zelda, the dry humor is reminscent of EarthBound, and the whole thing will make you feel like you stepped into a time portal to the 1990s. I've only played a couple hours so far and I'm already in love. If you enjoy games with interesting atmospheres, this one is definitely for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197979741653', 'num_games_owned': 1256, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1378309695}
review: First half is a great Zelda-like. Second half starts to fall short, since the game is orientated towards difficult TOP DOWN platforming instead of interesting puzzles. From there on I did not enjoy playing anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005648447', 'num_games_owned': 5285, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1378745614}
review: Une sorte de fantasme, de doux cauchemar/rêve mélancolique, parfois bucolique. Un jeu d'aventure 16 bits "à la Zelda" qui de part ses racines et ses personnages attachants - très rares, le monde étant presque post-apocalyptique - crée une nostalgie inconnue mais familière - un peu comme un vieil ami qu'on aurait retrouvé. Le patchwork de mondes alternatifs qui s'enchainent sans transitions parfois et l'écriture cohérente, voire profonde (solitude, dépression, amitié, moralité) - mais qui ne cherche pas à faire les liens logiques entre toutes les étapes de votre voyage "spirituel" - laissent libre court à toutes les interprétations. La contemplative, sombre et onirique musique du jeu achève l'atmosphère. Comptez 7 heures de jeu pour le terminer à 100%.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048152073', 'num_games_owned': 1339, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1378608042}
review: Great game if you enjoy 2D Legend of Zelda styled games. It has dungeons and puzzles and exploring and some cool boss fights. It's honestly pretty difficult but the fact that you gain more health and can do the dungeons in (almost) any order makes some of the later bosses feel a bit weak. It can be challenging and it can be surprisingly deep in it's characters and it's implications of Young's subconscious mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967599040', 'num_games_owned': 9883, 'num_reviews': 237, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1378716153}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971824969', 'num_games_owned': 3155, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1195, 'last_played': 1378182085}
review:
[Spoiler-Free Review]

Anodyne is an exploration game which borrows heavily from classic 2D Zelda titles (especially Link's Awakening). The dialogue is introspective, the subject matter is mature (sometimes even disturbing). It's also one of the strangest games I've ever played.

Exploration is at the core of the game. If Anodyne was a protest piece against hand-holding in video games it would be considered a masterpiece. You aren't given a whole lot of instruction regarding where to go next. This feels liberating, for the most part, as you alone are free to decide your next course of action. It's also intimidating and frustrating though, as getting lost/stuck at some point through your playthrough is pretty much a given. It's not necessarily bad game design, it's a product of having too open a world and too linear a path to success (i.e. to get past this next section, the player will have needed to speak with this person to get this item). There aren't many indicators letting you know whether you fulfill the prerequirements for an area so there's a lot of trial and error involved. Be patient or look up a guide.

All areas have their own themes and every dungeon offers up new challenges. This isn't the stereotypical fire/ice/earth/water stages type of game, the locales are varied and interesting: ranging from hotels to small towns and highway construction sites.

The soundtrack is excellent and deserves to be praised as such. It reminds me of EARTHBOUND most noticably. The atmosphere is palpable; brooding, imaginative, mysterious. I wish there was a sound test option to be able to listen to the soundtrack from the main title screen.

Aside from having a penchant for getting lost, the only other issues I'd express concerns about are the graphics and the flimsy gamepad controls.

The graphics are muddy and crude, utilizing a palette usually reserved for NES/GBC titles. They don't get in the way of the gameplay, but if you aren't a fan of pixel/sprite based games, you won't be convinced otherwise by Anodyne.

Although the XBOX 360 Controller is supported, the controls for movement are mapped to the analog stick and are very loose. I'd like to say this is a matter of preference, but when you're down to one health bar and your character charges at an enemy with reckless abandon despite your best efforts to carefully evade said foes, it's an issue. Nothing can be more frustrating than losing due to struggles with controls. A simple option to control the character using the digital pad would remedy this issue but as it stands, it isn't an option. I ended up remapping my controls through the joytokey program and my enjoyment with the game increased immediately.

If you like exploration games and don't mind the graphics, pick this one up. It'll surprise you.

P.S.
Anodyne easily takes the title for strangest post-game I've ever experienced. It's beyond interesting.

review:
Anodyne is a top-down dungeon crawler with SNES style graphics.
Your quest in Anodyne is to save the Land from the darkness that has come over it in the form of The Briar. 
Throughout the game you face many bosses who seem to know deep truths about who you really are. They hint at the fact that you play video games to escape from reality, and that one day you will have to learn how to deal with people.
The collecting aspect of the game is very engaging. You must collect cards and keys in order to unlock new areas.
Anodyne offers a beautifully realized SNES-like game world. It has a intriguing story and there are some really great songs that capture the mood of the game quite well.
Anodyne is a good designed old school adventure game and a perfect choice for those who liked the old Zelda games.

Sounds 9/10
Graphics 4/10
Gameplay 7/10
Atmosphere 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198035560545', 'num_games_owned': 3961, 'num_reviews': 224, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1450680366}
review:
Anodyne borrows heavily from early Legend of Zelda, but manages to stand on its own just fine. 

A lot of familiar mechanics are present here: pressing buttons, running through mazes, solving light puzzles, and jumping across holes. However instead of a large repertoire of gadgets and items, Anodyne sticks with one main weapon and a very small amount of items. The mechanics, from boss fighting to exploring, are largely focused around platforming. Jumping at the right time and angle will be essential at certain points of the game. Given the game's rather brief life, it is understanble that gadgets and mechanics are kept fairly contained.

Layered on top of the game is a bizarre narrative. There is certainly some failed humor every now and then, but you will also receive eerie messages, cryptic details, and what seems like nonsense. Also included among the dialog and regular text are the cards hidden throughout the game that act as indirective narrative. It is certainly an intriguing aspect, but don't expect to be rewarded with sure answers.

Anodyne is not without its flaws though. The mix of humor, nonsensical dialogue and strange text will definitely turn away some players. The art style might scream Legend of Zelda, but this adventure has been pared down quite a bit and this is most noticeable through the lack progression and gadgets. For those of you that like secrets there are some pretty extensive ones here, but if you are wanting everything up front, a large portion of the game is kept hidden away.

With a charming aesthetic and surreal narrative, Anodyne is a neat hidden gem. Those that like some mystery and an adventure that's smaller in scope compared to Link's adevntures will get the most out of this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012089036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1479997219}
review: Anodyne is a delightful, surreal, pixel-art masterpiece. Total gameplay time for the main storyline is a bit short (6 hours at  the most) but there are a lot of end-game secrets. Challenge level is minimal, but the environments are spectacular. Unfortunately the various levels do not tie together especially well, so it will probably take a bit of digging on your part to make sense of the world of Anodyne and how its levels relate to one another thematically. Still, it's a solid game for fans of Zelda:LTTP, surrealism, or gamers who love the 'indie' vibe.

As a meditation on the various states of loneliness, aggression and discovery we'd associate with adolescence, it's a little less successful. But also not super in-your-face. Which I appreciate. And as it is, dialog is largely skippable and the most puissant antagonists are fairly succinct. The controls are tight and the broom is pleasantly swishy while simultaneously being delightfully thwacky.Boy I'm getting off track. TL;DR:

This is good. Pacing is good, puzzles are good. Graphics and sound are good. Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007653974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1372096390}
review:
One of the best games I have played in recent memory. With The legend of Zelda: a Link to the Past being on of my favorite games of all time I just had to give this a download and was not dissapointed. 

The gameplay is very reminiscent of old school ALTTP/Links awakening Zelda with an emphesis on puzzle solving and revisiting previous locations. During the game you will come across gates that require cards to get through. The game gives you enough cards to let you experience tha base game but becomes much more difficult and unique with its puzzles if you want to enter the deepest areas of the games. 

The game world is very large and extremely varied with many different locales that can be traversed in a very non-linier fashion. Very late into the game you may notice that you are missing a large number of collectables and will gain an ability unlike any other game in order to fully explore the nooks and crannies of the maps. While doing this you will also be able to discover some very well hidden easter eggs from other indie titles. 

The story is vary sparse and leaves a lot of the reaction up to the player to figure out in an attempt to understand the world you are currently in. 

The soundtrack incredibly well done and can range from slightly eerie and mysterious to down right scary in some sections. 

Overall I cannot recommend this game enough for anyone who enjoys Zelda-like, puzzle or artistic games, or something that requires massive amounts of world exploration.

review: Anodyne is one of these short sweet indie games that offer a great experience while it last. The story stars with a character named young waking up to find himself in a dreamrelm. He then comes across a sage who says he is the chosen one and must   defeat the creatures in order to escape. What makes the story special is how the bosses and NPC's seem to have different ideas about what is going on and sharing them with you. The gameplay is very similar to the old Legend of Zelda games. Both have an overhead view and use a weapon for stabbing your enemies. The main differences come with the limited items and main weapon. You use a broom throughout the game to dispatch enemies and activate switches and the only usable item you obtain is some jumping shoes that allow you to jump which is used allot in later areas. The game looks fantastic with a retro art style. It fits the world and setting nicely and the game isn’t afraid of some dark tones when it wants to. The settings are also quite unique where you find yourself in a hotel or a strange universe instead of your usual dungeons and temples. Music is nice most of the time and has some nice tracks that I wouldn’t mind downloading. Anodyne mages to bring back the dying overhead action adventure genre and does it in such a well way. The game may only be 5-6 hours long but it is well worth the money and it was only made by two guys in less than a year. Pick it up some time and experience it for yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993275299', 'num_games_owned': 1975, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 3152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3152, 'last_played': 1371727492}
review:
Anodyne is a game that a lot of people will look at the visuals and be like "zomg my childhood."  Fuck it, I can't even write a review for this. The game fucking sucks ass. The puzzles are bs in a lot of ways, the game design is pure garbage and it's quite obvious the developers got lazy and gave up.

See the thing is that Anodyne had a really interesting meta story going for it, then about two hours in, the entire thing is completely dropped for no real reason. I was actually quite interested, but then no one ever spoke of the story again. It's easy to get lost in, the puzzles can be obnoxiously bullshit, and it has pointless grinding to continue to the end because the devs couldn't think of any other way to make you keep playing.

The cards are stupid, most of them you won't have any idea where the hell to even find them unless you look up a guide. The game just doesn't tell you. This would be fine if some of the cards didn't require you to magically know that you need to move one ordinary piece of the background in order to get to a "debug" world or something similar.

Honestly, don't waste your time. It's full of so many incredibly frustrating problems that unless you can get it for less than 2 dollars, pass.

Verdict: PASS

author: {'steamid': '76561197974544461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1371585783}
review:
If Legend of Zelda were set in the bizarre fantasy world of a dreaming child, you'd have Anodyne. It's a top-down dungeon crawler that features a large and diverse open-world that makes exploration and discovery quite enjoyable. The game doesn't hold your hand and only offers some subtle hints of direction, although it's never really all that challenging in regards to its combat or puzzle-solving. The 16-bit pixel art style is really well done, thanks largely in part to the terrific use of color that makes for some beautiful locations. The soundtrack is memorable and helps set that dream-like atmosphere that the devs were going for. On the downside, the gamepad controls can be overly sensitive and jumping puzzles tend to become frustrating as a result. Also, while I like that the story is abtract and open to interpretation, it feels unfocused and seems to serve mostly as an excuse to explore some eccentric locales.

In all, Anodyne is a solid Zelda-clone that's able to thrive on its colorful artwork, well-designed dungeons, and a soundtrack that is worth the price of admission by itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981047937', 'num_games_owned': 7422, 'num_reviews': 437, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1371620081}
review:
A surrealist Zelda-alike (although the comparison is a little flawed). Instead of gaining an item per dungeon and never using them again, you instead are introduced to new puzzles/mechanics per stage and then get to see them mixed up or combined as you progress.

Game becomes (almost painfully) non-linear after the halfway point, and has a post-game I did not dabble too heavily in that's apparently pretty experimental. I would wholeheartedly recommend giving this one a shot, because at worst, you're out 5 hours or so when all's said and done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010201020', 'num_games_owned': 1800, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1371650312}

author: {'steamid': '76561198020569610', 'num_games_owned': 3099, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1186, 'last_played': 1366786800}
review:
I leave precious few games with something to think about, but this is one that I will be mulling over for some time. A triumph of ideas, abstraction, incomplete narrative disclosure, and lovingly nostalgic level design... but the discomfiting soundtrack is what truly elevates the experience of playing the game. 

Perhaps not for everyone, but if you have ever loved GBC/GBA era Zelda games--and Earthbound/Mother style JRPGs--that should be enough to get your foot in the door on this one. Support developers who are this committed to making old ideas mean something new.

review: A wonderful surreal adventure born from the minds of developers with true vision. author: {'steamid': '76561198004524283', 'num_games_owned': 755, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1372153755}
review:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4iUpbdmOzMQ&list=PL0E56219EE956754E

Anodyne: A 16-bit game that goes through the very dream like story of Young in his quest to defend the Briar! The story of Anodyne is abstract and ‘weird’ and may come off in a way that becomes unappealing. For me though, Anodyne is a beautifully crafted world with a story that personally interest me, its controls are simple and fitting and each area of the game feels unique as well as strange but interesting. The music in this game also does a wonderful job of creating a very mood altering atmosphere. The game is a lot of ‘puzzle’ solving and plat-forming but never felt too hard to be frustrating but challenging enough to keep me interested. With all that said, if you enjoy 16-bith games with a unique style that harkens to older Zelda titles then I highly recommend Anodyne for its full price and hope you find your own interpretation of the story as so many others have.

-Thumbs Up from Royial

review: Okay, this is just like ... take Zelda: A Link to the Past, increase the difficulty, fill it to the brim with disturbing dream imagery, biting humor, and dark psychological implications, add an extensive (and even more ridiculously hard) postgame, and you'll have Anodyne. author: {'steamid': '76561198015795127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1371604835}
review:
Controls and Mechanics:

The controls are simple, basically you use the arrow keys to move and C to fight and to open doors / solve puzzles.
The combat mechanic is simple as well, you use your mighty sword (actually it is a broom) to attack the enemys while using the arrow keys to dodge.

Puzzles: 

The puzzles are quite interesting. Anywhere you go, you will find a puzzle you need to solve in order to continue with your adventure.
The puzzles require a lot of logic. The most common puzzles in the game require you to play with switches, you will find pushing enemys around a very usefull technic to solve puzzles.

Graphics:

There is not much I can say about the graphics. The style is very simple and old school, I liked it.

Gameplay:

The gameplay in anodyne is not the best, you explore the world, solve puzzles, murder stuff and find collectables. The exploring part is really good, there are different kind of areas to explore with many hidden stuff to find. I find the puzzles really annoying because you encounter them a lot. The main problem for me is that killing stuff is just not satisfying in this game, which is really sad.
There is as far as I know only one weapon, and in my opinion its bad. Yes you do have option to upgrade your weapon but thats all.

Players that don't like to explore will find the game really annoying because you have to explore every inch in the level in order to find cards (keys), without those cards you won't be able to access all the areas, and obviously you won't be able to finish the game.
The game is also really short so don't expect a long adventure. 

Music:

The music in the game is great, it helps the mood and I can definitly say that the music is one of the things that encourge you to play. Every level and biome got it's on music and usually it is also really good.

Story:

The story in the game is really average. The begining make you think it is going to be a really good and interesting story that will suck you in but when you go deeper into the game you get to know that it is not spectacular at all.
You play as Young, a guy with a white hair and wierd glasses that uses a broom to save the world. When you start the game you encounter an old dude that give you a quest to search for "the land", and thats how your adventure starts.

In conclusion, I have to say that maybe others will find the game much more interesting, but I didn't. I can also blame steam offline system, because I played the game while I had free time in the army and I had to be offline and I lost my save games like 4 or 5 times, and it forced me to play through the same areas.

Anyways the game is ok but it gets boring really quick. 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197996550048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1388302109}
review:
Anodyne is a game which I bought for $3 along with a bundle of other assorted indie games. Having finished it, I can wholeheartedly recommend it, even at full price, for it imparts simplicity, solitude, and subtlety that I find rather underappreciated or ignored these days.

The story, ostensibly about a human named Young attempting to protect "The Briar" from "The Darkness" that has spread across "The Land", would be rather uninteresting if it were not for how the game's description directly states that it all takes place within Young's subconscious. Resulting from this is a somewhat lonely journey which focuses more on succinct phrases rather than grandiose spiels and atmosphere over tangibility, overall akin to going through a series of dreams within a larger dream (which is no surprise as Yume Nikki is cited as one of the inspirations for this game). Later on in the game the ideas and caricatures presented occasionally get a bit too obtuse for me to understand, but the main theme of the plot is still clear and I was quite satisfied by the ending. Moreover, Anodyne never interrupts its gameplay for an extended period of time to exposit or pontificate, which is nice as it means players are not forced to care about the game's script if they do not want to. That would be a shame, however, as the multiple lines of dialogue from the game's NPCs and signs tend to be incredibly humorous or chilling, sometimes both at the same time.

Mechanically, the game is not particularly complex; imagine Link's Awakening but with no items outside of the Sword and the Roc's Feather. Although Young gains several equippable upgrades throughout the course of the game, the majority of them just increase the range of his broom, and the enemy and obstacle counts are not particularly high either. As such, the majority of the game consists of exploring the overworld (surprisingly large and spanning multiple environments), slaying enemies (both passive and aggressive), clearing dungeons (about as much as you'd expect in a Zelda game), vanquishing bosses (all of them uniquely designed and fairly tough), and ultimately collecting cards which are required to progress further in the game.

Nonetheless, the rooms of each dungeon tend to be designed well enough that old adversaries often offer new challenges. There are also some tricky puzzles and platforming sections as well, the latter sometimes becoming a bit too tricky due to the top-down perspective. Honestly though, there are only two points of contention I truly have with the gameplay. Firstly, the collection of said cards might put off players who do not enjoy backtracking and exploring EVERYWHERE. I was personally okay with it, though Young's mediocre movement speed made the task plodding at times. Secondly, the post-game is rather lackluster, basically furthering the card seeking with a late-introduced gimmick which can be hard to control along with literally exploiting glitches; it feels like an afterthought. Other than that, the simplicity of the game is a mark in its favor.

Moving on to aesthetics, the game describes its visuals as "GBC/16-bit", which is certainly true and they are sprited very well in that style, but what really stood out to me were the gorgeous overlays that complimented many of the game's areas. I'm particularly a fan of the cliffs (pictured above), which are bathed in a warm sunset's glow, along with some later, gloomier areas which would be a shame to spoil. The sound design is excellent as well, especially the "Obtain Key" noise which is utterly jarring and I love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004594294', 'num_games_owned': 1773, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1371604968}
review:
Anodyne is an action game with lock and key puzzles.  Put your Zelda franchise preconceptions aside.  The keys are not weapons.  When they're not literal keys, they're a set amount of collectible cards.  Your actions are limited.

That said, the combat is solid.  The variation of the world and the wonderful soundtrack helped maintain my interest.  While the story felt fractured, the dreamlike atmosphere worked well with the overall nostalgia.  Me likey.

I finished the game with 37 cards and earned a 100% achievement.  I don't know if I'll ever go back to get all of the post-game cards and items.  At that point, the play begins to reference glitches as might by used by Zelda speedrunners.  It's mildly interesting, but that's sort of thing I tend to see in a YouTube video and then never bother with again.  The main game is enough for me for now.

review: A very solid 16-bit, Zelda-ish Indie game. It's got a beautiful art style and soundtrack which gives a very nice ambience. The combat is okay; smacking around enemies with your only weapon, a broom. The story isn't that great as it gets confusing and it's not very straight forward on what to do, so you get lost at points. It's a very nostalgic type game and has a few Easter Egg secrets found in it such as The Binding of Isaac, Pokemon, and Legend of Zelda. It's surprising that this game was made by only two college students. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who is looking to take a trip back to the good ol' Gameboy era days. 7/10.

review: This is one fun adventure game. author: {'steamid': '76561198009508007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1374411487}
review:
If you happen to enjoy the Zelda titles on Game Boy (Color) and consider atmosphere and immersion to be a big part of your gaming experience, then by all means, give Anodyne a chance.
Initially initerested in the similarities to one of my favourite game franchises and my favourite games within, I was treated to an astoundingly well designed gem. Only having stumbled across this by chance I can't believe what I would have missed out here, sound design, level design, gameplay, everything seems to be exactly in place where it should be. All of this while retaining an ominous and mysterious world I for once actually felt like I was exploring something new.

Anyone who considered this game on a first glance, don't worry, you won't be disappointed if you purchase into this indie gem, and to anyone else, give yourself a push! You won't regret it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198023115742', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 1920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1027, 'last_played': 1645925062}
review:
[i]Anodyne[/i] could perhaps be best described as the lovechild of [i]The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening[/i] (the original Game Boy/Color versions) and [i]Yume Nikki[/i]. Combat is present, but there is a much stronger focus on exploration and soaking in the atmosphere.

Interestingly, there isn't much of anything when it comes to weapons, tools, or upgrades. At the beginning of the game you are given a broom (which functions much the same as a sword in any given 2D [i]Zelda[/i] title) and that's all you get for the entire game. As such, most of the game's puzzles revolve around discovering the various ways in which you can use the broom with the environment. You may be surprised at how versatile piles of dust can be.

Aside from HP upgrades and a few equipable modifications for your broom, the only other major collectibles are trading cards hidden in treasure chests. As you explore The Land you will occasionally bump into gates that require a certain amount of cards in order to open. Collecting these cards becomes your primary method of progression.

Although there are certain recurring themes, there is no real story or narrative to follow. This might disappoint some, but I feel like those who wanted a story from this game are maybe missing the point a little. [i]Anodyne[/i] seems far more focused on creating a strong atmosphere and evoking certain feelings than telling any sort of real narrative, and that's okay. The pixel art is often gorgeous with a strong aesthetic coherence, and the moody, ambient soundtrack is among the best of its genre. The two complement and elevate each other wonderfully.

It's definitely not going to be for everyone, but [i]Anodyne[/i] is among my favorite indie games and is well worth a look for anyone who might be interested in a more slow-paced and introspective [i]Zelda[/i]-like.
